    "1958-06-15T07:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "\n1950: The United States establishes diplomatic relations with Cambodia on June 29, with the appointment of Donald R. Heath as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary. The U.S. Legation opens in Phnom Penh on November 14 at the renowned Hotel Le Royal.  A Legation office and U.S. Information Service library are later established at a new location. The Legation is raised to Embassy status on June 25, 1952, at which point Heath becomes the first U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia.\n\n\n\n1953: Cambodia declares its full independence from France on November 9, after intense negotiations between King Norodom Sihanouk and the French governmentwith the United States often acting as mediator. Throughout the talks, the United States actively supports Cambodias bid for autonomy, although France does not fully cede authority over Cambodia until the Geneva Conference in 1954.\n\n\n\n1955: The United States establishes an assistance program in Cambodia with a budget of $50 million per year. The aid seeks to promote Cambodias economic and social progress by improving and expanding public education, building infrastructure, and modernizing the armed forces among other activities. The aid program is larger in size and scope than the combined support from all other countries and international organizations, with the United States providing $493 million in assistance by 1963.\n\n\n\n1958: Sihanouk, who abdicated the throne in 1955 and took the title of Prince, becomes the first Cambodian head of state to visit the United States. His itinerary includes stops in Washington, D.C., New York City, Detroit, Chicago, and Los Angeles. The Princes visit causes a stir in diplomatic circles, particularly following the Cambodian-themed parties he organizes in New York and Washington that include a traditional Khmer dance recital by the Royal Cambodian Ballet. During talks with President Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Prince presents a 12th-century solid granite Angkorian Buddha that still stands today in Washingtons National Gallery.\n\n\n1959: Cambodia unveils National Highway Four, built with $25 million of U.S. assistance. The 140-mile road, which links Phnom Penh to Sihanoukville, is dubbed the Khmer-American Friendship Highway. Built by American and Cambodian laborers working side by side, the road is the single largest cooperative aid project in Cambodia. U.S. development assistance also helps repair a further 800 miles of road and 43 bridges throughout the country.", 
        "id": "79770243223_10150634521558224", 
        "kh": "—’’’’"
    }, 
    "1959-06-15T07:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "Prince Norodom Sihanouk, U.S. Secretary of Interior Fred Seaton, and Ambassador Trimble inaugurate the U.S.  Cambodian Friendship road linking Phnom Penh with Sihanoukville on July 22, 1959.\n\n    Fred Seaton  Trimble       ", 
        "id": "79770243223_10150634522763224", 
        "kh": "–សម្តេចព្រះនរោត្តមសីហនុលោករដ្ឋមន្រ្តីក្រសួងមហាផ្ទៃនិងលោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតសម្ភាធផ្លូវមិត្តភាពកម្ពូជាអាមេរិកដែលភ្ជាប់ទីក្រុងភ្នំពេញទៅក្រុងព្រះសីហនុនៅថ្ងៃទី២២ខែកក្កដាឆ្នាំ១៩៥៩។"
    }, 
    "1960-06-15T07:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "1961: Cambodian architect Vann Molyvann unveils the Chaktomuk Conference Hall in Phnom Penh. Considered a masterpiece of New Khmer Architecture  a movement that unites modernist sensibilities with distinctly Cambodian traditions  the building is constructed with the help of U.S. assistance. Vann Molyvann helps usher in a golden age of Khmer culture, during which architecture, music, and film flourish until the Khmer Rouge takeover in 1975.\n \n1962: The International Court of Justice in The Hague rules in favor of Cambodia in a dispute with Thailand over Preah Vihear, an 11th century temple located in a disputed area near the Thai border. Former U.S. Secretary of State Dean Acheson successfully represents Cambodia in the case, which many observers had predicted would see Thailand prevail. After the verdict, Prince Norodom Sihanouk proclaims a seven-day national holiday and the country erupts into mass celebrations.\n\n1965: With the conflict escalating in Vietnam, border incursions into eastern Cambodia increase and result in civilian casualties. Prince Sihanouk fears for his countrys territorial integrity and seeks assurances from both the United States and communist governments. His political power is further threatened by dissident groups. Meanwhile, the United States claims that the Cambodian military is cooperating with Viet Cong forces. Unable to resolve their grievances, the United States and Cambodia officially sever diplomatic ties in May. Relations are not restored until the end of the decade.\n\n1967: Jacqueline Kennedy visits Cambodia in November as a personal guest of Prince Sihanouk. A crowd of 10,000 greets her at Pochentong Airport in Phnom Penh, including girls strewing jasmine petals in a traditional Buddhist welcome. During her trip, the former First Lady fulfills a lifelong dream of visiting Angkor Wat. She is the first American to be received with high state honors since ties were broken, signaling a promising turn in the relationship.\n\n1969: President Richard M. Nixon orders a covert bombing campaign of eastern Cambodia. Operation Menu lasts 14 months and results in the release of some 2,756,941 tons of ordnance. Nixon authorizes the bombings in an attempt to thwart Viet Cong forces, which by 1970 occupy between a fifth and a third of Cambodian territory. The campaign does not become known to the American public until 1973.\n\n1969: Diplomatic relations are restored. The U.S. Embassy reopens on August 16, with Lloyd M. Rives acting as Charg dAffaires ad interim and a staff of eight. Later that month, in an effort to demonstrate Washingtons renewed commitment to Cambodia, U.S. Senator Mike Mansfield visits Phnom Penh for the third time in seven years. During the visit, Prince Sihanouk calls the Senator one of the greatest and most loyal friends to Cambodia.\n\n:                      \n\n:       Dean Acheson          \n\n:                    \n\n:  Jacqueline Kennedy                      \n\n:  Richard M. Nixon       Operation Menu                 \n\n:      Lloyd M. Rives         Mike Mansfield           ", 
        "id": "79770243223_10150634532093224", 
        "kh": "––’é’’“”១៩៦១លោកវណ្ណម៉ូលីវណ្ណដែលជាស្ថាបត្យករខ្មែរម្នាក់បានធ្វើស្ថាបនាសាលសន្និសីទចតុមុខនៅភ្នំពេញ។ដោយត្រូវបានគេចាត់ទុកថាជាស្នាដៃឯកនៃស្ថាបត្យកម្មខ្មែរសម័យទំនើបដែលជាចលនាបន្ស៊ីគ្នារវាងចំណូលចិត្តរបស់ជនសម័យនិយមនិងប្រពៃណីដោយឡែករបស់ខ្មែរអាគារនេះត្រូវបានកសាងឡើងជាមួយនឹងជំនួយរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិក។លោកវណ្ណម៉ូលីវណ្ណបាននាំមកនូវយុគសម័យរុងរឿងនៃវប្បធម៌របស់ខ្មែរដែលក្នុងនោះស្ថាបត្យកម្មតន្ត្រីនិងភាពយន្តមានការរីកដុះដាលរហូតមកទល់នឹងពេលដែលខ្មែរក្រហមឡើងកាន់អំណាចនៅឆ្នាំ១៩៧៥។១៩៦២តុលាការអន្តរជាតិក្រុងឡាអេបានសំរេចអោយកម្ពុជាឈ្នះប្រទេសថៃក្នុងជំលោះប្រាសាទព្រះវិហារដែលត្រូវបានកសាងឡើងនៅសតវត្សទី១១នៅតំបន់មានជំលោះជិតព្រំដែនថៃ។លោកអតីតរដ្ឋមន្ត្រីការបរទេសអាមេរិកបានធ្វើជាតំណាងអោយភាគីកម្ពុជាប្រកបដោយជោគជ័យក្នុងរឿងក្តីនេះដែលអ្នកសង្កេតការជាច្រើនបានទស្សន៍ទាយថាប្រទេសថៃនឹងឈ្នះ។ក្រោយពីការចេញសាលក្រមសម្តេចសីហនុបានប្រកាសការឈប់សំរាកការងាររយៈពេល៧ថ្ងៃហើយនៅទូទាំងប្រទេសមានការអបអរយ៉ាងខ្លាំង។១៩៦៥នៅពេលដែលការប្រយុទ្ធគ្នានៅវៀតណាមរីករាលដាលកាន់តែខ្លាំងការវាយប្រហារឆ្លងកាត់ព្រំដែនចូលភាគខាងកើតនៃប្រទេសសកម្ពុជាមានកាន់តែច្រើនហើយបាននាំអោយជនស៊ីវិលស្លាប់និងរបួស។សម្តេចសីហនុមានការព្រួយបារម្ភចំពោះបូរណភាពទឹកដីនៃប្រទេសរបស់ទ្រង់ហើយបានស្វែងរកការធានាពីសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកផងនិងពីរដ្ឋាភិបាលកុំម្មុយនិស្តផង។អំណាចនយោបាយរបស់ព្រះអង្គកាន់តែរងការគំរាមកំហែងច្រើនឡើងៗពីពួកក្រុមប្រឆាំង។ទន្ទឹមនឹងនោះសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកបានអះអាងថាយោធាកម្ពុជាធ្វើសហប្រតិបត្តិការជាមួយវៀតកុង។ដោយមិនអាចដោះស្រាយការមិនត្រូវគ្នារបស់គេបានសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនិងប្រទេសកម្ពុជាបានកាត់ផ្តាច់ទំនាក់ទំនងការទូតជាមួយគ្នានៅខែឧសភា។រហូតមកទល់នឹងដំណាច់ទសវត្សនោះទើបទំនាក់ទំនងត្រូវបានស្តារអោយមានឡើងវិញ។១៩៦៧លោកជំទាវបានធ្វើទស្សនកិច្ចនៅកម្ពុជាជាភ្ញៀវពិសេសរបស់សម្តេចសីហនុនៅខែវិច្ឆិកា។មានមនុស្សប្រមាណ១០០០០នាក់បានទទួលលោកជំទាវនៅព្រលានយន្តហោះពោចិនតុងនៅភ្នំពេញដោយមានផ្កាម្លិះត្រូវបានគេរោយជាលក្ខណៈស្វាគមន៍តាមប្រពៃណីព្រះពុទ្ធសាសនា។ក្នុងអំឡុងទស្សនកិច្ចនោះលោកជំទាវទីមួយបានបំពេញសុបិនក្នុងជ្ងីវិតរបស់លោកជំទាវដែលចង់ទស្សនាប្រាសាទអង្គវត្ត។លោកជំទាវគឺជាជនជាតិអាមេរិកដំបូងគេដែលទទួលបាននូវកិត្តិយសថ្នាក់រដ្ឋខ្ពស់តាំងពីទំនាក់ទំនងត្រូវបានកាត់ផ្តាច់ដែលជាសញ្ញានៃការប្រែប្រួលគួរជាទីសង្ឃឹមនៃទំនាក់ទំនង។១៩៦៩លោកប្រធានាធិបតីបានអនុញ្ញាតិអោយមានយុទ្ធនាការទំលាក់គ្រាប់បែកដោយសំងាត់នៅភាគឥសានប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។ប្រតិបត្តិការនេះដែលមានឈ្មោះថាមានរយៈពេល១៤ខែហើយបានទំលាក់គ្រាប់បែកចំនួន២៧៥៦៩៤១តោន។លោកប្រធានាធិបតីបានអនុញ្ញាតិអោយមានការទំលាក់គ្រាប់បែកនេះដើម្បីទប់ដំណើរទៅមុខនៃពួកកុំម្មុយនិស្តវៀតកុងដែលរហូតមកដល់ឆ្នាំ១៩៧០បានកាន់កាប់ពី១ភាគ៥ទៅ១ភាគ៣នៃទឹកដីកម្ពុជា។រហូតមកដល់ឆ្នាំ១៩៧៣ទើបសាធារណជនអាមេរិកដឹងពីការទំលាក់គ្រាប់បែកនេះ។១៩៦៩ទំនាក់ទំនងការទូតត្រូវបានស្តារឡើងវិញ។ស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកបានចាប់ផ្តើមបើកឡើងវិញនៅថ្ងៃទី១៦ខែសីហាដោយមានលោកជាភារធារីហើយមានបុគ្គលិកចំនួន៨នាក់។ក្រោយមកនៅក្នុងខែដដែលនោះដើម្បីបង្ហាញពីការប្តេជ្ញាចិត្តថ្មីរបស់ក្រុងវ៉ាស៊ីនតោនចំពោះប្រទេសកម្ពុជាលោកព្រឹទ្ធសមាជិកសភាបានត្រឡប់មកភ្នំពេញវិញជាលើកទី៣ក្នុងរយៈពេល៧ឆ្នាំ។ក្នុងអំឡុងទស្សនកិច្ចនោះសម្តេចសីហនុបានហៅលោកព្រឹទ្ធសមាជិកថាជា“មិត្តម្នាក់របស់កម្ពុជាដែលអស្ចារ្យនិងស្មោះត្រង់បំផុត”។"

        "eng": "Jacqueline Kennedy visits Cambodia in November 1967 as a personal guest of Prince Sihanouk. A crowd of 10,000 greets her at Pochentong Airport in Phnom Penh, including girls strewing jasmine petals in a traditional Buddhist welcome. During her trip, the former First Lady fulfills a lifelong dream of visiting Angkor Wat. She is the first American to be received with high state honors since ties were broken, signaling a promising turn in the relationship.\n\n Jacqueline Kennedy                       ",

    "2009-06-15T07:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": ":              \n\n:  Bill Clinton          Clinton         %  %    \n\n:              \n\n:     Peace Corps               \n\n:                                    ,  \n\n2003: The United States and Cambodia sign an agreement to restrict the import of Cambodian artifacts into the U.S.  market, in an attempt to prevent looting of Cambodias cultural heritage. A highlight of the deal is the repatriation in 2007 of a sandstone Apsara dancer from the 13th Century that had been smuggled into the United States. U.S. assistance also helps restore some of Cambodias most precious Angkorean monuments, including an ambitious $1.5 million project to preserve Phnom Bakheng temple.\n\n2006: Former President Bill Clinton visits Cambodia in December. During a meeting with Prime Minister Hun Sen, he signs a memorandum of understanding under which his Clinton Foundation will provide support in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Meanwhile, bilateral U.S. assistance makes a major impact on HIV/AIDS over the course of the decade, helping to cut the diseases prevalence rate from 2% to less than 1%, making Cambodia a rare success story in the global fight against the disease.\n\n2006: The United States opens a new Embassy in January. The facility, which is located next to the famed Wat Phnom temple on Phnom Penhs north side, occupies an entire city block and houses over 500 employees. As the first purpose-built U.S. Embassy in Cambodia, the new complex is a sign of growing U.S. engagement in the country.\n\n2007: On April 4, the Peace Corps swears in its first class of volunteers to serve in Cambodia. The 29 volunteers serve their two-year tours living with Cambodian families in rural villages throughout the country, teaching English at upper secondary schools and regional teacher training centers. Successive classes swell in size as the decade continues.\n\n2009: The Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, better known as the Khmer Rouge tribunal, begins its first case on February 16. The defendant is Kaing Guek Eav, better known by his revolutionary name Duch, who oversaw the torture and execution of some 12,000 people as warden of Tuol Sleng prison. After 30 years of waiting, Cambodian witnesses finally appear in a court of law to describe the horrors they endured under the Democratic Kampuchea regime. A verdict in Duchs case is expected in the summer of 2010. Meanwhile, the four remaining Khmer Rouge leaders in custody are likely to face trial in 2011. The United States has committed $6.8 million to support the trial.",

    "2010-04-29T07:46:56+0000": {
        "eng": "Cambodian Acid Survivors Charity is an INGO registered in the U.S. which is committed to empowering and supporting survivors of acid burns and eliminating acid violence through legal reform and preventative education.  The center for acid attack victims is located in Srok Angk Snuol, Kandal Province, on a dirt road adjacent to the Bridgestone tire factory on Hwy 4.  The Cambodian Acid Survivors Charity (CASC) was established in 2006 by its sister organization, The Childrens Surgical Center, in response to a growing number of acid burn survivors seeking treatment at the center.  CASC is the only organization in Cambodia dealing exclusively with the issue of acid burns and acid attacks.  Using a holistic approach, they work at several levels to support and empower survivors of acid burns, as well as towards the elimination of acid violence altogether.  According to Ziad Samman, the CASC coordinator, in Cambodia there are currently around 233 acid attack survivors on the national registry.  Last year alone there were 28 acid attacks resulting in 33 victims.  While this number is alarming, Mr. Ziad feels that the number may be far greater and possibly as high as over 100 per year.  If you, or anyone you know is suffering from an acid attack, please contact the CASC Emergency Hotline number  at 092-600-031.  All services are free of charge.", 
        "id": "79770243223_121929307818033", 
        "kh": "’"

    "2010-05-20T09:04:52+0000": {
        "eng": "By Jennifer 8. Lee\nFortune cookies are universally recognized in the United States, but they confuse people in China. If you give fortune cookies to the Chinese, they are utterly perplexed. First they ask you, What is it? When you tell them its from America, they will nod. Then they will bite into it and become startled when they find a little piece of paper either in their mouth or in this cookie. They ask you what that paper is. You tell them, Its a fortune. They will mutter, Americans are so strange. Why are they putting pieces of paper in their cookies?\nRead more: http://www.america.gov/st/diversity-english/2009/February/20090212085747mlenuhret0.7881586.html#ixzz0oSUu4Uia",

    "2010-05-28T03:22:15+0000": {
        "eng": "  \n\nWatch video of the Environmental Fair celebrating the 40th anniversary of Earth Day.\n\nAmbassador Carol A. Rodley hosted the event, which featured displays by 14 local environmental NGOs and eco-businesses, nature-themed song and dance performances, and a recyclable art contest. The Embassy invited 10 high school teams to submit entries in the contest, which showcased conservation messages or ways in which trash can be reused. The teams rose to the challenge, creating innovative sculptures out of used paper, cans, bottles, straws, and other materials. The sculptures were judged at the fair by Ambassador Rodley, Minister of Environment Mok Mareth, Deputy Director of the Department of Education, Youth, and Sport Mr. Huot Samreth, and children from the Maryknoll Little Sprouts Program. Team Rescue from Indra Devy High School took the top prize with their rendering of a Cambodian fisherman out of recycled paper.\n\nRead more: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/earthday_april_2010.html",

    "2010-08-02T08:27:54+0000": {
        "eng": "\n1950: The United States establishes diplomatic relations with Cambodia on June 29, with the appointment of Donald R. Heath as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary. The U.S. Legation opens in Phnom Penh on November 14 at the renowned Hotel Le Royal.  A Legation office and U.S. Information Service library are later established at a new location. The Legation is raised to Embassy status on June 25, 1952, at which point Heath becomes the first U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia.\n\n\n\n1953: Cambodia declares its full independence from France on November 9, after intense negotiations between King Norodom Sihanouk and the French governmentwith the United States often acting as mediator. Throughout the talks, the United States actively supports Cambodias bid for autonomy, although France does not fully cede authority over Cambodia until the Geneva Conference in 1954.\n\n\n\n1955: The United States establishes an assistance program in Cambodia with a budget of $50 million per year. The aid seeks to promote Cambodias economic and social progress by improving and expanding public education, building infrastructure, and modernizing the armed forces among other activities. The aid program is larger in size and scope than the combined support from all other countries and international organizations, with the United States providing $493 million in assistance by 1963.\n\n\n\n1958: Sihanouk, who abdicated the throne in 1955 and took the title of Prince, becomes the first Cambodian head of state to visit the United States. His itinerary includes stops in Washington, D.C., New York City, Detroit, Chicago, and Los Angeles. The Princes visit causes a stir in diplomatic circles, particularly following the Cambodian-themed parties he organizes in New York and Washington that include a traditional Khmer dance recital by the Royal Cambodian Ballet. During talks with President Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Prince presents a 12th-century solid granite Angkorian Buddha that still stands today in Washingtons National Gallery.\n\n\n1959: Cambodia unveils National Highway Four, built with $25 million of U.S. assistance. The 140-mile road, which links Phnom Penh to Sihanoukville, is dubbed the Khmer-American Friendship Highway. Built by American and Cambodian laborers working side by side, the road is the single largest cooperative aid project in Cambodia. U.S. development assistance also helps repair a further 800 miles of road and 43 bridges throughout the country.", 
        "id": "79770243223_415368903223", 
        "kh": "—’’’’"

    "2010-08-05T09:46:00+0000": {
        "eng": "Question from Thailand on social entrepreneurship and energy consumption.\n\nFor question from Cambodian student, please click the link below:\nhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LFij9UX3-Vo", 
        "id": "79770243223_150071731670127", 
        "kh": ""
    }, 
    "2010-08-06T02:45:10+0000": {
        "eng": "1991: At the Paris Conference in October, Phnom Penh and the anti-government resistance reach an historic peace accord, setting the stage for UN-administered elections. On November 14, Prince Norodom Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 13 years in exile. He rides from the airport into Phnom Penh in a 1963 Chevrolet Impala convertible, as a large crowd lines the road, cheering and waving flags. Later that month, the city celebrates its first water festival  one of the biggest celebrations on the Khmer calendar  since 1969.\n\n1991: In November, the United States restores diplomatic relations with Cambodia, ends economic sanctions, and resumes development assistance. On November 11, a U.S. liaison office opens in Phnom Penh and Charles H. Twining is appointed U.S. Representative. By 1992, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) re-opens its permanent mission to Cambodia, and the agencys total budget for the decade reaches $264 million. U.S. assistance \nre-opens National Road 4, which was originally built by the United States in the 1950s and runs from Phnom Penh to the countrys only deep-water port, Sihanoukville.\n\n1992: The UN Transition Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC) takes over administration of Cambodia. U.S. assistance pays for 30% of UNTACs budget and supports its mandate of establishing a freely elected government. Leading the mission is Yasushi Akashi, a senior UN diplomat in charge of 16,000 soldiers and 5,000 civilians. Two of these civilian advisors, American diplomat Timothy Carney and American academic Stephen Heder, supervise the opening of Cambodias first free press since 1972 and create Radio UNTAC, a popular source of unbiased information in Khmer.\n\n1993: On May 28, 90% of Cambodians ignore threats of violence and vote in the countrys first democratic election, surpassing even the most hopeful predictions. FUNCINPEC party receives 45% of the vote, while CPP receives 38%. In September, the newly formed Constituent Assembly approves a constitution, and Norodom Sihanouk is crowned King. He appoints Prince Ranariddh as First Prime Minister and Hun Sen as Second Prime Minister.\n\n1998: On April 15, Pol Pot dies of natural causes in a jungle camp near the Thai border. His body is cremated on a funeral pyre made of tires. The Khmer Rouge, which had been dwindling in numbers due to defections of key leaders, perishes with him. President Clinton who was in Chile at the time, issues a\nwritten statement noting that ''Although the opportunity to hold Pol Pot accountable for his monstrous crimes appears to have passed, senior Khmer Rouge, who exercised leadership from 1975 to 1979, are still at large and share responsibility for the monstrous human rights abuses committed during this period. We must not permit the death of the most notorious of the Khmer Rouge leaders to deter us from the equally important task of bringing these others to justice.''\n\n:                  Chevrolet Impala            \n\n:          Charles H. Twining      (USAID)                \n\n:  ()   %      Yasushi Akashi             Timothy Carney    Stephen Heder        \n\n:    %       %   %            \n\n:            Clinton   Chile                 ", 
        "id": "79770243223_416733303223", 
        "kh": "––’’’’’១៩៩១នៅក្នុងសន្និសីទក្រុងប៉ារីសនៅខែតុលាក្រុងភ្នំពេញនិងក្រុមតស៊ូប្រឆាំងរដ្ឋាភិបាលបានឈានដល់កិច្ចព្រមព្រៀងជាប្រវត្តិសាស្ត្រមួយដែលបាននាំដល់ការបោះឆ្នោតមួយក្រោមការចាត់ចែងរបស់អង្គការសហប្រជាជាតិ។នៅថ្ងៃទី១៤ខែវិច្ឆិកាសម្តេចសីហនុបានយាងត្រឡប់មកប្រទេសកម្ពុជាវិញបន្ទាប់ពីនៅនិរទេសព្រះកាយអស់រយៈពេល១៣ឆ្នាំមក។ព្រះអង្គបានគង់លើរថយន្តអត់ដំបូលម៉ាកផលិតនៅឆ្នាំ១៩៦៣ពីព្រលានយន្តហោះចូលមកក្រុងភ្នំពេញដោយមានមនុស្សជាច្រើនឈរអមសងខាងផ្លូវថ្នល់ដើម្បីអបអរនិងគ្រវីទង់ជាតិ។នៅពេលក្រោយមកក្នុងខែដដែលនោះក្រុងភ្នំពេញបានអបអរទិវាបុណ្យអុំទូកជាលើកដំបូងតាំងពីឆ្នាំ១៩៦៩មក។បុណ្យនេះស្ថិតក្នុងចំណោមបុណ្យធំជាងគេតាមបក្រតីទិនខ្មែរ។១៩៩១នៅខែវិច្ឆិកាសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកបានភ្ជាប់ទំនាក់ទំនងការទូតឡើងវិញជាមួយកម្ពុជាបញ្ចប់ការដាក់ទណ្ឌកម្មសេដ្ឋកិច្ចហើយបន្តជំនួយអភិវឌ្ឍន៍ឡើងវិញ។នៅថ្ងៃទី១១ខែវិច្ឆិកាការិយាល័យទំនាក់ទំនងរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកបានបើកនៅទីក្រុងភ្នំពេញហើយលោកត្រូវបានតែងតាំងជាតំណាងរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិក។នៅឆ្នាំ១៩៩២ទីភ្នាក់ងារសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកសំរាប់ការអភិវឌ្ឍន៍អន្តរជាតិបានបើកបេសកកម្មអចិន្ត្រៃយ៍របស់ខ្លួននៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជាឡើងវិញហើយថវិការបស់ទីភ្នាក់ងារនេះសំរាប់ទសវត្សនោះជាសរុបឡើងដល់២៦៤លានដុល្លាអាមេរិក។ជំនួយរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកបានបើកផ្លូវជាតិលេខ៤ឡើងវិញ។ផ្លូវនេះត្រូវបានកសាងពីដំបូងមកដោយសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនៅទសវត្សឆ្នាំ១៩៥០ហើយភ្ជាប់ពីទីក្រុងភ្នំពេញទៅកំពង់ផែសមុទ្រទឹកជ្រៅតែមួយគត់របស់ប្រទេសកម្ពុជានៅក្រុងព្រះសីហនុ។១៩៩២អាជ្ញាធរបណ្តោះអាសន្នរបស់អង្គការសហប្រជាជាតិនៅកម្ពុជាអ៊ុនតាក់បានទទួលគ្រប់គ្រងប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។ជំនួយរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកទ្រទ្រង់៣០នៃថវិការបស់អ៊ុនតាក់ហើយបានជួយដល់ការបង្កើតរដ្ឋាភិបាលមួយតាមការបោះឆ្នោតដោយសេរី។ប្រមុខបេសកកម្មនោះគឺលោកដែលជាអ្នកការទូតជាន់ខ្ពស់របស់សហប្រជាជាតិហើយទទួលបន្ទុកលើទាហានចំនួន១៦០០០នាក់និងបុគ្គលិកស៊ីវិលចំនួន៥០០០នាក់។ទីប្រឹក្សាផ្នែកស៊ីវិលពីរនាក់គឺអ្នកការទូតអាមេរិកឈ្មោះនិងអ្នកជំនាញម្នាក់ជាជាតិអាមេរិកឈ្មោះបានគ្រប់គ្រងការបើកផ្នែកសារព័ត៌មានសេរីលើកដំបូងនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជាតាំងពីឆ្នាំ១៩៧២មកហើយបានបង្កើតវិទ្យុអ៊ុនតាក់ដែលជាប្រភពមានគេចូលចិត្តច្រើនក្នុងការផ្តល់ព័ត៌មានដោយមិនលំអៀងជាភាសាខ្មែរ។១៩៩៣នៅថ្ងៃទី២៨ខែឧសភា៩០នៃប្រជាជនកម្ពុជាមិនរវល់នឹងការគំរាមកំហែងដោយហឹង្សាហើយបានបោះឆ្នោតតាមលទ្ធិប្រជាធិបតេយ្យជាលើកដំបូងនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជាដែលជាការមានលើសពីការព្យាករណ៍ប្រកបដោយសុទិដ្ឋិនិយមបំផុត។គណបក្សហ៊្វុនស៊ិនប៉ិចបានទទួលសំលេងឆ្នោតចំនួន៤៥ចំណែកគណបក្សប្រជាជនបានទទួលសំលេងឆ្នោតចំនួន៣៨។នៅខែកញ្ញាសភាធម្មនុញ្ញដែលទើបតែត្រូវបានបង្កើតឡើងបានអនុម័តរដ្ឋធម្មនុញ្ញហើយសម្តេចនរោត្តមសីហនុបានឡើងគ្រងរាជសម្បត្តិជាព្រះមហាក្សត្រ។ព្រះអង្គបានតែងតាំងព្រះអង្គម្ចាស់នរោត្តមរ៉ាណារិទ្ធជានាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រីទី១និងលោកហ៊ុនសែនជានាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រីទី២។១៩៩៨នៅថ្ងៃទី១៥ខែមេសាប៉ុលពតបានស្លាប់ដោយជរាភាពនៅក្នុងជំរុំក្នុងព្រៃជិតព្រំដែនថៃ។សពរបស់គាត់ត្រូវបានបូជាក្នុងគំនរកង់ឡាន។ក្រុមខ្មែរក្រហមដែលមានចំនួនសមាជិកកាន់តែថយចុះដោយសារការរត់ចោលក្រុមនៃមេដឹកនាំសំខាន់ៗរបស់គេក៏បានរលាយរលត់ទៅជាមួយគាត់ដែរ។លោកប្រធានាធិបតីដែលនៅពេលនោះលោកកំពុងតែនៅប្រទេសបានថ្លែងជាលាយលក្ខណ៍អក្សរថាទោះបីជាឱកាសកាត់ទោសប៉ុលពតចំពោះឧក្រិដ្ឋុកម្មដ៏ឃោឃៅនេះបានកន្លងហួសទៅក៏ដោយប៉ុន្តែនៅមានមេដឹកនាំជាន់ខ្ពស់ក្នុងរបបនេះដ៏ទៃទៀតដែលបានទទួលខុសត្រូវចំពោះការដឹកនាំប្រទេសកម្ពុជានិងរំលោភសិទ្ធិមនុស្សពីឆ្នាំ១៩៧៥ដល់ឆ្នាំ១៩៧៩។យើងមិនត្រូវអនុញ្ញាតិអោយមរណភាពរបស់មេដឹកនាំខ្មែរក្រហមម្នាក់បង្អាក់ការនាំយកមេដឹកនាំដទៃទៀតរបស់របបនេះទៅកាត់ទោសចំពោះមុខច្បាប់នោះទេ។"

        "kh": "លោកអ្នកអាចសៀវភៅអំពីទំនាក់ទំនងរវាងសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនិងកម្ពុជាបានដោយចុចខាងលើ។សៀវភៅនេះមានសរសេរជាភាសាអង់គ្លេសនិងខ្មែរ។"

    "2010-08-09T06:55:22+0000": {
        "eng": ":              \n\n:  Bill Clinton          Clinton         %  %    \n\n:              \n\n:     Peace Corps               \n\n:                                    ,  \n\n2003: The United States and Cambodia sign an agreement to restrict the import of Cambodian artifacts into the U.S.  market, in an attempt to prevent looting of Cambodias cultural heritage. A highlight of the deal is the repatriation in 2007 of a sandstone Apsara dancer from the 13th Century that had been smuggled into the United States. U.S. assistance also helps restore some of Cambodias most precious Angkorean monuments, including an ambitious $1.5 million project to preserve Phnom Bakheng temple.\n\n2006: Former President Bill Clinton visits Cambodia in December. During a meeting with Prime Minister Hun Sen, he signs a memorandum of understanding under which his Clinton Foundation will provide support in the fight against HIV/AIDS. Meanwhile, bilateral U.S. assistance makes a major impact on HIV/AIDS over the course of the decade, helping to cut the diseases prevalence rate from 2% to less than 1%, making Cambodia a rare success story in the global fight against the disease.\n\n2006: The United States opens a new Embassy in January. The facility, which is located next to the famed Wat Phnom temple on Phnom Penhs north side, occupies an entire city block and houses over 500 employees. As the first purpose-built U.S. Embassy in Cambodia, the new complex is a sign of growing U.S. engagement in the country.\n\n2007: On April 4, the Peace Corps swears in its first class of volunteers to serve in Cambodia. The 29 volunteers serve their two-year tours living with Cambodian families in rural villages throughout the country, teaching English at upper secondary schools and regional teacher training centers. Successive classes swell in size as the decade continues.\n\n2009: The Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, better known as the Khmer Rouge tribunal, begins its first case on February 16. The defendant is Kaing Guek Eav, better known by his revolutionary name Duch, who oversaw the torture and execution of some 12,000 people as warden of Tuol Sleng prison. After 30 years of waiting, Cambodian witnesses finally appear in a court of law to describe the horrors they endured under the Democratic Kampuchea regime. A verdict in Duchs case is expected in the summer of 2010. Meanwhile, the four remaining Khmer Rouge leaders in custody are likely to face trial in 2011. The United States has committed $6.8 million to support the trial.", 
        "id": "79770243223_417703883223", 
        "kh": "២០០៣សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនិងប្រទេសកម្ពុជាចុះហត្ថលេខាលើកិច្ចព្រមព្រៀងដើម្បីដាក់កំហិតលើការនាំចូលវត្ថុបូរាណខ្មែរទៅក្នុងទីផ្សាសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកដើម្បីការពារបេតិកភណ្ឌវប្បធម៌កម្ពុជាពីការលួចប្លន់។ចំណុចលេចធ្លោមួយនៃកិច្ចព្រមព្រៀងនេះគឺការបញ្ជូនត្រឡប់មកវិញកាលពីឆ្នាំ២០០៧នូវបដិមាកអប្សារាពីសម័យសតវត្សទី១៣ដែលត្រូវបានគេលួចយកទៅសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិក។ជំនួយរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកថែមទាំងបានជួយជួសជុលឡើងវិញនូវប្រាសាទសម័យអង្គរខ្លះដ៏មានតំលៃបំផុតរបស់ប្រទេសកម្ពុជាដូចជាគំរោងធំមួយក្នុងការអភិរក្សប្រាសាទភ្នំបាក់ខែង។២០០៦អតីតប្រធានាធិបតីអាមេរិកធ្វើទស្សនកិច្ចនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជានៅខែធ្នូ។ក្នុងពេលប្រជុំជាមួយលោកនាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រីហ៊ុនសែនលោកបានចុះហត្ថលេខាលើអនុស្សារណៈយោគយល់គ្នាមួយដែលក្នុងនោះមូលនិធិនឹងជួយក្នុងការប្រយុទ្ធប្រឆាំងនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍។ទន្ទឹមនឹងនោះជំនួយទ្វេភាគីរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកមានផលច្រើនលើស្ថានភាពជំងឺអេដស៍នៅក្នុងអំឡុងទសវត្សនោះដោយបានជួយកាត់បន្ថយអត្រាអ្នកផ្ទុកមេរោគអេដស៍ពី២មកនៅត្រឹមតិចជាង១ដែលជាការធ្វើអោយប្រទេសកម្ពុជាគឺជាករណីជោគជ័យដ៏កំរមួយក្នុងការប្រយុទ្ធប្រឆាំងនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍ជាសាកល។២០០៦សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកបានបើកស្ថានទូតថ្មីនៅខែមករា។ស្ថានទូតនេះដែលស្ថិតនៅជិតវត្តភ្នំដ៏មានឈ្មោះល្បីនៅភាគខាងជើងទីក្រុងភ្នំពេញមានផ្ទៃដីស្មើនឹងប្លុកទាំងមូលមួយក្នុងក្រុងហើយមានបុគ្គលិកធ្វើការជាង៥០០នាក់។ក្នុងនាមជាកន្លែងដែលត្រូវបានសង់ឡើងតាមការកំណត់សំរាប់ស្ថានទូតទីតាំងអាគារទាំងនេះគឺជាសញ្ញាមួយនៃទំនាក់ទំនងដែលមានកាន់តែច្រើនឡើងនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។២០០៧នៅថ្ងៃទី៤ខែមេសាអ្នកស្ម័គ្រចិត្តរបស់ទីភ្នាក់ងារក្នុងក្រុមដំបូងបានធ្វើសច្ចារប្រណិធានចូលបំពេញការងារនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។អ្នកស្ម័គ្រចិត្តទាំង២៩នាក់នោះមានអាណត្តិបំពេញការងាររយៈពេល២ឆ្នាំដោយរស់នៅជាមួយគ្រួសារខ្មែរតាមភូមិជនបទនៅទូទាំងប្រទេសបង្រៀនភាសាអង់គ្លេសនៅតាមវិទ្យាល័យកំរិតទុតិយភូមិនិងមជ្ឈមណ្ឌលគរុកោសល្យភូមិភាគ។ក្រុមបន្តបន្ទាប់មកទៀតមានចំនួនសមាជិកកាន់តែច្រើននៅក្នុងទសវត្សនេះ។២០០៩អង្គជំនុំជំរះវិសាមញ្ញក្នុងតុលាការកម្ពុជាដែលភាគច្រើនស្គាល់ថាជាតុលាការខ្មែរក្រហមបានចាប់ផ្តើមដំណើរការលើករណីទី១នៅថ្ងៃទី១៦ខែកុម្ភៈ។ចុងចោទគឺឈ្មោះកាំងហ្កិចអៀវដែលមានឈ្មោះបដិវត្តន៍ថាឌុច។គាត់គឺជាប្រធានគុកទួលស្លែងហើយបានដឹកនាំក្នុងការធ្វើទារុណកម្មនិងសំលាប់មនុស្សចំនួនប្រមាណ១២០០០នាក់។បន្ទាប់ពីរយៈពេលរង់ចាំចំនួន៣០ឆ្នាំសាក្សីជាជនជាតិខ្មែរនៅទីបំផុតបានបង្ហាញមុខនៅក្នុងតុលាការដើម្បីរៀបរាប់ពីការភ័យរន្ធត់ដែ         "eng": "This is the transcript of Dr. Frank Huffman's symposium presentation on July 22, 2010\n\nDr. Frank Huffman published nine books and numerous articles on Southeast Asian languages and linguistics. His Cambodian System of Writing, Beginner Reader, and Modern Spoken Cambodian were first published in 1970, and with later books including the first comprehensive English-Khmer Dictionary (1978). With his coauthor Im Proum, he began the complilation of this dictionary in 1970. In 2004 he donated his collection of Khmer books to the Buddhist Institute in Phnom Penh.\n\n Frank Huffman     \"Cambodian System of Writing\" \"Beginner Reader\"  \"Modern Spoken Cambodian\"   Im Proum -  \n\nRelated link: http://sealang.net/archives/huffman/",

        "eng": "WHAT ARE THE BENEFITS OF ATTENDING COMMUNITY COLLEGE?\n\nIn addition to academic programs leading to college degrees (e.g. associates degrees), community colleges offer vocational education and technical training. Community colleges also usually have strong ties with their state's universities. This makes it easier for the student to transfer to one of these universities to complete the last two years of a four year Bachelors Degree after completing an Associates Degree at the Community College. The cost of a Community College is significantly less than a four year university and although they are less expensive you can still receive an excellent education there. Many American and international students attend the first two years of study in a community college with lower costs and easier admission policies to take many of the required subjects connected to their degree and then transfer for their last two years to a four year university.\n\nTo get more answers, click the link below.",

This means users will have more information at their disposal directly from the top of the site. \r\n\r\n    * The easy-to-navigate site functions the same as the old site, so users dont have to learn a new navigation.\r\n    * The homepage slideshow highlights the top four stories. It displays embassy events in bigger images, so its easy to grab your attention.\r\n    * The tabbed area in the middle section of the page offers the ability to display multiple key embassy programs, social media sites and State Department reports without taking away from the daily content.\r\n    * On the upper part of the homepage, the 7 tabs remain the same, except Policy News which is replaced by News & Events. This tab holds Embassy events articles, press releases, speeches and State Department reports.\r\n    * For now, Khmer website of the embassy (http://khmer.cambodia.usembassy.gov/) is still in the old design.         "eng": "How many slaves work for you?\r\n\r\nTake the survey: http://slaveryfootprint.org/\r\n\r\nTwo months ago, the Fairtrade Fund launched Slavery Footprint, a web- and mobile-based application that allows users to understand how their lives intersect with modern slavery.\r\n\r\nThe app works by asking users to complete a quick survey about where they live and what they buy and eat.\r\n\r\nThat information is processed in an algorithm that analyzes the 400 most common consumer items and determines the likelihood that those items were tainted by modern slavery somewhere along the supply chain.\r\n\r\nMore: http://blogs.state.gov/index.php/site/entry/one_million_footprints_on_the_path_to_freedom",

Within each college or university you will find schools, such as school of arts and sciences or the school of business.\n\nQ: WHO CAN BECOME A COLLEGE OR UNIVERSITY STUDENT? ARE THERE AGE LIMITATIONS TO ATTEND U.S. COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES?\n\nA: A high school education is usually required to become an undergraduate university student.     "2012-09-13T03:04:57+0000": {
        "eng": " Obama  Chris Stevens   \n\n   \n\n\"... Every day, all across the world, American diplomats and civilians work tirelessly to advance the interests and values of our nation.\n\nOften, they are away from their families. Sometimes, they brave great danger.\n\nYesterday, four of these extraordinary Americans were killed in an attack on our diplomatic post in Benghazi.\n\nAmong those killed was our Ambassador, Chris Stevens, as well as Foreign Service Officer Sean Smith. We are still notifying the families of the others who were killed.\n\nAnd today, the American people stand united in holding the families of the four Americans in our thoughts and in our prayers ...\"\n\nClick the link below to read remarks by the President on the deaths of U.S. Embassy staff in Libya.\nhttp://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/09/12/remarks-president-deaths-us-embassy-staff-libya", 
        "id": "79770243223_10151125450868224", 
        "kh": "លោកប្រធានាធិបតីចុះហត្ថលេខាលើសៀវភៅរំលែកទុក្ខមរណភាពរបស់លោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតអាមេរិកប្រចាំនៅប្រទេសលីប៊ី។នៅលើជញ្ជាំងខាងក្រោយលោកជាឈ្មោះរបស់មន្ត្រីក្រសួងការបរទេសអាមេរិកដែលបានបាត់បង់ជីវិតក្នុងពេលបំរើការងារនៅបរទេស។"

    "2012-09-13T07:08:25+0000": {
        "eng": "Yesterday, our U.S. diplomatic post in Benghazi, Libya was attacked.\n\nHeavily armed militants assaulted the compound and set fire to our buildings.\n\nAmerican and Libyan security personnel battled the attackers together.\n\nFour Americans were killed. They included Sean Smith, a Foreign Service information management officer, and our Ambassador to Libya Chris Stevens.\n\nWe are still making next of kin notifications for the other two individuals.\n\nThis is an attack that should shock the conscience of people of all faiths around the world.\n\nWe condemn in the strongest terms this senseless act of violence, and we send our prayers to the families, friends, and colleagues of those weve lost.\n\nAll over the world, every day, Americas diplomats and development experts risk their lives in the service of our country and our values, because they believe that the United States must be a force for peace and progress in the world, that these aspirations are worth striving and sacrificing for. \n\nAlongside our men and women in uniform, they represent the best traditions of a bold and generous nation.\n\nIn the lobby of this building, the State Department, the names of those who have fallen in the line of duty are inscribed in marble.\n\nOur hearts break over each one. And now, because of this tragedy, we have new heroes to honor and more friends to mourn.\n\nChris Stevens fell in love with the Middle East as a young Peace Corps volunteer teaching English in Morocco. He joined the Foreign Service, learned languages, won friends for America in distant places, and made other peoples hopes his own.\n\nIn the early days of the Libyan revolution, I asked Chris to be our envoy to the rebel opposition. He arrived on a cargo ship in the port of Benghazi and began building our relationships with Libyas revolutionaries. He risked his life to stop a tyrant, then gave his life trying to help build a better Libya. The world needs more Chris Stevenses. I spoke with his sister, Ann, this morning, and told her that he will be remembered as a hero by many nations.\n\nSean Smith was an Air Force veteran. He spent 10 years as an information management officer in the State Department, he was posted at The Hague, and was in Libya on a brief temporary assignment. He was a husband to his wife Heather, with whom I spoke this morning. He was a father to two young children, Samantha and Nathan. They will grow up being proud of the service their father gave to our country, service that took him from Pretoria to Baghdad, and finally to Benghazi.\n\nThe mission that drew Chris and Sean and their colleagues to Libya is both noble and necessary, and we and the people of Libya honor their memory by carrying it forward. This is not easy. Today, many Americans are asking  indeed, I asked myself  how could this happen? How could this happen in a country we helped liberate, in a city we helped save from destruction? This question reflects just how complicated and, at times, how confounding the world can be.\n\nBut we must be clear-eyed, even in our grief. This was an attack by a small and savage group  not the people or Government of Libya. Everywhere Chris and his team went in Libya, in a country scarred by war and tyranny, they were hailed as friends and partners. And when the attack came yesterday, Libyans stood and fought to defend our post. Some were wounded. Libyans carried Chris body to the hospital, and they helped rescue and lead other Americans to safety. And last night, when I spoke with the President of Libya, he strongly condemned the violence and pledged every effort to protect our people and pursue those responsible.\n\nThe friendship between our countries, borne out of shared struggle, will not be another casualty of this attack. A free and stable Libya is still in Americas interest and security, and we will not turn our back on that, nor will we rest until those responsible for these attacks are found and brought to justice. We are working closely with the Libyan authorities to move swiftly and surely. We are also working with partners around the world to safeguard other American embassies, consulates, and citizens.\n\nThere will be more time later to reflect, but today, we have work to do. There is no higher priority than protecting our men and women wherever they serve. We are working to determine the precise motivations and methods of those who carried out this assault. Some have sought to justify this vicious behavior, along with the protest that took place at our Embassy in Cairo yesterday, as a response to inflammatory material posted on the internet. Americas commitment to religious tolerance goes back to the very beginning of our nation. But let me be clear  there is no justification for this, none. Violence like this is no way to honor religion or faith. And as long as there are those who would take innocent life in the name of God, the world will never know a true and lasting peace.\n\nIt is especially difficult that this happened on September 11th. Its an anniversary that means a great deal to all Americans. Every year on that day, we are reminded that our work is not yet finished, that the job of putting an end to violent extremism and building a safe and stable world continues. But September 11th means even more than that. It is a day on which we remember thousands of American heroes, the bonds that connect all Americans, wherever we are on this Earth, and the values that see us through every storm. And now it is a day on which we will remember Sean, Chris, and their colleagues.\n\nMay God bless them, and may God bless the thousands of Americans working in every corner of the world who make this country the greatest force for peace, prosperity, and progress, and a force that has always stood for human dignity  the greatest force the world has ever known. And may God continue to bless the United States of America.\n\nThank you.\n\nhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Di9E4da5G4k&feature=share&list=UU6ZhpmNnLxlOYipqh8wbM3A", 
        "id": "79770243223_153939821411459", 
        "kh": "’’’’–––’’’–’–"
    },

    "2012-10-02T06:15:45+0000": {
        "eng": "Press Statement on Conviction of Mam Sonando:\n\nWe are deeply concerned by the conviction and harsh sentence of Mam Sonando, a Cambodian independent broadcaster.\n\nToday the Phnom Penh Municipal Court sentenced him to 20 years in prison for alleged insurrection.\n\nA number of observers in Cambodia have noted that the charges against him appear to have been politically-motivated, based on his frequent criticism of the government.\n\nWe strongly support freedom of expression, including the rights of members of the press to peacefully express political views without fear of persecution, retribution, or intimidation, consistent with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. We call on the Cambodian government to release Mam Sonando immediately, to ensure that its court system is free from political influence, and to reaffirm its commitment to guaranteeing its citizens basic human rights.\n\nhttp://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2012/10/198518.htm#.UGqD-s_xTSA.facebook",

    "2012-10-05T04:22:07+0000": {
        "eng": "U.S. Citizens in Cambodia cast their votes at the U.S. Embassy.\n\nMore photos: https://picasaweb.google.com/106739195343586325665/EarlyVotingAtTheEmbassy\n\nA significant change in balloting in recent years has been the adoption of procedures that make ballots available to voters before the election.\n\nThis trend started with provisions for absentee ballots, issued to voters who anticipate being away from their home (and their voting place) on Election Day.\n\nAnother new provision is early voting, for which voting machines are set up in shopping malls and other public places for up to three weeks before Election Day.\n\nEven though early ballots are becoming more popular, they are not counted until tabulation begins after the polls close, so that no official information can be released about which candidate is ahead or behind.\n\nRead more: http://iipdigital.usembassy.gov/st/english/article/2012/10/20121002136975.html#axzz286eoMyMI",

    "2012-11-06T12:24:10+0000": {
        "eng": "Learn about U.S. Election:\n\nDid you know? American people, technically, do not vote directly for the president and vice president.\n\nWhen they cast their vote, they are actually voting for a group of people known as electors.\n\nThis indirect election system, called the Electoral College, reflects the federal governing system of allocating powers to a national government representing not only the people but also the states.\n\nThe Electoral College is composed of 538 electors.\n\nEach elector casts one electoral vote following the general election. The candidate that gets more than half (270) wins the election.\n\nLearn more about Electoral College: http://go.usa.gov/YHzG\n\nPicture credit: www.c-spanclassroom.org",

A minimum of five (5) years in progressively more responsible project/ program management and advisor positions, with experience in the guidance, development,  implementation, and evaluation of projects/programs in animal health and surveillance for avian influenza and veterinary diseases, including laboratory testing, required.\n\n. The name of the exercise is Angkor Sentinel 2013.\n\nDuring the exercise the two nations will be conducting training related to the following topics: Humanitarian Assistance, Disaster Relief, infantry, medical, engineering and battle staff capacity just to name a few.     "2013-04-19T07:14:53+0000": {
        "eng": "SIGN UP FOR THIS NEW ONLINE U.S. UNIVERSITY COURSE ON DEMOCRATIC DEVELOPMENT:\n\nThe U.S. Embassy invites you to take advantage of an opportunity to participate in an online U.S. university course on Democratic Development.\n\nThis course was launched in April of 2013 by Stanford University and is being taught by Larry Diamond, a leading scholar of democratization.\n\nThe course will provide world-class instruction in how democratic institutions and governance are established, maintained, and\nstrengthened.\n\nTHE COURSE HAS ALREADY BEGUN, BUT IT IS NOT TOO LATE TO ENROLL.\n\nRegistration and additional information are available online at https://www.coursera.org/course/democraticdev.\n\nThe course also provides a chance for individuals who share a commitment to democratic values to connect with each other around the world.\n\nThis course is primarily intended for individuals in college or beyond, with some academic background or preparation in political science or the social sciences and a proficiency in English.  \n\nHowever, it seeks to be accessible to a diverse international audience, including educators at the secondary and college levels, government officials, development professionals, civil society leaders, journalists, bloggers, activists, and individuals involved in a wide range of activities and professions related to the development and deepening of democracy.\n\nThe time commitment for the course is approximately 1 to 2 hours per week for a total of 10 weeks.\n\nFor those who sign up and take the course, we will be hosting some discussion sessions here at the Embassy and we will hold a graduation ceremony for those who complete the course.\n\nIf you would like to receive information about these events, please let us know if you sign up for the course by sending an email to IRCPhnomPenh@state.gov.",

        "eng": "The U.S. Embassy is pleased to announce the recruitment of candidates for E-Teacher Scholarship Program.\n\nMore information: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/eteacher.html\n\nELIGIBILITY:\n* Have the ability to complete academic work at a U.S. university level (an advanced level of reading and writing in English, roughly equivalent to a minimum TOEFL score of 525/iBT 70)\n\n* Have an understanding of English technical terms relating to computers and the Internet\n\n* Have regular access (4-5 times/week) to a reliable, up-to-date computer with high-speed internet connectivity\n\n* Have basic technology skills related to email, internet searches and downloads/uploads, logins/passwords, and e-file use (e.g., pdf, MS Word, Excel). Practical Applications in Listening and Speaking Skills participants require access to real-time tools such as Skype\n\n* Have the ability to type in English well enough to perform online tasks in real-time and submit written assignments in a timely manner\n\n* Have at least 8-10 hours per week to devote to the coursework\n\n* Be a Cambodian and reside in Cambodia at the time of the course\n\n* Not hold dual citizenship in the United States",

        "eng": "U.S. Embassy Statement on the Inaugural Session of the Fifth Legislature of the National Assembly:\n\nAmbassador William E. Todd attended the Inaugural Session of the Fifth Legislature of the National Assembly today under the patronage of His Majesty King Norodom Sihamoni.  His attendance is not an endorsement of any election outcome or of any political party.\n\nThe United States urges a transparent review of irregularities in the July 28 national elections which would help efforts to assess and address flaws in the electoral process and give the Cambodian people greater confidence in the electoral system.\n\nWe believe that a functioning National Assembly requires the participation of both major political parties.  We call on the two parties to follow through on their September 16 joint statement denouncing violence, supporting discussion of electoral reforms, and agreeing to resolve national problems through dialogue. \n\nAll parties should seize this opportunity to improve democratic processes and implement meaningful reforms which strengthen the rule of law and increase respect for human rights.         "eng": "\"As I learn more about the Khmer language, I am amazed by the number of proverbs that relate to agriculture.     "2014-01-04T07:59:37+0000": {
        "eng": "New Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Potential for Violence and Severe Travel Restrictions in and Around Phnom Penh:\n\nToday, the Royal Government of Cambodia announced a prohibition on all public demonstrations in and around Phnom Penh.  Separately, the main political opposition party has stated it intends to conduct a mass rally and march through Phnom Penh on Sunday, January 5, 2014.  There is a potential for violence should security forces attempt to disperse demonstrations in the capital over the next several days.  Based on the governments handling of past protests, the U.S. Embassy anticipates that major roads into Phnom Penh will be blocked and significant restrictions on vehicular movements will be imposed within the city, resulting in severe traffic disruptions coming into and throughout Phnom Penh.  The Embassy recommends that U.S citizens within Phnom Penh limit any unnecessary travel away from their residences and avoid large crowds and immediately leave any area where crowds are gathering.  U.S. citizens outside of Phnom Penh should expect significant delays traveling into the city.  The Embassy also notes that violence, including fatalities, has occurred at roadblocks in the recent past.  You should remain alert to local security developments by monitoring local news reports, be vigilant regarding your personal security and preparedness, be aware of your surroundings, and plan your activities accordingly.  Please continue to monitor our website for updates regarding the Embassys operating status.\n\nhttp://cambodia.usembassy.gov/acs_violent_demonstrations_in_phnom_penh.html",

    "2014-01-09T10:04:55+0000": {
        "eng": "\"The U.S. Embassy has long worked with Cambodia to help protect the Kingdoms unique historical and cultural heritage, and last week we had another milestone in the history of this important partnership  the launch of an online catalog by the National Museum of Cambodia. \r\n\r\nThis inventory project, which began all the way back in 2004, documents the museums entire collection of over 16,400 works of art.         "eng": "Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Demonstrations Planned for Sunday, January 26 and Monday, January 27 2014\r\n\r\nThis security message is being issued to alert U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to Cambodia that the leaders of various unions have announced plans for a demonstration of over 10,000 people to be held in Phnom Penhs Freedom Park (Streets 106/108 between 51 and 63) on Sunday, January 26. Additionally, a demonstration of approximately 200 people is planned for ...Monday, January 27 to be held in front of the Ministry of Information (#62 Preah Monivong Blvd). These would be the first large-scale demonstrations since the Phnom Penh Municipality announced a prohibition on demonstrations in early January, and Cambodian government officials have publicly stated that these events will not be allowed to proceed. There is a potential for violence should government security forces clash with protestors.     "2014-02-03T05:03:41+0000": {
        "eng": "Ambassador Todd:  \"I meet daily with government officials, politicians, business leaders, and civil society leaders, but I also enjoy discussions with my tuk-tuk driver, the lady who runs the kuy teav noodle stand around the corner from my house, and the young students who are part of my Youth Council.  From these conversations, it is clear to me that change to most Cambodians isnt some intangible concept; what they want is for the government to address the specific problems that affect their daily lives and to expand opportunities for all the countrys citizens, not just an elite few.     "2014-02-19T03:52:50+0000": {
        "eng": "What is a watershed? It is an area created by a water system that hosts a wide variety of living things.  Well-managed watersheds protect biodiversity, maintain forests and water sources, and preserve fish stocks.  They also benefit people who generate their livelihoods from forests, agriculture, and fisheries.  \n\nAs Cambodia develops, watersheds have come under threat, particularly from over-logging, economic concessions, and slash and burn agriculture.  Find out how USAID is helping Cambodia protect watersheds:  http://bit.ly/1bO8MoA (English), http://bit.ly/1j7jgnv (Khmer)\n\n(Photo credit: Fintrac)", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152046089398224", 
        "kh": ""
    },

        "eng": "Ambassador Todd: \"Human trafficking is not merely a challenge for law enforcement, but an economic and social challenge as well.  While Cambodian police and courts must prosecute and punish traffickers for their crimes, equitable economic growth and development that creates decent jobs will also have a tremendous impact on preventing human trafficking.     "2014-03-07T10:46:53+0000": {
        "eng": "Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Potential for Civil Unrest on Saturday, March 8, 2014\n\nThis security message is being issued to alert U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to Cambodia that the leaders of various unions have announced plans for a public forum of up to 30,000 people to be held in Phnom Penhs Freedom Park (Streets 106/108 between 51 and 63) on Saturday, March 8, 2014, beginning at 8:00 a.m. Cambodian authorities have publicly stated that the unions have been denied a permit for the event, but organizers have indicated they intend to proceed with the gathering. Additionally, local press have quoted union leaders as saying they anticipate clashes with government security forces...\n\nThe Embassy encourages U.S. citizens to avoid crowds and other gatherings and to immediately leave any area where crowds are gathering. U.S. citizens should remain alert to local security developments by monitoring local news reports, be vigilant regarding their personal security and preparedness, be aware of their surroundings, and plan their activities accordingly...\n\nPlease read full text of message here:\nhttp://cambodia.usembassy.gov/030714_acs.html",

        "eng": "Ambassador Todd:  \"Each year thousands of U.S. citizens adopt children from abroad, and many families in other countries adopt U.S. children.  We have seen the great benefit that intercountry adoption can bring to children in need.  The loving bonds that make a family strong transcend race, nationality, culture, and religion.  This conviction forms the foundation of our cooperation with Cambodia on adoption issues and our shared commitment to a transparent and ethical process for intercountry adoption.     "2014-05-10T14:22:07+0000": {
        "eng": "Hello everyone, Im Michelle Obama, and on this Mothers Day weekend, I want to take a moment to honor all the mothers out there and wish you a Happy Mothers Day. \n\nI also want to speak to you about an issue of great significance to me as a First Lady, and more importantly, as the mother of two young daughters.\n\nLike millions of people across the globe, my husband and I are outraged and heartbroken over the kidnapping of more than 200 Nigerian girls from their school dormitory in the middle of the night. \n\nThis unconscionable act was committed by a terrorist group determined to keep these girls from getting an education  grown men attempting to snuff out the aspirations of young girls. \n\nAnd I want you to know that Barack has directed our government to do everything possible to support the Nigerian governments efforts to find these girls and bring them home. \n\nIn these girls, Barack and I see our own daughters.\n\nWe see their hopes, their dreams  and we can only imagine the anguish their parents are feeling right now.\n\nMany of them may have been hesitant to send their daughters off to school, fearing that harm might come their way. \n\nBut they took that risk because they believed in their daughters promise and wanted to give them every opportunity to succeed. \n\nThe girls themselves also knew full well the dangers they might encounter. \n\nTheir school had recently been closed due to terrorist threats but these girls still insisted on returning to take their exams. \n\nThey were so determined to move to the next level of their educationso determined to one day build careers of their own and make their families and communities proud.   \n\nAnd what happened in Nigeria was not an isolated incident. It is a story we see every day as girls around the world risk their lives to pursue their ambitions. \n\nIts the story of girls like Malala Yousafzai from Pakistan.\n\nMalala spoke out for girls education in her community, and as a result, she was shot in the head by a Taliban gunman while on a school bus with her classmates. \n\nBut fortunately Malala survivedand when I met her last year, I could feel her passion and determination as she told me that girls education is still her lifes mission. \n\nAs Malala said in her address to the United Nations, she said The terrorists thought that they would change our aims and stop our ambitions but nothing changed in my life except this: Weakness, fear and hopelessness died. Strength, power and courage was born.\n\nThe courage and hope embodied by Malala and girls like her around the world should serve as a call to action. \n\nBecause right now, more than 65 million girls worldwide are not in school. \n\nYet, we know that girls who are educated make higher wages, lead healthier lives, and have healthier families. \n\nAnd when more girls attend secondary school, that boosts their countrys entire economy. \n\nSo education is truly a girls best chance for a bright future, not just for herself, but for her family and her nation. \n\nAnd thats true right here in the U.S. as wellso I hope the story of these Nigerian girls will serve as an inspiration for every girl  and boy  in this country. \n\nI hope that any young people in America who take school for granted  any young people who are slacking off or thinking of dropping out  I hope they will learn the story of these girls and recommit themselves to their education.\n\nThese girls embody the best hope for the future of our worldand we are committed to standing up for them not just in times of tragedy or crisis, but for the long haul.\n\nWe are committed to giving them the opportunities they deserve to fulfill every last bit of their God-given potential. \n\nSo today, let us all pray for their safe return... let us hold their families in our hearts during this very difficult timeand let us show just a fraction of their courage in fighting to give every girl on this planet the education that is her birthright.  Thank you.\n\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PAncJ3nuczI",

        "eng": "Have you heard of the sport ultimate frisbee?  Heres a story of how this sport encouraged regular exercise and inspired self-confidence in youth, especially women, in one Cambodian community.\n\nVicki Chan is a Peace Corps Cambodia Volunteer serving in Kampong Cham province.  She noticed that women in her community rarely participate in sports, so she decided to introduce them to her athletic passion  ultimate frisbee.  The Ultimate Frisbee Club that Vicki started now includes more than ten young Cambodian women who play and practice every day in an grassy area in front of the Kampong Cham Provincial Hall.  \n\nBefore they joined the club, none of the young women had ever played any sports before.  Their training and dedication earned them an invitation to join an all-Cambodian team to compete in the Mekong Cup, an international ultimate frisbee tournament held in Phnom Penh this month.         "eng": "On July 6, students of the Access program from Battambang, Kampong Chhnang, Kratie, Phnom Penh, and Ratanakiri came to the Embassy for the 8th annual full-day English Camp. They played games, conducted video interviews, and performed skits, all in English. Our three English Language Fellows and Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) volunteers were invaluable and inspired the participants with their leadership and support.\n\nFunded by the U.S. government, the English Access Microscholarship Program (Access) provides a foundation of English language skills to talented 13-20 year-olds from disadvantaged communities through after-school classes and intensive sessions, empowering them to contribute to the development of their country while boosting their ability to participate in U.S. exchange and study programs.     "2014-07-22T08:30:00+0000": {
        "eng": "Important Notice about the Diversity Visa Lottery (DV) program:\n\n\tDishonest agencies in Phnom Penh have been extorting money from winners of the DV program.  These agencies have assisted Cambodians to apply for the DV program and later charged the winners outrageous fees.  THERE IS NO FEE TO ENTER THE LOTTERY!\n\n\tThere has also been a notable increase in fraudulent emails and letters sent to DV program applicants.  The scammers behind these fraudulent emails and letters are posing as the U.S. government in an attempt to extract payment from DV applicants.  Applicants are encouraged to read our FRAUD ALERT regarding the DV program here: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/diversity_visa.html.\n\n\tNo organization can send you a notification of your selection in the DV program.  Any individual or organization that promises to secure a visa to the United States for you is ENGAGING IN A FRAUDULENT PRACTICE.  Only U.S. consular officials have authorization to approve or deny your visa application.\n\n\tDV-2015 is closed since November 2, 2013.  DV-2015 applicants can use their confirmation number to check their entrant status at http://www.dvlottery.state.gov/ESC/.  \n\n\tThe opening date of DV-2016 has not yet been announced.  That date will be announced on our website and Facebook page once DV-2016 is open for applications.\n\n\tFor more information, please contact our Consular Office at IVPhnomPenh@state.gov.",

        "eng": "PRESS RELEASE\n\nThe U.S. Embassy in Cambodia welcomes todays historic guilty verdict by the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia (ECCC) against Nuon Chea, the deputy to Pol Pot, and Khieu Samphan, a former head of state, for crimes against humanity committed during the Khmer Rouge regime.  We express our gratitude to the judges and other representatives of the tribunal for their hard work and commitment to justice.\n\nThe U.S. Government has long supported the goal of prosecuting those most responsible for the atrocities perpetrated by the Khmer Rouge regime, which claimed as many as 2.2 million victims and brought unimaginable hardship and misery to the people of Cambodia.         "eng": "A new study from NASA and California Institute of Technology finds that the impact of aerosols on clouds is almost double that estimated by the UNs Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.  Of all the factors that influence Earths climate, the effect that tiny particles in Earths atmosphere called aerosols have on clouds is the least well understood. Aerosols scatter and absorb incoming sunlight and affect the formation and properties of clouds.     "2014-08-22T11:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "Opportunity, Equality, and Access for Women\nBy Ambassador William Todd\n\nThis past weekend, I was privileged to speak to a remarkable group of young women at the opening ceremony of a two-week leadership institute sponsored by the Women in Public Service Project, the Harpswell Foundation, and Pannasastra University.  A total of 63 young women are participating in the institute, where they will hear from experts and participate in workshops on critical thinking, leadership, ethics, and public service.  These young women represent a new generation of Cambodian women who are ready to make a positive impact on society and to take on leadership roles in their communities.\n\nIn my remarks, I shared my thoughts about the importance of having more women in leadership positions in Cambodia and the three things that women and girls need to achieve their full potential:  Opportunity, Equality, and Access.  Without opportunity, equality, and access, women and girls will always be at a disadvantage compared to their male counterparts.  Why? These three pillars are what I see as the necessary tools to build a capable and confident generation of women leaders in business, science, education, and policymaking, in effect a more productive and responsible society.  The leadership institute is one small but important step towards achieving these objectives, and I am encouraged by the possibilities and creativity the institute fosters.\n\nThis gives me an opportunity to describe the vision behind the Women in Public Service Project, which was launched in 2011 by the U.S. Secretary of State at the time, Hillary Clinton, and the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars.  With support from the U.S. Department of State, the Women in Public Service Project develops partnerships around the world to advance the pillars I mentioned above, opportunity, equality, and access\n\nThe Harpswell Foundation and Pannasastra University of Cambodia (PUC) are the hosts of this months leadership institute in Cambodia.  The Harpswell Foundation was founded by U.S. academic and humanitarian Alan Lightman and operates two facilities in Phnom Penh that provide housing and support for outstanding Cambodian women while they attend university.  PUC is one of Cambodias premier private universities and a frequent U.S. Embassy partner.  The south campus in Phnom Penh also hosts an Embassy-sponsored American Corner and an Educational Advising Center, which provides free counseling about opportunities to study in the United States. \n\nJoining me at the launch was the director of the Women in Public Service Project, Dr. Rangita de Silva de Alwis.  Dr. de Silva de Alwis made an impassioned appeal to Cambodias young women, encouraging them to promote themselves and to fight for greater opportunity.\n\nAnother speaker at the inauguration was H.E. Dr. Ing Kantha Phavi, Cambodias Minister of Womens Affairs.  I want to personally thank Minister Phavi for sharing her valuable perspective on the steps that the Cambodian government is taking to encourage women to take on positions of leadership in government and society.  Dr. Phavi herself is an excellent example of the positive impact that women can have in government and public policy in Cambodia.\n\nIn recent blog entries, I discussed the importance of creating opportunities for women to succeed in government, business, and other fields and described some of the many ways that the U.S. Embassy supports womens development and equality in Cambodia.  It is truly gratifying to be able to lend my support to partners like the Women in Public Service Project, the Harpswell Foundation, and Pannasastra University who share our interest in helping Cambodian women to become leaders.  I wish the participants in the leadership institute the best of luck and look forward to following their progress in the future.\n\nPlease look for the full blog post on the Embassy website (http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/) on Monday.\n\n#AmbTodd", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152403618928224", 
        "kh": "’’’’’’"
    }, 
    "2014-08-25T02:52:33+0000": {
        "eng": "Ambassador Todd addresses the issue of child malnutrition and hunger in Cambodia in his weekly column titled: Helping Cambodian Children to Grow Up Healthy and Strong. \n\nLack of food is not the only cause of malnutrition and hunger.  Two other major factors are infectious disease and sanitation, which affect the bodys ability to ingest and utilize food.  A brand-new USAID program called Nourish is going to be launched in the next couple of weeks and will support Cambodias efforts to improve the nutrition of women and children through improved sanitation and hygiene.  Improving the nutritional status of women and raising awareness about nutrition and sanitation among mothers will go a long way towards creating a better future for Cambodias children. \n\nI am proud of the work that the U.S. Embassy is doing in conjunction with the Cambodian government, the NGO community, and other international partners to improve food security and nutrition in Cambodia.  This is clearly an issue where Cambodians of all political parties should work together for the benefit of Cambodias most vulnerable groups.  The United States will continue to look for ways to bring groups together to advance our common goal of ending malnutrition and hunger in Cambodia and to help the next generation of Cambodians to achieve their full potential. \n\nRead the Ambassadors full column in The Cambodia Herald at http://goo.gl/7sOQ8M\n\n#AmbTodd",

    "2014-08-27T10:21:43+0000": {
        "eng": "Working Towards an AIDS-Free Generation in Cambodia\nby Ambassador William Todd \n\nGeorge W. Bush signed into law the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, known as PEPFAR. PEPFAR is the largest commitment by any nation to combat a disease internationally, with more than $52 billion committed to fight HIV/AIDS (and malaria and tuberculosis) as of the end of 2013. This commitment to fight AIDS worldwide has been continued by President Obama. Through PEPFAR and other initiatives, the United States has rallied the world in the fight against HIV and AIDS.\n\nBut the United States is far from the only nation that is taking on HIV/AIDS. In fact, one of the world leaders in the fight against HIV/AIDS is Cambodia. This is not just my own observation but the opinion of global experts. In 2010, the United Nations recognized Cambodia with a Millennium Development Goal Award for outstanding national leadership, commitment and progress for reducing HIV prevalence by more than 50% and for achieving universal access to HIV/AIDS treatment. In 2013, an expert panel reviewed Cambodias strategy for HIV and concluded that the country is on track to eliminate all new HIV infections by 2020. That would make Cambodia the first country in the world to achieve an AIDS-free generation!\n\nThe U.S. Government is proud to partner with Cambodia in its efforts to eliminate HIV/AIDS. The U.S. Embassy has had its own PEPFAR office since 2006, drawing on the resources of two outstanding agencies: the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). In fact, some of our CDC staff are co-located with the Ministry of Health, working side by side on many health initiatives.\n\nPEPFARs efforts to combat HIV/AIDS in Cambodia take many forms. One priority is to help to prevent new infections, with a particular focus on reducing the transmission between mothers and babies and among populations that are at highest risk of infection. PEPFAR programs have helped to care for individuals who are HIV-positive and for the orphans left behind by those who have died as a result of AIDS. PEPFAR also helps to ensure that HIV-positive Cambodians receive high-quality treatment and works to strengthen the Cambodian health system to ensure that it has the capacity and know-how to address the needs of HIV/AIDS patients.\n\nDuring the last year, PEPFAR helped Cambodia provide treatment to almost 50,000 individuals and directly provided HIV testing to over 80,000 pregnant women. PEPFARs integrated approach to reducing AIDS in Cambodia is a model that should be duplicated in as many places as possible.\n\nPeople often ask me if it is really possible that Cambodia could become the first country to have an AIDS-free generation, even before the United States. And my answer is yes  as long as Cambodia maintains its commitment.\n\nDespite limited resources, Cambodia has worked strategically to address the problem of HIV/AIDS ever since the first cases were detected in the early 1990s. Cambodia is one of only 12 countries worldwide that has been able to ensure universal access to HIV treatment (according to the World Health Organization Global Update on Treatment, 2013). In addition, the Cambodian government has developed excellent cooperation with international, NGO, and civil society partners on the issue of HIV/AIDS. I congratulate the Ministry of Health and the National Center for HIV/AIDS, Dermatology, and Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs) for their leadership on this issue.\n\nAlthough progress is being made, the fight to defeat HIV/AIDS in Cambodia is far from over. An estimated 75,000 adults and children are living with HIV in Cambodia, and there are approximately 1,100 new infections every year. Many people are still highly susceptible to HIV infection, including women and men who work in the sex industry and drug abusers. In addition, there is still discrimination against those who are living with HIV/AIDS, and even the threat of discrimination may prevent some people from getting the treatment that they need.\n\nHIV/AIDS is not a problem that can be solved by governments alone  it is the responsibility of each and every one of us. On an individual level, we need to make smart choices and to protect ourselves and our loved ones. At the community level, we need to embrace those who are struggling with HIV/AIDS and ensure that they have access to the care and treatment that they need. And at the national and international level we need to continue to work together through programs like PEPFAR to bring resources where they are needed most.\n\nWhat role will you play in helping Cambodia to have the worlds first AIDS-free generation?\n\nRead this and all of the Ambassador's other blogs at http://goo.gl/GiDqK8 \n\n#AmbTodd", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152416935058224", 
        "kh": "’“”’’’––’"
    },

        "kh": "ធ្វើការដើម្បីអោយមនុស្សជំនាន់ក្រោយនៅកម្ពុជាគ្មានជំងឺអេដស៍៖នៅឆ្នាំ២០០៣លោកប្រធានាធិបតីបានចុះហត្ថលេខាអោយទៅជាច្បាប់នូវគំរោងកម្មវិធីផែនការបន្ទាន់សំរាប់បន្ធូរបន្ថយផ្នែកជំងឺអេដស៍ដែលមានឈ្មោះជាអក្សរកាត់ថា។គឺជាការប្តេជ្ញាចិត្តធំបំផុតរបស់ប្រទេសមួយក្នុងការប្រយុទ្ធប្រឆាំងនឹងជំងឺមួយជាអន្តរជាតិដោយមានថវិកាចំនួនជាង៥២ពាន់លានដុល្លាអាមេរិកត្រូវបានកំណត់សំរាប់ប្រយុទ្ធនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍និងជំងឺគុ្រនចាញ់និងជំងឺរបេងដោយគិតមកត្រឹមដំណាច់ឆ្នាំ២០១៣។លោកប្រធានាធិបតីបានបន្តការប្តេជ្ញាចិត្តនេះដើម្បីប្រយុទ្ធនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍នៅទូទាំងសាកលលោក។តែមិនមែនសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកតែឯងទេដែលជាប្រទេសដែលកំពុងប្រយុទ្ធប្រឆាំងនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍នោះ។តាមពិតទៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជាជាប្រទេសមួយក្នុងចំណោមប្រទេសនាំមុខគេក្នុងការប្រយុទ្ធនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍នៅក្នុងពិភពលោកគឺ។នេះមិនមែនគ្រាន់តែជាការសង្កេតឃើញរបស់ខ្ញុំតែប៉ុណ្ណោះទេតែវាជាមតិរបស់អ្នកជំនាញពិភពលោកផងដែរ។នៅឆ្នាំ២០១០អង្គការសហប្រជាជាតិបានផ្តល់អោយកម្ពុជានូវរង្វាន់ចំពោះការសំរេចគោលដៅអភិវឌ្ឍន៍សហសវត្សចំពោះ“ភាពជាអ្នកដឹកនាំកំរិតជាតិការប្តេជ្ញាចិត្តនិងភាពជឿនលឿនដ៏លេចធ្លោ”ដោយសារកម្ពុជាបានកាត់បន្ថយអត្រាប្រេវ៉ាឡង់បានលើសពី៥០ហើយធ្វើអោយមានលទ្ធភាពសំរាប់មនុស្សទូទៅក្នុងការទទួលបានការព្យាបាលលើជំងឺអេដស៍។នៅឆ្នាំ២០១៣ក្រុមអ្នកឯកទេសមួយក្រុមបានមកពិនិត្យយុទ្ធសាស្រ្តរបស់កម្ពុជាលើមេរោគអេដស៍ហើយបានសន្និដ្ឋានថាប្រទេសកម្ពុជាកំពុងតែស្ថិតនៅក្នុងដំណើរទៅរកការលុបបំបាត់ការឆ្លងថ្មីទាំងអស់នៃមេរោគអេដស៍នៅត្រឹមឆ្នាំ២០២០។ការនេះនឹងធ្វើអោយកម្ពុជាក្លាយជាប្រទេសទី១ក្នុងពិភពលោកដែលមានមនុស្សមួយជំនាន់គ្មានជំងឺអេដស៍រដ្ឋាភិបាលសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកមានមោទនភាពនឹងធ្វើជាដៃគូជាមួយប្រទេសកម្ពុជានៅក្នុងការខិតខំដើម្បីលុបបំបាត់ជំងឺអេដស៍។ស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកមានការិយាល័យរបស់ខ្លួនដែរគឺមានតាំងពីឆ្នាំ២០០៦មកដោយពឹងផ្អែកលើធនធានរបស់ទីភ្នាក់ងារចំនួនពីរគឺទីភ្នាក់ងារសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកសំរាប់ការអភិវឌ្ឍន៍អន្តរជាតិនិងមជ្ឈមណ្ឌលការពារនិងកំចាត់ជំងឺរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិក។តាមពិតទៅបុគ្គលិកខ្លះរបស់យើងក្នុងមានទីតាំងការិយាល័យធ្វើការជាមួយក្រសួងសុខាភិបាលដោយធ្វើការទន្ទឹមគ្នាលើសកម្មភាពផ្តួចផ្តើមជាច្រើនផ្នែកសុខភាព។ការខិតខំរបស់ក្នុងការប្រយុទ្ធប្រឆាំងនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍នៅកម្ពុជាមានទំរង់ជាច្រើន។អាទិភាពមួយគឺជួយការពារកុំអោយមានករណីឆ្លងថ្មីដោយផ្តោតសំខាន់លើការកាត់បន្ថយការឆ្លងរវាងមាតានិងទារកនិងក្នុងចំណោមប្រជាជនដែលមានការប្រឈមខ្លាំង។កម្មវិធីបានជួយយកចិត្តទុកដាក់ចំពោះអ្នកដែលមានមេរោគអេដស៍និងចំពោះក្មេងកំព្រាដែលឪពុកម្តាយបងប្អូនស្លាប់ចោលដោយសារជំងឺអេដស៍។ថែមទាំងជួយធ្វើអោយប្រជាជនកម្ពុជាដែលផ្ទុកមេរោគអេដស៍ទទួលបានការព្យាបាលប្រកបដោយគុណភាពហើយធ្វើការដើម្បីពង្រឹងប្រព័ន្ធសុខាភិបាលកម្ពុជាដើម្បីធ្វើអោយកម្ពុជាមានសមត្ថភាពនិងចំណេះក្នុងការដោះស្រាយតំរូវការនៃអ្នកជំងឺអេដស៍។ក្នុងឆ្នាំកន្លងទៅនេះបានជួយប្រទេសកម្ពុជាក្នុងការផ្តល់ការព្យាបាលដល់មនុស្សចំនួន៥០០០០នាក់ហើយបានធ្វើតេស្តរកមេរោគអេដស៍ដោយផ្ទាល់ដល់ស្រ្តីមានផ្ទៃពោះចំនួនជាង៨០០០០នាក់។យុទ្ធសាស្រ្តចំរុះរបស់ក្នុងការកាត់បន្ថយជំងឺអេដស៍នៅកម្ពុជាគឺជាគំរូមួយសំរាប់អោយគេយកទៅធ្វើតាមនៅតាមកន្លែងនានាជាច្រើន។គេច្រើនសួរខ្ញុំថាតើកម្ពុជាអាចក្លាយជាប្រទេសទីមួយដែលក្នុងនោះមនុស្សមួយជំនាន់គ្មានជំងឺអេដស៍ដោយក្លាយមុនសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកទៅទៀតបានដែរឬទេចំលើយរបស់ខ្ញុំគឺអាចក្លាយបានដរាបណាប្រទេសកម្ពុជារក្សាការប្តេជ្ញាចិត្តរបស់ខ្លួន។ទោះបីជាមានធនធាននៅមានកំរិតក្តីតែប្រទេសកម្ពុជាបានធ្វើការទៅតាមយុទ្ធសាស្រ្តដើម្បីដោះស្រាយបញ្ហានៃជំងឺអេដស៍តាំងពីករណីដំបូងត្រូវបានរកឃើញនៅដើមទសវត្សឆ្នាំ១៩៩០មក។កម្ពុជាស្ថិតក្នុងចំណោមប្រទេសចំនួនតែ១២ប៉ុណ្ណោះនៅក្នុងពិភពលោកដែលអាចធានាបាននូវលទ្ធភាពក្នុងការផ្តល់ការព្យាបាលជាទូទៅដល់អ្នកផ្ទុកមេរោគអេដស៍នេះបើយោងតាមរបាយការណ៍រួមចុងក្រោយរបស់អង្គការសុខភាពពិភពលោកស្តីពីការព្យាបាលឆ្នាំ២០១៣។លើសពីនេះទៀតរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាលកម្ពុជាមានកិច្ចសហប្រតិបត្តិការយ៉ាងល្អជាមួយអន្តរជាតិអង្គការមិនមែនរដ្ឋាភិបាលនិងដៃគូក្នុងសង្គមស៊ីវិលលើបញ្ហាជំងឺអេដស៍។ខ្ញុំសូមថ្លែងការកោតសរសើរដល់ក្រសួងសុខាភិបាលមជ្ឈមណ្ឌលជាតិកំចាត់ជំងឺអេដស៍ជំងឺសើស្បែកនិងកាមរោគដែលបានដឹកនាំលើបញ្ហានេះ។ទោះបីជាមានភាពជឿនលឿនយ៉ាងនេះក្តីតែការប្រយុទ្ធនឹងជំងឺអេដស៍នៅកម្ពុជាត្រូវមានយូរតទៅទៀត។មានមនុស្សពេញវ័យនិងកុមារចំនួនប្រមាណ៧៥០០០នាក់កំពុងផ្ទុកមេរោគនេះនៅកម្ពុជាហើយមានករណីឆ្លងថ្មីចំនួនប្រមាណ១១០០នាក់ជារៀងរាល់ឆ្នាំ។មានមនុស្សជាច្រើនកំពុងស្ថិតនៅក្នុងភាពប្រឈមយ៉ាងខ្លាំងក្នុងការឆ្លងមេរោគនេះដូចជាបុរសនិងស្រ្តីរកស៊ីផ្លូវភេទនិងអ្នកប្រើគ្រឿងញៀន។លើសពីនេះទៀតមានការរើសអើងនៅឡើយទៅលើអ្នកជំងឺអេដស៍សូម្បីតែការគំរាមធ្វើការរើសអើងក៏អាចរារាំងមិនអោយអ្នកខ្លះមិនហ៊ានទៅរកការព្យាបាលដែលគេត្រូវការបានដែរ។ជំងឺអេដស៍មិនមែនជាបញ្ហាមួយដែលរដ្ឋាភិបាលអាចដោះស្រាយតែម្នាក់ឯងបានទេ។វាជាការទទួលខុសត្រូវរបស់យើងគ្រប់គ្នា។សំរាប់ម្នាក់ៗយើងត្រូវចេះធ្វើការជ្រើសរើសប្រកបដោយភាពវៃឆ្លាតហើយចេះការពារខ្លួនយើងនិងមនុស្សជាទីស្រឡាញ់របស់យើង។នៅតាមសហគមន៍យើងត្រូវរាប់រកអ្នកជំងឺអេដស៍ហើយធ្វើយ៉ាងណាអោយគេមានលទ្ធភាពទទួលបានការថែទាំនិងការព្យាបាលដែលគេត្រូវការ។នៅថ្នាក់ជាតិនិងថ្នាក់អន្តរជាតិយើងត្រូវបន្តធ្វើការជាមួយគ្នាតាមរយៈកម្មវិធីដូចជាកម្មវិធីដើម្បីរកធនធានសំរាប់អ្នកដែលត្រូវការចាំបាច់ជាងគេ។តើអ្នកនឹងមានតួនាទីអ្វីក្នុងការជួយប្រទេសកម្ពុជាអោយមានមុនគេនូវមនុស្សក្នុងមួយជំនាន់ដែលគ្មានមេរោគអេដស៍"
