        "eng": "AmCham Night at the Embassy \n-The Ambassador's Penh\n\nLast night, I was delighted to host the American Chamber of Commerce in Cambodia  better known as AmCham  for their monthly networking event.  It was a wonderful opportunity for the Cambodian business community, special guests, and members of the U.S. Embassy to meet one another, to learn about recent activities of the vibrant business community here, and to discuss ways we can work together.  We had a great turnout with over 200 guests representing the private sector and NGOs who came to network and develop new relationships for doing business in Cambodia.  Acleda Bank, Samaritans Purse, Visa, and the Cambodia Women Entrepreneurs Association represent some of the diverse guests who attended the event. \n\nThe U.S. Embassys partnership with AmCham has played a critical role in our efforts to expand U.S. trade and investment in Cambodia.  Over the last two years, I have traveled with AmCham on two reverse trade missions to the United States and three regional trade missions to Thailand and Singapore.  We have also co-hosted a webinar on doing business in Cambodia and worked together on AmCham-sponsored roundtables that featured such speakers as Minister of Commerce Sun Chanthol and Minister of Education Hang Chuon Naron.  As I emphasized last night, Amcham members can be confident that my U.S. Embassy team is an advocate for building and expanding their outreach.\n\nI am pleased we are starting to see the fruits of our cooperation.  More and more American companies are looking at increasing trade and investing in Cambodia.  Earlier this year Tiffany & Co., an iconic American jewelry company, opened a diamond-polishing factory in Cambodia.  Several other large U.S. companies are planning to start operations next year.\n\nI want to thank everyone who attended the AmCham networking event.  Your presence made the night a tremendous success.  With your help, we can continue to attract new American companies, expand bilateral trade, and support investment in Cambodia.\n\nAmCham and its members deserve considerable credit for the work they do to create a more secure and prosperous future for the people of the United States and Cambodia.         "eng": "Happy World Fisheries Day!  Observed on November 21, World Fisheries Day seeks to promote sustainability by drawing attention to overfishing, habitat destruction, and other threats to our marine and freshwater resources. \n\nA recent UN study reported that more than 2/3 of the world's fisheries have been overfished, and more than 1/3 are in a state of collapse.  The stakes are high.  According to the UN Food and Agriculture Organization, 2.5 BILLION people receive at least 20% of their animal protein intake from fish, and fisheries and aquaculture support the livelihoods of 10-12 percent of the worlds population.     "2014-11-25T07:48:02+0000": {
        "eng": "Do you know what makes someone a hero?  According to American writer Joseph Campbell, A hero is someone who has given his or her life to something bigger than oneself.  \n\nThis can absolutely be said about the U.S. Navy Seabees, who have had a 25 person team present in Cambodia since 2008.  The team has been busy constructing water wells, maternity ward clinics, and modern bathroom facilities to improve conditions for the people of Cambodias provinces.  The Seabees also provide basic life support (BLS) training that includes lessons on proper sanitation and hygiene, snake bites, and basic stitching methods.  The Seabees support the U.S. Embassy and USAID by constructing 2-room maternity wards and 5-stall bathroom facilities in an effort to improve pre and post natal care for mothers and to improve the health and sanitation conditions for students.  \n   \nThe Seabees completed maternity wards are already serving a combined population of 55,278 Cambodians and supporting an average of 390 births per year.  The bathroom facilities are currently serving a student population of 3,506.  Over the next three years the Seabees will construct maternity wards and modern bathrooms throughout six provinces that will serve over 90 villages and 77,000 people.  \n\nThe U.S. Embassy is proud of the work done by the Seabees and looks forward to their continued success.  See more photos of the United States Navy Seabees in the Embassy Picasa photo album here http://goo.gl/8xDRSB .\n\nPhoto: Kep, Cambodia (Nov 10, 2014) Seabees from U.S. Naval Mobile Construction Battalion (NMCB) 4 Detail Cambodia, pose with their counterparts from the Royal Cambodia Armed Forces (RCAF) in front of a 2-room maternity ward being constructed at the Russey Srok Health Center in Kampot Province.\n\nSeabees Kampot, Cambodia",

        "eng": "Call for Proposals: YSEALI Generation \n\nHave you ever had an idea that you wanted to turn into action? Is your group or organization passionate about saving the environment? \n \nA call for grant proposals on the topic of environmental advocacy has been issued by the Office of Public Diplomacy at the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  Grant proposals of up to $250,000 are welcome from U.S. and local non-profit organizations, academic institutions, international  groups and those alike, to develop and manage a four-day workshop on the theme of environment as part of President Obamas Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI).  \n\nThe workshop will be entitled YSEALI Generation: Environmental Advocacy, Responsibility, and Teamwork, and will be held in Cambodia in April 2015.  Complete proposals must be submitted by email to uya@state.gov on or before December 15, 2014.\n\nYSEALI was announced by President Obama in December 2013 and formally launched in May 2014.  The initiative aims to bring together young Southeast Asian leaders to help them work across ASEAN borders to solve common issues including economic development, education, environmental protection, and civic engagement.  Previous YSEALI Generation workshops have been held in Manila, Kuala Lumpur, and Rangoon, and the next one will be held in Singapore in early December on the theme of power of human capital.  The YSEALI Generation: Environmental Advocacy, Responsibility, and Teamwork workshop offers a way for young leaders to partner with the United States on addressing environmental issues, which also have a direct impact on economic development and other pressing concerns. \n\nFor the full call for proposals announcement, go to the U.S. Embassy Cambodia website here http://goo.gl/hiHZdu",

    "2014-11-26T09:40:20+0000": {
        "eng": "Recognizing the Service of the U.S. Marine \n-The Ambassador's Penh\n\nI would like to express my gratitude to the U.S. Embassys Marine Security Guard Detachment for planning the annual Marine Corps Ball last Saturday at the Sofitel Hotel in Phnom Penh.  It was an honor and a privilege to participate in such an amazing event in recognition of the Marines and to celebrate 239 years of distinguished service to our nation and to global peace and security.\n\nThis occasion was among a number of events taking place around the world to commemorate the founding of the Marine Corps on November 10, 1775.  Several distinguished guests were in attendance, including government officials, military service members, and representatives from various companies, non-governmental organizations, and diplomatic missions here in Cambodia.  I was delighted to see so many of my friends there; people who share my appreciation for the Marines serving here at the Embassy and for all Marines and members of the armed forces that serve across the globe.\n\nThe Marine Ball is a time-honored tradition complete with elegant tuxedos and evening gowns, inspiring speeches and presentations, and of course, dancing.  Another component of the Marine Ball is the cake cutting ceremony.  The first slice of cake is given to the oldest Marine present, who then offers it to the youngest Marine in attendance.  This ritual symbolizes the older and wiser Marines passing their knowledge to the next generation.  I was also presented with a slice of cake from one of our Marines, and just like the entire Marine Ball, it was fantastic!\n\nThere are not enough words to express the depth of my respect and gratitude for the Marines.  Their hard work, dedication, and sacrifice inspire me and countless others.  After 239 years of service, the Marine Corps motto of Semper Fidelis  always faithful  is as true today as it was in 1775.  They continue to defend our nation, our citizens, and our values with honor, dignity, and excellence.\n\nPhoto: Ambassador Todd with the members of the U.S. Embassy Marine Security Guard Detachment.\n#AmbTodd", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152602367593224",

        "eng": "Did you know that starting next spring, 250 YSEALI professionals will get the chance to study in the United States?  If you are a young professional in Cambodia, here is how you can add your name to the list. \n\nThe YSEALI Professional Fellows Program is a professional development exchange program for the best and brightest community leaders from the ASEAN region, working in the fields of civic engagement, NGO management, economic empowerment, governance, legislative process, environmental and natural resources management. \n\nThe program provides participants with a five-week fellowship at U.S.-based non-profit organizations, private companies, government offices, or legislative bodies. Fellows will work with community leaders to enhance their practical expertise, leadership skills and professional contacts to address issues in their home communities.\n\nThe application deadline for YSEALI Professional Fellows is December 5th, 2014, so act now if you would like to apply.  Applicants must be: \n  Between the ages of 25-35 at the time of the application, although exceptional applicants younger than 25 will be considered if they meet all other eligibility requirements;\n  A Cambodian citizen;\n  Currently employed and with at least two years of professional experience at the time of application;\n  Proficient in spoken and written English at the time of application; and\n  Eligible to receive a United States J-1 visa.\n\nTo apply now go here http://goo.gl/c1eztH. Once there, click the link to at the bottom of the page to apply.\n\nWant to peek at what else YSEALI has to offer?     "2014-11-27T01:55:10+0000": {
        "eng": "THE WHITE HOUSE\nOffice of the Press Secretary\n\nFor Immediate Release                           November 26, 2014 \n\nTHANKSGIVING DAY, 2014\n- - - - - - - \nBY THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA\nA PROCLAMATION\n\nThanksgiving Day invites us to reflect on the blessings we enjoy and the freedoms we cherish. As we gather with family and friends to take part in this uniquely American celebration, we give thanks for the extraordinary opportunities we have in a Nation of limitless possibilities, and we pay tribute to all those who defend our Union as members of our Armed Forces. This holiday reminds us to show compassion and concern for people we have never met and deep gratitude toward those who have sacrificed to help build the most prosperous Nation on earth. These traditions honor the rich history of our country and hold us together as one American family, no matter who we are or where we come from. \n\nNearly 400 years ago, a group of Pilgrims left their homeland and sailed across an ocean in pursuit of liberty and prosperity. With the friendship and kindness of the Wampanoag people, they learned to harvest the rich bounty of a new world. Together, they shared a successful crop, celebrating bonds of community during a time of great hardship. Through times of war and of peace, the example of a Native tribe who extended a hand to a new people has endured. During the American Revolution and the Civil War, days of thanksgiving drew Americans together in prayer and in the spirit that guides us to better days, and in each year since, our Nation has paused to show our gratitude for our families, communities, and country. \n\nWith God's grace, this holiday season we carry forward the legacy of our forebears. In the company of our loved ones, we give thanks for the people we care about and the joy we share, and we remember those who are less fortunate. At shelters and soup kitchens, Americans give meaning to the simple truth that binds us together: we are our brother's and our sister's keepers. We remember how a determined people set out for a better world -- how through faith and the charity of others, they forged a new life built on freedom and opportunity. \n\nThe spirit of Thanksgiving is universal. It is found in small moments between strangers, reunions shared with friends and loved ones, and in quiet prayers for others. Within the heart of America's promise burns the inextinguishable belief that together we can advance our common prosperity -- that we can build a more hopeful, more just, and more unified Nation. This Thanksgiving, let us recall the values that unite our diverse country, and let us resolve to strengthen these lasting ties. \n\nNOW, THEREFORE, I, BARACK OBAMA, President of the United States of America, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and the laws of the United States, do hereby proclaim Thursday, November 27, 2014, as a National Day of Thanksgiving. I encourage the people of the United States to join together -- whether in our homes, places of worship, community centers, or any place of fellowship for friends and neighbors -- and give thanks for all we have received in the past year, express appreciation to those whose lives enrich our own, and share our bounty with others. \nIN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this twenty-sixth day of November, in the year of our Lord two thousand fourteen, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and thirty-ninth. \n\nBARACK OBAMA \n# # #",

        "eng": "\"What are you thankful for?\" was the question on everyone's mind at the Phnom Penh Access Center on Tuesday evening. \n \nAndrea Echelberger, U.S. English Language Fellow, led the Access students in a lesson about the history and traditions of Thanksgiving, finishing up with a discussion about thankfulness.  When asked what she is thankful for, one student responded, \"I am thankful for my school because it gives me good opportunities for my future to help my mother and father.\" Many other students answered that they are thankful for parents, sisters and brothers, friends, and teachers.  However, at the end of the lesson, all of the students unanimously agreed that they are thankful for Facebook!\n\nThe English Access Microscholarship Program (Access) provides a foundation of English language skills to talented 13-20 year-olds from economically disadvantaged sectors through after-school classes and intensive sessions.  \n\nAccess gives participants English skills that may lead to better jobs and greater educational opportunities. Participants also gain the ability to compete for and participate in future exchanges and study in the United States.\n\nThe English Access Microscholarship Program is available to students in Phnom Penh, Banteay Meanchey, Battambang, and Kampong Speu.  \n\nTo find out more about the program, click here http://goo.gl/57Eov6",

    "2014-11-28T10:20:19+0000": {
        "eng": "Promoting Entrepreneurship\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nI believe that entrepreneurs play a vital role in the development of a prosperous and dynamic society.  In the United States, innovators such as Bill Gates, Steve Jobs, and Mark Zuckerberg generated ideas that have revolutionized technologies that we utilize globally.  They are internationally recognized and admired for nurturing their unique ideas into businesses and industries that have changed our lives and changed how we interact with one another. The creativity, drive, and determination that these and other entrepreneurs exhibit are the same qualities that I see in so many of the young Cambodians I talk to and work with. I firmly believe that their entrepreneurial energy and spirit are important keys to Cambodias future success.\n\nThis is why I was so delighted that Cambodian social entrepreneur and Young Southeast Asian Leadership Initiative (YSEALI) member Thul Rithy was able to participate in this years Global Entrepreneurship Summit in Morocco with the support of the U.S. Embassy.  Thul joined dozens of other young leaders from around the world for this event, held annually during Global Entrepreneurship Week.  The purpose of this summit is to bring a diverse group of entrepreneurs together with high-level government officials, corporate leaders, and small-medium enterprises (SMEs) in order to network, share experiences, and exchange ideas on a wide variety of topics.  \n\nHere is what Thul had to say during his time in Morocco: Participating in the Global Entrepreneurship Summit was a great eye-opening and friendship-building experience with smart, good-hearted and beautiful people from around the world. I was very impressed with each individual's works in their respective communities. There have been many things that pop up in my head, but one thing that surely stays in there all the time is the idea of growing a strong start-up community in Cambodia.\n\nGlobal Entrepreneurship Week aims to inspire and develop innovators and entrepreneurs through networking, mentorship, and business plan competitions. Celebrating its fifth year, this years summit theme  Harnessing the Power of Technology for Innovation and Entrepreneurship  emphasized the role that modern technology plays in fueling innovative concepts which build social capital, promote human development, and facilitate information exchange. More than 3,000 individuals from over 50 countries participated in interactive sessions that featured experienced entrepreneurs who started locally, scaled their business ideas, and created successful enterprises.  The summit included business plan competitions, an Innovation Village that allowed young entrepreneurs to network and find mentors, and a number of activities celebrating the achievements of women entrepreneurs.  Also speaking at the summit was U.S. Vice President Joe Biden, who made it clear that a country can thrive when it fosters an environment that allows young people to become empowered through education and employment opportunities. \n\nThe Vice President told the group, As the demographic wave of young people enters the labor force, it doesnt matter where you live if people cannot get educated; or they get educated and they cant get a job; or they get a job and cant earn a decent living; or they can earn a living, but it gets siphoned off or stolen by corruption; or if half the population women  cannot contribute to prosperity; those countries caught in that vortex are not positioned to succeed in the 21st century because real and lasting stability depends on governments and citizens finding a way to work together to expand opportunity and unlock the enormous talents of your people.\n\nThe U.S. Embassy continues to promote entrepreneurship as part of our efforts to help empower youth and expand Cambodias middle class.  Among other programs and initiatives, we have hosted a series of workshops and lectures at high schools and universities in Phnom Penh and Siem Reap that focused on the role that entrepreneurs play in solving problems and advancing progress in Cambodia.  Entrepreneurs help solve some of societys greatest challenges.  They design innovative solutions that raise productivity.  They start new businesses that create jobs.  These activities lead to economic growth, poverty reduction, and improvement in the quality of life for the citizens of Cambodia.  I will continue to lend my support and encourage ambitious and resourceful Cambodians like Thul Rithy, because many of these young Cambodians are destined to be future leaders and agents of change for the country and the world.\n\n#AmbTodd",

    "2014-12-02T09:24:54+0000": {
        "eng": "World AIDS Day 2014\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nWatching the news yesterday, I was impressed to see stories about the many different ways people throughout Cambodia commemorated World AIDS Day 2014.  December 1 is a day to not only reflect on the many lives lost and forever changed as a result of AIDS, but also to celebrate the lives saved and recognize those working to eliminate this disease.  As I have stated before, the U.S. partnership with Cambodia to reduce HIV/AIDS infection rates here is one the most successful stories among our development assistance programs.  But with an estimated 75,000 people in Cambodia living with HIV and approximately 1,100 newly infected people each year, there is still much work to be done.  I commend the ongoing efforts of those taking on the challenge to create an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia, which includes government and civil society organizations.\n\nThe United States has focused its resources for eradicating HIV/AIDS in Cambodia and throughout the world through the Presidents Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).  With resources from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the PEPFAR office in Cambodia supports partnerships, programs and activities focused on saving lives.  Last year alone, PEPFAR assisted Cambodia in providing treatment to almost 50,000 people and HIV testing to over 80,000 pregnant women.  These and other PEPFAR-supported endeavors make the goal of an AIDS-free generation an achievable one.  To build on prior success, the total amount of U.S. government funding available through PEPFAR in 2015 for HIV/AIDS programs implemented by USAID and CDC in Cambodia will remain the same as in 2014.  The focus of this support is on delivering the highest impact interventions, bringing them to scale among the most vulnerable populations, and maintaining a sense of urgency to stop this epidemic.\n\nI was recently reminded by a friend to reflect on what we have achieved together in Cambodia to fight HIV/AIDS.  Not so long ago, resources were so limited that hospital beds were filled with dying patients, while others lay dying on the floor.  Nearly 35 years into the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and more than 20 years since the first cases were detected here, Cambodia today is one of 12 countries in the world that provide universal access to HIV treatment, and the HIV prevalence rate in adults decreased by more than half from 1998 to 2010.  At the end of the day, the results of our joint efforts lives saved and new infections averted determine whether or not we are winning the fight against HIV/AIDS.  Without a doubt, Cambodias story is a true achievement.  Now the question is: how do we build off of our past achievements to obtain even greater success in the future?  \n\nOn World AIDS Day 2014 in Cambodia, organizations like Friends International and the AIDS Healthcare Foundation held programs that included youth activities and HIV testing.  The Labor Ministry awarded several companies in a range of sectors  including the garment industry, hospitality, banking, telecommunications, and entertainment  for providing HIV/AIDS education and counseling services to their employees.  These are just a few examples of the numerous individuals involved in the fight against this disease.  However, no one entity alone can create an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia.  That is why we must not only work towards our shared goal on December 1; it is a prolonged commitment.\n\nThe United States and the Royal Government of Cambodia have developed a strong partnership and have collaborated with other international, non-governmental, and civil society organizations to fight against HIV/AIDS.  With advances in science and technology, lifesaving knowledge and health care can be brought to even more people throughout Cambodia via collaboration.  Moving forward, I hope to see a continued emphasis on partnership to ensure that our collective investment is used efficiently and effectively, with maximal results. \n\nThe vision for the next phase in the fight against HIV/AIDS is a defined, shared, and sustainable result.  I genuinely believe that if Cambodia maintains its commitment and continues to work with its partners, it has a very good chance of becoming the first country in the world with an AIDS-free generation.  Each of us can play a vital role in helping to create an AIDS-free generation in Cambodia.  On an individual level, we can make smart choices that will protect ourselves and our loved ones.  At the community level, we can embrace those who are struggling with HIV/AIDS and ensure that they have access to quality care and treatment.  And at the national and international level, we can continue working together through programs like PEPFAR to provide resources where they are needed most.  In recognition of World AIDS Day, I encourage each of you to do your part in the fight against HIV/AIDS in Cambodia.\n\nWhat did you do in recognition of World AIDS Day 2014?  Please share your comments.\n\n#AmbTodd\n\nPhoto: Youth education programs and activities were featured during a World AIDS Day 2014 event at the Mith Samlan Center in Phnom Penh. (Friends International)\n\nRead this and all previous entries from Ambassador Todd's blog here http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152613338383224", 
        "kh": "’––’––"

    "2014-12-05T10:37:12+0000": {
        "eng": "Taking Care of Our Animals\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nCambodia is home to an amazingly diverse collection of animals.  One animal  the elephant  has long been part of Cambodian history.  Elephants have assisted human endeavors in various ways for centuries; from helping Cambodians sustain themselves through agriculture and forestry, to even taking Khmer warriors into battle.  If you have visited the Angkor Wat area, I am sure that you noticed the images of elephants carved on the walls of ancient Khmer temples.  Elephants can still be seen in Cambodia today carrying crops, lumber and just about anything else, including tourists.  Unfortunately, the number of elephants in Cambodia has decreased over the years due to illegal poaching and mistreatment.  I recently had the pleasure to learn more about these endangered animals at the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Center during a visit with my Youth Council.\n\nToday, I want to focus on a very special elephant named Sambo, one of Phnom Penhs most famous attractions.  For more than 30 years, Sambo spent nine or more hours a day carrying tourists around Wat Phnom.  Sambos work helped support her owner, Sin Sorn, and his family.  However, the numerous hours spent walking on the hard pavement of Phnom Penhs streets caused Sambo to develop chronic foot infections.  After her plight received worldwide attention in 2012, a nongovernmental organization was able to provide Sambo with the medical treatment she dearly needed.  \n\nI was delighted to learn that Sambo is retiring to a special elephant sanctuary in Mondulkiri Province, where she will live with other elephants and receive proper veterinary care.  Sambos retirement and transportation to her new home is a wonderful example of what can be accomplished by working together.  This collaborative effort was supported by the U.S. government through the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), Cambodias Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, the Alexander Abraham Foundation, and private citizens.  A farewell ceremony was held in her honor in Phnom Penh last week and I was pleased to see a number of Cambodian and international media outlets covering the event.  Sambos story is truly uplifting and helps put the people of Cambodia in a positive light.\n\nThis week, I have been eagerly waiting for news about Sambos journey to her new home.  So I was delighted to hear that five days after leaving Phnom Penh, Sambo safely arrived at the Elephants Livelihood Initiative Environment project inside the Seima Protected Forest.  From the reports I received, she looks happy in her new home and will meet other elephants in the next few days.  I would like to thank everyone who made all of this possible; especially the people who cared for Sambo during the long journey to Mondulkiri. \n\nI believe that all animals deserve to be treated well.  As a reader, you know that I am an animal lover and my family has had a dog for nearly as long as I can remember.  By treating Sambo and other animals with respect and dignity, our society demonstrates compassion.  I commend Mr. Sorn for agreeing to let Sambo  now 52 years old  retire and spend the remaining years of her life in a natural habitat with other elephants.  As Mr. Sorn said, We owe Sambo a great debt and it is time to pay her back.  I couldnt agree more.\n\n#AmbTodd\n\nRead the latest blog from Ambassador Todd each week! http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152618463148224", 
        "kh": "––’’’’’’’––“”’"
    },

        "eng": "The 2014 To Walk the Earth in Safety report describes the efforts of the U.S. Conventional Weapons Destruction Program and its partners to reduce the harmful effects of landmines and other unexploded ordinance (#UXO).  In Cambodia, the U.S. has contributed more than $97 million toward landmine clearance and safe disposal, education programs, and assistance for landmine explosion survivors and their families.  Programs such as the HALO Trust and Golden West Humanitarian Foundation play an active role in removing UXOs from Cambodian fields in an environmentally responsible manner, making these areas safe for people to live, work and play.  \n\nThe full report is available here: http://goo.gl/Q9kgsO \n\nPhoto: A HALO de-miner training to use a MINEHOUND detector near a temple in Cambodia.     "2014-12-10T04:25:35+0000": {
        "eng": "Ambassador Todd has released an official statement in recognition of Human Rights Day 2014:\n\nToday marks the 66th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly on December 10, 1948, which affirms that the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world.  The shared values that guided the international community in creating this landmark document in the wake of the Second World War  fundamental beliefs about liberty, equality, and justice under the law for all  remain essential today.  On this day, we recognize the progress that has been made in protecting and promoting basic freedoms across the world and also reflect on how far we have to go.  \n\nIn recognition of Human Rights Day, I would like to give special acknowledgement to the many individuals, civil society organizations, and NGOs that work every day to promote democratic principles and to advocate for human rights in Cambodia.  The U.S. Embassy in Cambodia is proud to stand with you.  The knowledge, dedication, and passion that you demonstrate in your work serve as an inspiration to all.\n\nDuring my time in Cambodia, I have followed the human rights situation closely.  There have been some improvements, but there have also been setbacks.  The Universal Declaration of Human Rights is incorporated into the Constitution of the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia, but living up to the principles enshrined in the UDHR requires constant effort and attention. \n\nI encourage all Cambodians to take this day to rededicate themselves to promoting basic human rights and freedoms.  In particular, I urge the government to engage with the opposition and civil society to address the issues of impunity, nepotism, and corruption, which together have a corrosive effect on society, weakening economic growth and stability, and undercutting progress made on human rights.  It is incumbent on all parties to set aside petty differences and to work together for the benefit of the people of Cambodia.\n\nThe United States remains deeply committed to the protection of human rights in order to secure the peace, deter aggression, promote the rule of law, combat crime and corruption, strengthen democracies, and prevent humanitarian crises.  This commitment is evident in our work with all levels of government and society.  We look forward to continuing our partnership with all sectors of Cambodian society to promote the universal freedoms enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Cambodian Constitution.\n\n#AmbTodd #HumanRightsDay",

    "2014-12-10T07:56:01+0000": {
        "eng": "The Power of Film\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nAmericans love going to the movies. Catching the latest blockbuster on the big screen with friends on a Friday night is a rite of passage for many teenagers in America. Around the world, movies bring people together, they entertain us, and some even make us laugh or cry. I also believe films can teach us about our society, both past and present, and become an important part of our historical memory.\n\nI know movies also appeal to Cambodians, especially young people. This country has a proud history of filmmaking. During the golden age of Cambodian cinema in the 1960s, over 300 films were made in the Kingdom. Sadly, only 30 of them survived the Khmer Rouge period. But I am optimistic about the future of Cambodian cinema. Today, a new generation of Cambodian filmmakers is receiving well-deserved recognition for their tireless work. Earlier this year, Rithy Panhs The Missing Picture was the first Cambodian film to be nominated for an Academy Award. In October, film director Sotho Kulikar received the Spirit of Asia Award at the prestigious Tokyo International Film Festival for her entry The Last Reel, which opened the 5th Annual Cambodia International Film Festival last week.\n\nThe Last Reel is the first full-length independent film by Hanuman Films, a Cambodian film production company run by Kulikar. Joining the film as executive producer was American Lloyd Levin, who first came to Cambodia to work on the Lara Croft: Tomb Raider film. At Hanuman Films, they are working to raise Cambodias profile by bringing more international film productions to the country.\n\nI think movies can give a voice to the past, and this is true for The Last Reel, which explores the legacy of civil war and the shadow it has cast over the next generation. Kulikar hopes her film will play its part in a long overdue healing process in Cambodia, by encouraging generations old and young to talk more openly about the past.\n\nI was also delighted to learn that the film Dont Think Ive Forgotten: Cambodias Lost Rock and Roll was featured during the Cambodia International Film Festival. John Pirozzi, the films American director, attended a special screening at Chaktomuk Theater and hosted a lively Q&A session with the musicians and performers from the film. As you may recall from a previous blog, Remembering Cambodias Lost Rock and Roll, this film is about Cambodias vibrant and unique music scene during the 1960s. The U.S. Embassy was honored to collaborate with John and the Documentation Center of Cambodia to support the world premiere of the film earlier this year. The film will premiere in the United States at the renowned Film Forum in New York City in April 2015, giving more people the chance to learn about Cambodias remarkable history and culture.\n\nI am thrilled that so many people attended the Cambodia International Film Festival this year. Congratulations to all of the organizers and to the filmmakers who participated.\n\nDo you like films? What lessons have you learned from watching movies?\n\n#AmbTodd \n\nClick here to see more photos and read more from Ambassdor Todd's blog http://goo.gl/vPQDm",

    "2014-12-12T10:19:01+0000": {
        "eng": "A Life Worth Living \n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nOn December 10, the world lost a powerful voice for human rights in Cambodia with the sudden and unexpected death of Chan Soveth, who was a senior investigator for the human rights NGO ADHOC.  As many Cambodians already know, Soveth died of a heart attack after returning home from a Human Rights Day event.  He is survived by his wife and three children.\n\nAlthough he died much too soon, at age 51, Soveth leaves behind a legacy that should make his family and nation proud.  Soveths primary work was to compile investigation reports on suspected human rights violations, with a focus on land disputes.  He helped to shed light cases that might otherwise have gone unnoticed by the human rights community.  Soveth didnt just bring attention to problems  he looked for solutions.  For instance, he took the lead in establishing a dialogue with the Cambodian Human Rights Committee, which led to a new found cooperation between the government and NGOs on the investigation of human rights violation cases.  \n\nLike many of his generation, Soveth was orphaned during the Khmer Rouge regime and lived for a time as a refugee.  He was able to overcome adversity, to develop knowledge and expertise, and ultimately to find his lifes work as a human rights investigator.  Soveth worked tirelessly  day or night, weekday or weekend.  Soveth worked in some of the most remote parts of the country, and he never backed down in the face of threats and intimidation.  He always put the needs of the Cambodian people ahead of his own personal safety and comfort.  \n\nTo me, Soveths story demonstrates that one person really can bring about positive change through hard work, dedication, and persistence.  It also shows that you dont have to be famous to make a difference.  Soveth may have worked behind the scenes for most of his career, but his work has had a positive impact on many thousands of Cambodians.  Although he is no longer with us, my hope is that Soveths life will serve as an inspiration to present and future human rights defenders, both in Cambodia and throughout the world.  He has certainly been a great inspiration to me.  He will be missed.\n\n#AmbTodd\n\nRead more from Ambassador Todd's blog, \"From the Ambassador's Penh\" here: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/",

        "eng": "VOA Khmer recently interviewed Erin Moriarty Harrelson about her work with Cambodias deaf community.  Erin, who is also deaf, is a Fulbright National Geographic Digital Storytelling Fellow and looks to make a difference by documenting the lives of deaf people in rural Cambodia.  Cambodias deaf population lack sufficient access to education and information due to the absence of closed caption television and other resources.  \n\nErin's work can assist policymakers and NGOs improve conditions for the countrys deaf people.  I hope to help raise awareness about deaf people in Cambodia and their everyday lives.     "2014-12-16T07:11:25+0000": {
        "eng": "Life Along Cambodias Great Lake\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nI was reminded of Cambodias stunning natural beauty during a recent visit to the Preak Toal village and its neighboring bird sanctuary.  Located not far from Siem Reap, it is a breathtaking ecosystem full of plant and animal life.  Even getting to the sanctuary was an adventure; a two-hour boat ride through lush mangroves and wet forests.  But as visually impressive as the sanctuary was, I was most inspired by the people I met in the fishing communities of Preak Toal.  Their story is closely tied to the bird sanctuary and the remarkable Tonle Sap Lake. \n\nThe people that live along the Tonle Sap are hard workers.  They depend on fish for food as well as their livelihoods, but this precious resource is not always available.  Changes in the weather, rains, and droughts can make fishing a difficult and frustrating activity.  As a fisherman myself, I know how patient and how attentive one has to be to land a catch.  Hearing about the daily challenges they face and knowing there are no easy solutions gave me a glimpse into how tough it can be to live and work in Preak Toal.\n\nBut as I listened to their stories, the issue they raised again and again was their childrens education.  Among the 3,500 youth under 18 years of age in Preak Toal, only 100 of them are in primary school and just 10 are in secondary school.  As a father, educating my children has been one of the top priorities of my life.  So I understand why the parents in this community are so worried about schooling.  Education is a tool that all children need to stand on their own and provide opportunities to their children in the future.\n\nAfter talking with the fishermen, I visited the bird breeding sanctuary of the Preak Toal Core Area, part of the Tonle Sap Biosphere Reserve and a breeding sanctuary for more than 100,000 large water birds from 12 different species.  With changes in climate and the natural environment, local wildlife species  many of them quite rare  have struggled to survive.  They have been losing their natural habitat at a rapid rate causing their populations to dwindle.  This was why I was so pleased to see that the fishing communities of Preak Toal have been deeply involved in the protection and management of the bird sanctuary that borders their homes.  With assistance from the U.S. government, members of the fishing villages have been trained to serve as forest rangers, monitoring and reporting on the bird populations of the sanctuary.  \n\nThe rangers position themselves on hand-built platforms perched high in the trees overlooking the sanctuary.  They can remain at their stations for up to 10 days at a time, closely watching the various birds residing in the area.  The hard work of these rangers  as well as the joint efforts of local Cambodian authorities and the U.S. Embassy  has led to significant increases in the bird population.  This precious ecosystem is gradually regaining its glory as the keeper of the regions huge number of animal and plant species.  \n\nIt was an incredible trip and an experience that I will never forget.  Speaking with the families of Preak Toal and seeing the beautiful bird sanctuary highlighted, once again, how important it is that Cambodians protect their precious resources.  I want to thank all those with whom I met for taking their time to share their story with me.  I was both moved and energized by their commitment to their community and their environment.\n\n#AmbTodd #Cambodia\n\nRead more from Ambassador Todd's blog here:  http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152639846748224", 
        "kh": "’’’––––’"
    },

        "eng": "On December 13, Major General James Pasquarette, Deputy Commanding General for U.S. Army Pacific, based in Hawaii, was joined by Cambodian Minister of Health His Excellency Mam Bun Hen at the groundbreaking ceremony for a new blood donation center in Phnom Penh constructed with the support of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.  The building will be the new home of the National Blood Transfusion Center in Phnom Penh and is the first of three new blood donation centers to be built by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in Cambodia.  The center will help ensure a safe blood supply for the capital city and also serve as the national headquarters for storing blood.  \n\nThe National Blood Transfusion Center is the largest project ever constructed using Overseas Humanitarian, Disaster, and Civic Aid funding from the U.S. Department of Defenses Pacific Command.  This project includes additional support from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, Global Fund, the Australian Red Cross, and U.S. Pacific Command Surgeon's Office.  \n\n#Cambodia U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Headquarters Australian Red Cross",

    "2014-12-19T09:59:48+0000": {
        "eng": "Social Media in Cambodia \n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nIf you are reading this blog, you probably have access to a computer and have a Facebook account.  Cambodians are increasingly connected online, and the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia is proud to be a small part of this technological revolution.  \n\nWhen I began my service as the U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, our Facebook page had just over 25,000 fans.  Today, a third of 1 million fans along with more than 34,000 Twitter followers  prove that Cambodians want to connect with us and receive news about the programs we support.  Furthermore, it shows that people want to participate in dialogue on important issues in the country.  All of you who have commented on our Facebook page, responded on my blog, or have sent me questions for my weekly Ask the Ambassador column, have greatly contributed to the valuable conversations we are having about Cambodias future.\n\nToday, the Internet provides unprecedented reach and freedom for people to gather information and express their opinions.  Even more important, this technology is interactive, allowing users to select the content they find most useful and relevant in their lives.  This ability to access accurate and independent information is the engine of a free and democratic society.  Despite low access to the Internet in several parts of the country, the fact that so many Cambodians are taking advantage of online resources when they are available is an indication of their desire to be well-informed, active participants in the countrys growing democracy.    \n\nWith 1.23 billion users across the world, Facebook has become an increasingly important way of obtaining information not only about friends and family, but also about world events.  Along with Twitter, YouTube, and other platforms, social media is having a tremendous impact on the way Cambodians are receiving and sharing information about what is happening in the country and around the globe.  The attraction of social media is that it enables a two-way dialogue, something that is not possible with traditional media.  This form of communication has continued to grow in significance and now serves as a powerful tool for soliciting ideas and feedback on the issues that matter to Cambodians, particularly with young people.\n\nSocial media has provided a large number of Cambodian youth with opportunities to express their views about the countrys development.  With one of the youngest populations in Southeast Asia, Cambodias hope for the future lies in the minds and the lives of these young people.  The number of Facebook pages, Twitter accounts, and YouTube videos being created in Cambodia represents the desire for knowledge and innovation by young Cambodians.  This intellectual curiosity is a great equalizer when it comes to competing for opportunities in the country, throughout the ASEAN region, and across the world.  Therefore, along with face-to-face outreach, the U.S. Embassy works hard to connect with youth via social media, posting content that appeals to young Cambodians and making an effort to respond to their questions and comments. \n\nWhen the U.S. Embassy promotes its social media platforms, it is not to compete with other individuals or organizations to see who can get the most fans.  Whether you choose to follow your favorite singer, news source, or a public official; we support a free and democratic society in Cambodia which allows its people to access and select content from the Internet and other media of their choosing.  The reason why we seek your support is because every time that you like and share our Facebook posts or retweet our Twitter content, you help us reach more users.  This gives more Cambodians access to information about education, exchanges, President Obamas Young Southeast Asian Leadership Initiative (YSEALI), English language learning, and a host of other programs.  So while 333,333 is remarkable (and a very lucky number), this is only the beginning.\n\nOur next goal is to reach 500,000 Facebook fans.  Would you like to help us achieve this next milestone?  We will do our part by making sure our Facebook page is a source of meaningful, noteworthy and helpful information, and you can assist us by letting all of your friends know that we invite them to join our online family.  With our combined efforts, I am confident that we will make it to 500,000 Facebook fans and beyond.\n\n#AmbTodd #Cambodia\n\nRead more from the Ambassador Todd's blog here: blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/",

    "2014-12-23T10:03:21+0000": {
        "eng": "Gaining Access to the World with English\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nIn todays globalized economy and with the economic integration of ASEAN countries in 2015, mastery of the English language is a critical tool for Cambodias future leaders.  Many jobs now require at least some ability in English, so young people are becoming more interested in learning the language.  Some communities, however, still lack adequate resources for those seeking to improve their English language skills.  To assist, the U.S. Embassy helps young Cambodians and their families through the English Access Microscholarship Program (Access).  When I hear about the Access Program, I am most inspired by stories about the impact that it continues to have on youth throughout the country.\n\nA native of Phnom Penh, Afiny Math left school at an early age to work and help her family financially.  Due to limited financial resources, it was nearly impossible for her to have an opportunity to receive a good education.  Seeking to improve her English language skills, Afiny applied to the Access Program and was selected.  Upon graduation from the program, she received employment with the Cambodian Islamic Youth Association  the same organization that administered the Access Program where she was a participant.  Today, Afiny is a role model and a good example of how English language learning can have an impact on ones life. \n\nAfinys story is featured on the website for the U.S. State Department's English Access Microscholarship Program.  She is one of approximately 95,000 students from more than 85 countries that have participated in the program since 2004.  Through after-school classes and intensive summer learning activities, talented youth aged 13-20 receive a strong foundation of English language skills.  Additionally, they develop an appreciation for American culture and values, enhance their ability to compete for and participate in future U.S. government exchange and study programs, and increase their capability to successfully participate in their countrys development.\n\nOver the past 10 years, the Access Program has provided scholarships to more than 1,000 Cambodian students in 11 provinces.  Working with a number of NGOs to administer the program, Access has provided students with friendly learning environments to practice their English language and critical thinking skills.   To enhance their English learning experience, U.S. Embassy staff visit Access Program sites across the country to present certificates, give presentations, or simply have conversations with the students.  Each year, I have the pleasure of meeting several Access Program students and teachers during the English Camp hosted at the U.S. Embassy.  We invest as much as we can to ensure that each participant in the Access Program has an enjoyable experience that will contribute to their continued study of the English language.  \n\nI feel strongly about Cambodians having access to quality English education.  Along with the Access Program, the U.S. Embassy supports English language education in Cambodia in a variety of ways.  English Language Fellows from the United States are working with the National Institute of Education and regional teacher training centers to strengthen curriculum development and professional skills for both teacher trainers and teacher trainees.  Cambodian English language teachers receive instruction training and materials to better prepare their students.  Peace Corps Volunteers are assisting teachers and providing English instruction in 14 provinces.  These and other programs help to increase Cambodias competitiveness by giving people the ability to pursue higher quality education and better jobs.  Furthermore, Cambodians will have the opportunity to utilize the knowledge and skills that they have acquired to assist in developing their communities.  A group of Access students in Ratanakiri are already proving this by helping to establish a library in their local community.  After seeing the commitment demonstrated by the participants of our English language programs, I am confident in their ability to contribute to Cambodias progress.\n\nThrough the English Access Microscholarship and other programs, the United States remains committed to helping the people of Cambodia to achieve success and prosperity.  Whenever I speak to young Cambodians, I am pleased to hear so much excitement and interest about English language learning and studying in the United States.  In addition to giving them the skills they need to thrive, these present-day opportunities will help lead Cambodia into a more prosperous future. \n\n#AmbTodd #Cambodia English Access Microscholarship Program-Cambodia\n\nPhoto: New Access Program students in Banteay Meanchey received certificates as well as bicycles, donated to those that live farthest away from the language center.",

    "2014-12-26T02:45:00+0000": {
        "eng": "Heres to a Wonderful Holiday Season for All \n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nI am currently in the United States celebrating Christmas with my family.  Like many Americans and others around the world, we spent time together this week gathering with relatives and friends, decorating the Christmas tree, and sharing a holiday dinner complete with two of my favorite foods: turkey and pumpkin pie.  My children are older now, but I am delighted to see that they are still just as excited about this time of the year as their father.\n\nBefore coming to see my family in the U.S., I made sure to spend holiday time with my extended family in Cambodia as well.  I joined U.S. Embassy personnel and their family members to celebrate with good food and music on the Embassys lawn.  The children in attendance were even lucky enough to receive a visit from Santa Claus himself!  The event culminated with the holiday light show.  With thousands of lights accompanied by holiday music, it is a wonderful display of art and imagination.  If you have walked or driven by the Embassy at night this month, you have seen many Cambodian families sitting in the nearby park to watch the light show.  In the spirit of the holiday season, we are happy to share this festive American tradition with all of our friends in Cambodia.\n\nDuring this time of the year, Americans observe a wide variety of holidays, including the Christian observance of Christmas, the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, and the African-American celebration of Kwanzaa.  Regardless of ones religious or ethnic background, Americans of all faiths and traditions spend this time to reflect on our shared values: unity among family and friends, appreciation for life, and a spirit of goodwill toward others.  While somewhat different, our holiday traditions are similar to those familiar to people in Cambodia.  Just as Americans celebrate this holiday season by sharing meals and exchanging gifts with our loved ones, Cambodians will be doing the same during the Khmer New Year.\n\nThe holiday season reminds us about the importance of reaching out and taking care of our fellow human beings.  Our Marine Security Guard Detachment at the U.S. Embassy has spent the last few months conducting a Toys for Tots campaign to provide Cambodian children with gifts and bring smiles to their faces.  Their goal is not to just give free toys, but to deliver a message of hope that will encourage these children and build their self-esteem.  Many of our extraordinary men and women in uniform serving around the world are not able to be with their families during the holidays.  This makes efforts like Toys for Tots all the more reason to acknowledge our Marines and their dedication to helping others.\n\nI would like to express my appreciation to those who unselfishly serve others, not only during this holiday season, but on a daily basis.  Thanks to our U.S. military service members, American and Cambodian staff at the Embassy, our local and international NGO partners, and the many Cambodian men, women, and young people dedicated to moving Cambodia forward.  I wish you all a joyous and wonderful holiday season. \n\n#AmbTodd #Cambodia",

    "2014-12-31T10:00:01+0000": {
        "eng": "On behalf of Ambassador Todd and the U.S. Embassy, best wishes to all for a safe and happy New Year!\n\nResolutions for the New Year \n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nAs I prepare to celebrate the start of a new year in the United States, I see that many Americans are reflecting on the past and anticipating the future with many customs brought by our diverse immigrant population from Asia, Europe, Africa and Latin America.    The festivities actually begin on the night of December 31 with parties, concerts, television specials, and other events followed by spectacular fireworks displays.  On the first day of the New Year, people in many U.S. cities and towns watch American football games, parades, and shows about the main events from the previous year.  No matter how one chooses to celebrate, Americans recognize this time as an opportunity to reflect on prior achievements and plan for the upcoming year.\n\nFor many people, another important tradition that makes this day special is creating a New Years resolution.  This is a personal commitment to accomplish something important to them during the New Year.  Studies show that about 45 percent of Americans make New Years resolutions annually, with a significant number of people finding the determination to achieve their goals.  Making a resolution offers a fresh start, whether you are doing something for the first time or renewing an effort that was not successful in the past.  The New Years resolution is grounded in the fundamental belief that we can improve our lives as long as we continue to try our best.\n\nPresident Abraham Lincoln said, Always bear in mind that your own resolution to succeed is more important than any other.  When thinking about a New Years resolution, it is helpful to choose an objective that can be successfully reached.  These goals may be short-term or long-term, simple or complex, individual or shared.  Some of the most common New Years resolutions for Americans include:\n Focusing on health:  Lose weight, exercise, eat healthier foods.\n Becoming more financially savvy:  Lower debts, save money.\n Quitting a bad habit:  Drink less alcohol, quit smoking.\n Improving professionally:  Find a better job, pursue higher education.\n Traveling more:  Plan a trip.\n Being more environmentally responsible:  Reduce, reuse, recycle.\n Serving others:  Volunteer more.\nAs you can see, these are positive goals that can be achieved with a committed effort.  While optimism and the can-do attitude are values deeply cherished in the United States, Cambodians also believe that a better future is possible through dedication and hard work.  This is why I am sure that my readers can relate to the idea of a New Years resolution.\n\nCommitting to a personal resolution is a New Years tradition that I have always loved.  While spending time here with my family in the United States, I have also been coming up with some New Years resolutions that I look forward to starting upon my return to Cambodia.  I plan on taking more trips throughout the country, particularly to areas that I have not yet visited.  While traveling this year to places like Krati Province and the Prek Toal Bird Sanctuary and Floating Village along the Tonl Sap, I learned a great deal from my interactions with Cambodians living in the rural parts of the country.  I will continue to speak with and listen to the public  both directly and via social media  about the issues that matter most to the Cambodian people.  With over 350,000 Facebook fans and more than 35,000 followers on Twitter to date, I look forward to increasing our reach so that even more people can be involved in meaningful dialogue with us about Cambodias future.  Focusing on the future of the entire country, I will promote youth outreach and work to improve the daily lives of the average Cambodian.  By encouraging Cambodian youth to join the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (YSEALI), I am confident that they will be able to strengthen their leadership and networking skills.  Last but not least, I will remain committed to a prosperous and mutually beneficial friendship between the United States and Cambodia.\n\nEven though the Khmer New Year in April is a much larger celebration than January 1 in Cambodia, the New Years resolution is something that I would like to share with you.  I am grateful to the many Cambodians who have helped me learn about your customs and holidays, so hopefully you will join me in taking part in this American tradition.  As we get ready to for the first day of 2015, I wish all of you peace, health, and happiness in 2015. \n\nWhat are your New Years resolutions?  Please feel free to let me know in the comments section.\n\n#AmbTodd \nRead more from Ambassador Todd's blog here: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/\n\n#Cambodia #NewYear", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152673950863224", 
        "kh": "“’”’’“”’’•••••••“”’’’éé––’’’"

        "eng": "Do you use Twitter? We do! Follow the U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh @USEmbPhnomPenh\n\n#Cambodia",

    "2015-01-03T09:30:03+0000": {
        "eng": "A Successful First Year for YSEALI\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nThe Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative  known to many as YSEALI  recently celebrated its first anniversary.  Since the creation of President Obamas signature program for promoting youth leadership and networking in the region, more than 1,000 Cambodian youth have joined thousands more of their peers throughout Southeast Asia to not only discuss topics such as entrepreneurship and civic engagement, but also to take significant action to address issues that matter most in their communities.  As a reader of my blog, you are probably familiar with my excitement about YSEALI and the potential that I believe it has for creating the next generation of leaders in Cambodia.   \n\nYSEALI has provided a number of opportunities and tools to support Cambodias youth.  Workshops in Manila and Kuala Lumpur featured enthusiastic Cambodian participants who were among the first to win grant money to create a YSEALI regional project.  Called Streams of Hope, this innovative project involved youth from Cambodia, Vietnam, and the Philippines to promote the importance of river rehabilitation.  In November, 20 YSEALI participants  two from each ASEAN member nation  met in Rangoon to examine how collaboration within their fields of interest can lead to a bigger impact in their communities and throughout the region.  In December, the U.S. Embassy sent six young Cambodians to Singapore to participate in a regional workshop entitled YSEALI Generation: The Power of Human Capital.  With help from the U.S.-ASEAN Business Council, YSEALI members were able to identify the soft skills that are crucial to gaining a quality job and ensuring career advancement. \n\nI was delighted to learn that the some of the young Cambodians that traveled to Singapore volunteered to serve as Digital Delegates during the workshop, using social media to give updates and respond to questions about YSEALI.  Talking about their experience and their plans upon returning home, one participant said: \n\nWith all the valuable skills I have acquired during this workshop, I am committed to bringing back skills to share with youth in my community.  For this reason, I have initiated a project to strengthen human capital in my home country by conducting a series of informal sharing sessions with youth who are in need of soft skills, as a preparation for those seeking improvement to reach their full potential in their career. \n\nUtilizing Facebook and the popular #YSEALI on Twitter, these stories are being shared with others in Cambodia and around the world.  Social media is clearly having a significant impact on the success of YSEALI, and I look forward to speaking with more of you about the efforts of these young people in 2015.  \n\nYSEALI is creating stronger links between rising leaders in Cambodia and their regional and U.S. counterparts working on matters of mutual interest.  Cambodia is among the top countries with applicants for the YSEALI Professional Fellows Program, which sends some of the best and brightest community leaders from ASEAN to the United States for one month to engage with experts in the fields of civic engagement, NGO management, economic empowerment, governance, legislative process, and environmental and natural resources management.  After a successful program in 2014, the number of applications for the spring 2015 program has tripled from the region, reaching new audiences by attracting more than half from outside the capital cities.   \n\nI would like to congratulate everyone for their hard work and commitment to YSEALI in its first year.  This initiative has created an amazing network of young people working together to address issues that are important to Cambodians and others in Southeast Asia.  I could not be more proud of the program, and I invite all between the ages of 18 and 35 to join this active and growing community.  To find out more about YSEALI and sign up for membership, please go to https://youngsoutheastasianleaders.state.gov/. \n\n#AmbTodd #Cambodia \n\nRead more entries from Ambassador Todd's blog here: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/",

    "2015-01-08T02:36:01+0000": {
        "eng": "Why Mentoring Matters\n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nHave you ever had a mentor or been a mentor to someone?  If you have, then you probably recognize the impact that mentoring can have on a person.  But if you think that you have never been a part of this kind of relationship, it might have to do with how you define mentoring.  So what exactly is mentoring?  There are many different ways to answer this question, but a basic definition is that a mentor is someone who works with others in a positive, constructive way so that both mentor and mentee have the potential to grow through the relationship.  Moreover, it is important to keep in mind that mentoring is not an event  it is a collaborative process.  Benjamin Franklin once said, Tell me and I forget, teach me and I may remember, involve me and I learn.  Open and honest interaction between mentor and mentee not only ensures trust; it also guarantees that both individuals will benefit from the relationship. \n\nI have been a mentor and been mentored my entire career.  One of my mentors along the way taught me two valuable lessons: you have to be able to take risks to grow, and it is fine to make mistakes as long as learn from them.  I also learned that you are never too old to grow and develop. Since I have been here in Cambodia, I have continued to be mentored by closely working with civil society.  I am very grateful for the knowledge and experiences that they have shared with me, and I sincerely believe that I am a better leader today because of their support and ideas.\n\nAs President Obama said in his 2014 proclamation that recognized January as National Mentoring Month in the United States, Mentors push our next generation to shape their ambitions, set a positive course, and achieve their boundless potential.  I believe that effective leaders always give back, especially to younger generations.  This is a driving force behind our work with the Ambassadors Youth Council (AYC).  Aside from advising me on the concerns of youth in Cambodia, AYC members serve as mentors to other Cambodians, helping people gain access to valuable work experiences, educational resources, and skill-building activities that will help improve their lives and the lives of others.\n\nWith approximately 70 percent of the population being under the age of 30, it is clear that Cambodias future would greatly benefit from mentoring.  Recognizing the value of youth, political parties have created programs for mentoring and information sharing, with both the Cambodian Peoples Party and the Cambodian National Rescue Party establishing their own youth councils.  A number of civil society groups in Cambodia have also developed initiatives that encourage mentoring as a means of empowering the next generation of leaders.  By embracing the role of the mentor, the leaders of today can help educate and inspire young Cambodians, improving their chances of securing better academic and professional opportunities in the future.\n\nMentoring can come in many forms.  For example, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) helps to ensure that midwives and other certified health providers in Cambodia learn life-saving skills and practices through training, coaching, and mentoring activities.  Development Innovations  another project funded by USAID  is also promoting mentoring to grow a community of innovators in Cambodia.  Through its Mentor Network, local and international mentors provide support for mentees with promising technology-based initiatives.  With the knowledge and experience gained from civil society, technology development, and social enterprise, these mentors assist others in creating solutions that make Cambodia a better place for everyone.\n\nLater this year, 250 young leaders from throughout the ASEAN region will be selected as YSEALI Professional Fellows, serving for five weeks in non-profit organizations and government offices in the United States.  Working directly with their American counterparts, the YSEALI Professional Fellows will enhance their practical expertise, leadership skills, and professional contacts in the fields of civic engagement, NGO management, governance, law, economics, and environmental and natural resources management.  When the young Cambodians participating in this program return home, they have the potential to become remarkable mentors for others seeking to address challenges and create new opportunities.  In fact, one of the most powerful aspects of YSEALI is that it serves as a natural conduit for mentoring.  This is one of the reasons why I am encouraged by the substantial number of youth in Cambodia getting involved with YSEALI.\n\nIs mentoring right for you?  Do you want to be a mentor or a mentee?  Please share your comments, follow us on social media, and go to our U.S. Embassy website for more information about these and other opportunities.\n\n#AmbTodd \n\nRead more entries from the Ambassador's blog here: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/", 
        "id": "79770243223_10152710951073224", 
        "kh": "–“”“”’’’––"
    },

        "kh": "សិស្សនិស្សិតអន្តរជាតិមានការភ្ញាក់ផ្អើលចំពោះភាពខុសគ្នារវាងថ្នាក់រៀននៅសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនិងថ្នាក់រៀននៅក្នុងប្រទេសដទៃជាច្រើនទៀត។សិស្សនិស្សិតអាចកំណត់ទំរង់លក្ខណៈនៃការសិក្សាអប់រំរបស់គេ។"

    "2015-01-09T10:12:40+0000": {
        "eng": "Friends International: Socially Responsible Business in Cambodia \n-From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nI recently spoke with members of my team at the U.S. Embassy about their visit to the Phnom Penh office of Friends International.  Some of my readers may already be familiar with this award-winning international NGO, which was established in Cambodia in 1994 and its local NGO known as Mith Samlanh (friends in English).  Today, Friends International works with young people and their families in four different continents.  Among the long list of innovative programs and activities that my team learned about and observed in practice was how Friends International utilizes a social business model to support youth development in Cambodia.  By offering vocational training, employment, and other means for generating income, their social businesses provides an opportunity for both the young people and the organization to receive high social and financial returns.  While empowering youth, Friends International is also helping them to become more actively involved in improving the lives of others in Cambodia.\n\nWhen Nobel Prize Laureate Professor Muhammad Yunus developed the social business model, he envisioned an enterprise that would be driven by more than just the goal of financial gain.  He once said, Business is a very beautiful mechanism to solve problems, but we never use it for that purpose. We only use it to make money.  It satisfies our selfish interest but not our collective interest.  The impact that the business has on people and their communities  not the amount of profit made in a given period  is what measures the success of a social business.  While financial profit may still be an objective, those funds are used to assist others, creating products and supporting programs that have a social purpose.  Here in Cambodia, more people are seeing the potential for the establishment and expansion of social business, and organizations like Friends International are sharing best practices that have begun to spread throughout the country. \n\nTo ensure the organizations sustainability, Friends International operates a wide range of income generating activities.  Here in Cambodia, they have restaurants, a beauty salon, and other training businesses that give students from their Vocational Training Center the chance to gain experience in real business environments.  Parents are also given instruction on how to start their own social businesses so that they can earn income and send their children to school instead of having them work on the streets.  These activities also help the organization generate profit, with the money being used to fund additional projects that benefit youth and their families.  In fact, Mith Samlanh is able to fund more than half of its own financial needs directly with the income that comes from these social business ventures.\n\nI have spoken before about the strong commitment that the U.S. Embassy has for individuals and organizations that support innovation, youth development, and economic empowerment in Cambodia.  We promote entrepreneurship not only as a means of expanding Cambodias middle class; socially responsible business can also play a valuable role in solving problems and advancing progress in the country.  While Friends International is a nongovernmental organization with a social purpose at the heart of its mission, the notion of social responsibility can be expanded throughout civil society and the business sector.  This is why Im especially proud of USAIDs support for this organization. From small and medium enterprises to large multinationals, more companies are emphasizing the importance of social responsible business practices in the economic development of Cambodia.  I would like to commend the efforts of organizations like Friends International, which is taking a lead role in helping others understand and utilize socially responsible business.  They serve as a remarkable example of how an innovative business model can be financially successful in Cambodia, all while having a positive social impact on the entire country.  \n\nDo you have ideas about socially responsible business practices in Cambodia?  If so, please share your comments.\n\n#AmbTodd \n\nRead more blog entries from Ambassador Todd here: http://blogs.usembassy.gov/todd/",

        "eng": "Global UGRAD Exchange Program 2015-2016\n\nDo you want to experience life on an American college campus?  The U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh is now accepting applications for the Global UGRAD program, which provides full scholarships for four Cambodian university students to spend a full semester at a U.S. university.  The program is open to all outstanding undergraduate students at least 18 years of age who have little to no experience outside of Cambodia with a focus on students from underrepresented sectors.  Global UGRAD students will study at accredited U.S. institutions of higher education, receive intensive English language instruction if needed, and engage in community service, professional development workshops, and cultural enrichment activities.         "id": "79770243223_10152727962143224",
