    "2015-08-07T10:31:50+0000": {
        "eng": "Staying the Course\n  - From the Ambassador's Penh\n\nAs I begin this final entry to my blog, I would first like to say thanks to all of the people of this great nation.  It has been both an honor and a privilege to spend these last three years serving as the U.S. Ambassador to the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia.  I especially appreciate all of the comments and questions that you have shared with me.  I think back to my very first blog entry in June 2012, when I stated that my top goal was to foster a more effective relationship between the people of the United States and Cambodia.  Today, I am proud to say that there has been significant progress made because of the contributions and dedication of civil society members.  Their efforts have encouraged a growing number of people to play an active role in the development of Cambodia.\n\nOver the course of more than three years in Cambodia, I have been fortunate to have met with and learned from several wonderful and dedicated individuals who are making a difference in the lives of the Cambodian people.  When I think about what has already been achieved and the challenges that lie ahead, the efforts of these men and women make me very hopeful.  Many of these individuals are a part of Cambodias vibrant civil society.  In fact, frequent readers of my blog know that I have often written about the amazing work of civil society and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), since much of Cambodias success in recent years  a growing economy, improvements in health care and schools, a greater focus on human rights, and more  is due in great part to the work of civil society leaders and organizations.\n\nMany readers of my blog would often ask me about my thoughts regarding the role of NGOs and civil society in Cambodia.  No matter if it is Cambodia, the United States, or any other nation  I firmly believe that when civil society is strong, the country is stronger.  I also think that any effort to restrict the freedoms of assembly and expression is not conducive towards a healthy and sustainable democracy.  With the Royal Government providing the space for NGOs to operate freely, civil society was able to make significant contributions to the electoral process and built voter confidence during the 2013 national elections.  It is my hope that government and civil society leaders will continue to work together to promote democracy, protect human rights, and bring prosperity to all citizens of Cambodia.\n\nHistory shows that government alone cannot deliver social and economic progress that is broad-based and sustainable.  A thriving civil society is needed to empower citizens, to find innovative solutions to challenges, and to hold government leaders accountable.  Furthermore, when there is limited government funding for public services, civil society helps to fill important gaps, especially for people living in under-served communities.  Here in Cambodia, there have already been many achievements in the areas of health, nutrition, education, environmental protection, and community development due to the efforts of the NGO community.  With the sustained presence of effective programs and partnerships with civil society, there is potential to help Cambodia reach even greater heights.\n\nNot long after arriving to Cambodia, I invited a number of representatives from civil society to be a part of my NGO Advisory Council.  The Council proved to be an effective avenue for engaging with Cambodian civil society directly on a wide range of important topics, including the role that U.S. government programs and policies play in addressing some of the leading challenges in Cambodia.  I would like to thank all of the members of the NGO Advisory Council for providing me with your expertise and advice these past three years.  We have had some excellent and very frank discussions together, which has helped me and my U.S. Embassy team to strengthen the relationship between the United States and Cambodia. \n\nIn the United States, many people use the expression staying the course, which means to pursue a goal regardless of time, obstacles, or criticism.  As Cambodia moves forward, I encourage members of civil society to stay the course and continue improving the quality of life for the Cambodian people.  By working together with the Royal Government, the private sector, and other partners found in the region and around the world, Cambodias civil society will continue to help lead the country towards achieving all of its development goals.\n\nI want to again thank everyone for your support during my time in Cambodia.  I look forward to hearing about even greater success in the future.  May God bless each of you and your families, may God bless the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia, and may God bless the United States of America.\n\n#AmbTodd #Cambodia\n\nTo read more entries from Ambassador Todd's blog - in English and Khmer - please go to blogs.usembassy.gov/todd.", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153157100063224", 
        "kh": "’’–––“”’"
    },

    "2015-08-11T06:37:20+0000": {
        "eng": "  John Kerry    ,              (English) go.usa.gov/3s923 \n\nU.S. Secretary of State John Kerry recently announced the U.S. Agency for International Development's Oceans and Fisheries Partnership (USAID Oceans) project, committing $4.3 million to combat illegal, unreported, and unregulated fishing and seafood fraud in the Asia-Pacific region.  As many people in Cambodia and ASEAN depend on resources that the ocean and surrounding waterways provide, the project will support better sustainable aquaculture management and maritime security.         "eng": "Do you ever wonder what Cambodia and its neighbors in the Lower Mekong region look like...from space?  \n\nThis week, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) and the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) launched SERVIR-Mekong, a project to promote the use of satellite imagery to help the Lower Mekong region better predict and cope with floods and other natural disasters, as well as increase resilience to the negative effects of climate change.     "2015-09-03T07:02:45+0000": {
        "eng": "   Julie Chung                (NAMRU-2)          \n\nDuring a recent trip to Koh Kong and Sihanoukville Provinces, U.S. Embassy Charg de affaires Julie Chung observed how the U.S. Navy is working with its Cambodian partners to address issues with maritime security in the region.  She visited the Royal Cambodian Navys Ream Naval Base, where the United States previously donated six rigid-hull inflatable boats and is currently assisting with the repair and renovation of the naval bases pier.  Also, with assistance from the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 Detachment (NAMRU-2), a brand new medical laboratory is now operating at the naval base, providing a significant upgrade in the quality of medical care for 3,000 service members and dependents as well as an additional 25,000 people living in surrounding communities.",

        "eng": "Feed the Future  the U.S. Governments global hunger and food security initiative  is providing support to Cambodian horticulture farmers working together in producer groups to coordinate on vegetable production, build relationships with traders, and receive bulk discounts on purchases.         "eng": "September 15 is the United Nations' International Day of Democracy and this years theme is \"Space for Civil Society.\"  One example of how the United States supports civil society in Cambodia and the region is through initiatives like the USAID-funded GREEN Mekong (Grassroots Equity and Enhanced Networks in Mekong) Program.         "eng": "The Office of Defense Cooperation (ODC) at the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia is pleased to invite young Cambodians to compete for appointment to the United States Service Academies for the Class of 2020.\n\nAn information brief on the appointment process will be conducted on Wednesday, October 7 at 2:00 p.m. at Passtra University of Cambodia, South Campus, No. 184, Norodom Boulevard (South of Independent Monument).  For directions you can contact (eduUSA@puc.edu.kh or 015 563 235).  \n\nInterested applicants must: \n* Be unmarried and within 17-22 years old. \n* Have strong English proficiency.  \n* Earn competitive scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) or the American College Test (ACT).\n* Earn competitive scores on an Embassy-administered Candidate Fitness Assessment (CFA). You can learn about each part of the CFA with this YouTube video:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AlIZz9O7QiQ. \n* Have a medical exam showing they are free of communicable diseases or major health problems. \n* Perform well in an individual interview process administered by the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh in cooperation with the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces.\n\nTo help assess and prepare applicants for the scholastic and fitness tests, the ODC has scheduled practice tests at the U.S. Embassy.  If you meet the eligibility requirements listed above, contact the ODC at ODCCambodia@state.gov with your name, age, and contact information to reserve a place.    \n\nImportant dates:  \n* October 15 at 2:00 pm  Practice SAT at the U.S. Embassy \n* October 16 at 6:00 am  Practice CFA at the U.S. Embassy\n* October 22 at 2:00 pm  Practice SAT at the U.S. Embassy\n* October 29 at 2:00 pm  Practice SAT at the U.S. Embassy\n* October 30 at 6:00 am  Practice CFA at the U.S. Embassy\n* November 1- Deadline for interested applicants to have completed at least one practice  SAT and one practice CFA.  Scores on these tests will be used to determine which  candidates are competitive enough to continue in the selection process.\n* November and December  Competitive applicants will have individual interviews with members of the U.S. military and the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces.  \n\nFor more information, visit the U.S. Embassy web site at   http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/the_united_states_service_academies.html",

        "eng": "Do you work to create safe spaces for women and girls in your community?  Do you advocate for clean energy, green schools, or banning plastic bags?  Do you work with youth to build more peaceful communities?  If so, you might be a Community Solutions Leader!\n\nThe 2016 Community Solutions Program Application is officially open!!!  \n\nWe are looking for the best and brightest community leaders working in Transparency and Accountability, Environmental Issues, Tolerance and Conflict Resolution, and Women and Gender Issues.  The program is open to Cambodians between the ages of 25-38 who have at least two years of experience working on a community project or initiative.  Proficiency in spoken and written English is required.\n\nThe Community Solutions Program is a U.S. Department of State exchange program that helps leaders from Cambodia and around the world to strengthen their capacity for leadership and development in their home countries. Selected candidates will participate in: (1) a four-month U.S. fellowship with a local non-profit organization or government agency; (2) structured virtual learning and networking via the Online Community Leadership Institute; and (3) the design and implementation of follow-on projects in their home countries.\n\nThe application deadline is Friday, October 30, 2015.  For information on how to apply; please visit: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/community_solutions_program.html\n\nIf you have any questions about this opportunity please contact the U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh Public Affairs Section at NornS@state.gov",

    "2015-10-07T07:17:47+0000": {
        "eng": "Cambodians around the world are justifiably proud of their extraordinary cultural heritage.  The Temples of Angkor were recently selected by the travel company Lonely Planet for the number one spot on its Ultimate Travel List 2015.  \n\nThe U.S. Government has been supporting restoration work at the Phnom Bakheng temple in the Angkor Archaeological Park since 2004, largely through the State Department Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation.  To date the U.S. government has provided nearly $3 million to protect and preserve this incredible monument for future generations, including a new $450,000 grant announced in July.  The delicate and difficult work to preserve Phnom Bakheng is being conducted by the World Monuments Fund in close coordination with the APSARA Authority.\n\nBut there is much more to the work at Phnom Bakheng than just restoring the temple.  With financial support from the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh, the World Monuments Fund has produced three videos to tell some of these stories.  Check out this video entitled The Villagers to learn more about the people who work and live near Phnom Bakheng.  \n\nPlease check back on Thursday and Friday for two more videos!\n\n      Lonely Planet  Ultimate Travel   \n\n     (The State Department Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation)    ,\n \n\n    World Monuments        \n\n     !\n\nhttps://vimeo.com/140796495 \n\nWorld Monuments Fund   Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation  #AFCP",

    "2015-10-19T03:03:02+0000": {
        "eng": "Cambodian architect Pen Sereypagna manages the Vann Molyvann Project, which is documenting the work of the great architect Vann Molyvann so that it is preserved for future generations.\n\nRight now, Pagna is a full-time research intern at the East-West Center in Hawaii as part of the US/ICOMOS International Exchange Program.  (US/ICOMOS stands for the U.S. National Committee of the International Council on Monuments and Sites  a non-governmental organization.)  During his internship, Pagna will receive hands-on training that he will use to preserve Cambodias architectural heritage amid the pressures of globalization and rapid urban development.  Pagnas program is supported in part by the U.S. Embassy.\n\nFor more on the Vann Molyvann Project, see: http://www.vannmolyvannproject.org/the-project",

    "2015-10-19T09:34:38+0000": {
        "eng": "Ambassador William Heidt and Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung met today with Youk Chhang, director of the Documentation Center of Cambodia (DC-Cam), which works tirelessly to document Khmer Rouge atrocities while helping Cambodians reconcile with their past and move towards a brighter future.\n\nOriginally started in 1995 as an initiative of the Cambodian Genocide Program at Yale University, DC-Cam has established itself as a leading research center on the Cambodian genocide.  With the worlds largest repository of printed documents and other original documentary materials related to the Khmer Rouge era, DC-Cam contributeds to a number of research projects, education and outreach programs, and legal cases against former Khmer Rouge leaders.  Most importantly, DC-Cams efforts honors the victims and protects the lessons of history for future generations.  \n\nThe U.S. government is proud to support DC-Cams work, including through a $4 million endowment from the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) as well as a 2015 USAID program to document and publicize records of the Khmer Rouge regime.\n\nOn October 12, DC-Cam hosted a special ceremony to bless urns that were recently discovered at Wat Langka.  The U.S. Navy Seabees (the Navy Mobile Construction Battalion) based in Cambodia constructed the shelving for the urns.  Visit this link for more on the Wat Lagka ceremony: https://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/urns-found-at-wat-langka-receive-blessings-97141/.  \n\nTo learn more about DC-Cam please see:\nhttp://www.dccam.org/\n\n  William Heidt   Julie Chung    (DC-Cam)      \n\n    Yale                    \n\n    $   (USAID)  USAID   \n\n      Seabees \n\n link   : https://www.cambodiadaily.com/news/urns-found-at-wat-langka-receive-blessings-97141/ \n\n : http://www.dccam.org/",

Government programs like USAID's Feed the Future help them by drawing on the latest innovations including improved plant breeding techniques, knowledge of behavior change, and enhanced information about pests and diseases.\n\nThe private sector also plays an important role in ensuring a healthy planet.         "eng": "First Lady Michelle Obama talks about her experience meeting a Cambodian student.  (English below)\n\n   Fortune      \n\n    \n\n \n\n         --  \"      \"\n\nAt the Fortunes 50 Most Powerful Women Summit last week in Washington, First Lady Michelle Obama told the story of a very special Cambodian girl who is trying to overcome hardships to pursue her dream of becoming a math teacher.  Mrs. Obama met this Cambodian student on her historic visit to Cambodia in March.\n\nIn her speech, the First Lady said:\n\nShe stood up in front of me, the First Lady of Cambodia, and dozens of international reporters and camera crews, and let me tell you, she spoke so eloquently about her life.  She was poised and confident.  And this is what she told us.  She said -- and these are her words -- she said, I have been through a lot of hardships.  I know that I need to overcome them.  She said, Ive never thought that they are the barrier to stop me.  Ive never thought of giving up, she said.  I never lose hope in myself.\n\nWatch the video of Mrs. Obamas remarks at:\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-dNrObuUlgo&t=941, or read the transcript of the speech at: https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/10/13/remarks-first-lady-fortunes-50-most-powerful-women-summit",

    "2015-11-09T06:24:17+0000": {
        "eng": "On November 6, Cambodia marked National Nutrition Day in a ceremony at the Wat Botum Park to raise awareness about the importance of breastfeeding for the health of children.  Cambodia has made considerable progress fighting childhood malnutrition, reducing stunting among children under five by 36 percent since 2000.  This progress is impressive, but one-third of Cambodian children under five are still stunted and one fourth continue to be underweight, so there is still more work to be done.  Breastfeeding is a critical way for children to get a great start in life.  Breast milk provides babies with all the essential nutrients they need, is uncontaminated, provides important immune protection against disease, and is free.  \n\nThe U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) was a proud sponsor and organizer of this years National Nutrition Day event, along with the Council for Agricultural and Rural Development (CARD) together with the Ministry of Health, UNICEF, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, and the Civil Society Network of Cambodian SUN Movement.\n\n(Photo Credit: UNICEF Cambodia)", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153336496138224", 
        "kh": "’"
    },

        "eng": "Mu Sochua Honored by San Francisco State University (English below)\n\n        San Francisco State University    San Francisco  California  \n\n    San Francisco State University                \n\n   !\n\n     :  \nhttp://news.sfsu.edu/news-story/outstanding-alumni-be-honored-hall-fame-event\n\n         \n\nOn November 6, Cambodian Member of Parliament Mu Sochua was recognized as one of San Francisco State Universitys alumnae of the year in a ceremony in San Francisco, California.  According to the university:\n\nThe Honorable Mu Sochua, who graduated from SF State in 1979 with a B.A. in psychology, will also receive recognition as one of the alumnae of the year.  Sochua is a member of the Cambodian parliament and was formerly that country's minister for women's affairs.  As a political activist, Sochua has worked tirelessly to improve conditions for women in Cambodia by taking on issues including domestic violence, the spread of HIV/AIDS and abuse toward minors.\n\nCongratulations to Mu Sochua on this outstanding accomplishment!\n\nRead more about Mu Sochuas award here:  http://news.sfsu.edu/news-story/outstanding-alumni-be-honored-hall-fame-event \n\nThanks to the hard work of Cambodians both in and out of government, Cambodia has made tremendous progress in the last 15 years in reducing poverty, increasing levels of secondary education of girls, lowering child and maternal mortality rates, and improving rural livelihoods.",

        "eng": "\"When we talk about climate change, were not just talking about the harm that is caused to the habitat for butterflies or polar bears  as some people try to mock it  as serious as those effects might be.\n\nWe are talking about the impacts on people  people everywhere  of severe droughts, rapid sea level rise.\n\nWere talking about the impacts on whole cities of unpredictable and uncontrollable extreme weather events.\n\nWere talking about the impact on entire countries of fundamental shocks to the global agricultural system...And the prospect of a hotter, drier climate throughout the Middle East and parts of Asia will place even more strain on the most precious and essential resource of all  fresh water.\n\nWeve already seen tensions rise around the basins of the Nile River in Africa, the Indus River in South Asia, and of course, the Mekong River in Southeast Asia.\" - Secretary of State John Kerry\n \nTo read the full remarks on Climate Change and National Security, visit: http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2015/11/249393.htm\n \n(Photo: Cambodia HARVEST)",

The timing of these charges gives the appearance of undue political influence in the judicial process. More broadly, the pattern of actions against the opposition suggests a return to the harsh political practices and tactics of the  that the Cambodian people have made clear they no longer want.         "eng": "Official Statement - State Department\nFurther Deterioration of Cambodias Democratic Environment (English below)\n  \n\n    (CNRP)                     \n               \n       -\nhttp://khmer.cambodia.usembassy.gov/111615_pr.html\n\nWe are deeply concerned by todays removal of Cambodian National Rescue Party (CNRP) leader Sam Rainsy from the National Assembly in a unilateral move by the ruling Cambodian Peoples Party.  We call on the National Assembly to reinstate him immediately and to restore his parliamentary immunity.  We also call on the government to revoke the arrest warrant issued against Rainsy on seven-year-old defamation charges and to allow him and other opposition Parliamentarians to return to Cambodia without fear of arrest or persecution.  \n\nTodays actions are the latest incidents of harassment and intimidation of Cambodias opposition, including the recent violent attacks against two opposition Members of Parliament and the removal of opposition party deputy leader Kem Sokha from his position as First Vice President of the National Assembly.  These developments are harmful to Cambodian democracy and contrary to the wishes of the Cambodian people.\n\nWe urge the government to take immediate steps to guarantee a political space free from threats or intimidation in Cambodia, and for the government and opposition to engage in serious and meaningful dialogue on actions to strengthen Cambodias democratic future.\nhttp://cambodia.usembassy.gov/pr_en111615.html",

        "eng": "  William Heidt        \n\n      \n\n Heidt          \n\n Heidt                \n\nAmbassador William Heidt presented his credentials as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the United States of America to the Kingdom of Cambodia to Samdech Vibol Sena Pheakdey Say Chhum, Acting Head of State and President of Cambodian Senate, on Wednesday morning, December 2, 2015, during a ceremony at the Senate in Phnom Penh.     "2015-12-03T06:09:48+0000": {
        "eng": "Today is the International Day of Persons with Disabilities, which promotes awareness and mobilizes support for the inclusion of persons with disabilities in society.\n\nIn Cambodia, there are an estimated 700,000 persons who are disabled and many of them face physical, social, and economic barriers that prevent them from realizing their potential and playing a greater role in their communities.  Earlier this year, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) launched the Rehabilitation and Prosthetics Program for Persons with Disabilities in Cambodia.  The program will allow Veterans International Cambodia (VIC) to continue to provide rehabilitation and prosthetic services for persons with disabilities.\n\nJudith Heumann, Special Advisor for International Disability Rights at the Department of State said, The United States is committed to inclusion and to empowering people with disabilities to stand up for their rights and to oppose discrimination in all of its forms.  You can learn more about Special Advisor Heumanns work to promote the rights of the 1 billion people worldwide who live with a disability here:  https://share.america.gov/what-makes-successful-civil-rights-advocate/\n\nPhoto caption: Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung, H.E. Sem Sokha, Secretary of State at the Ministry of Social Affairs, Veterans and Youth Rehabilitation, VIC Country Director Keo Rithy, and other guests at the official launch of VICs Rehabilitation and Prosthetics Program.",

    "2015-12-10T13:27:59+0000": {
        "eng": "AMBASSADOR HEIDT'S STATEMENT ON HUMAN RIGHTS DAY\nDecember 10, 2015 \n\nEveryone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers.\" - Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights\n\nThe United States stands with the people of #Cambodia and billions of others around the world in celebration of Human Rights Day. This years theme highlights four freedoms  freedom of speech, of religion, from want, and from fear  which underlie the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. While there has been significant progress in advancing these and other fundamental freedoms in Cambodia, more needs to be done in order to safeguard these liberties for all citizens.\n \nWhen reflecting on the true meaning of freedom  particularly the freedom of speech  I recall a famous quote: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.\" Freedom of expression is not only guaranteed under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights; it is also a vital element of the Constitution of the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia. Therefore, I encourage all Cambodians  members of the Royal Government, civil society, and everyday citizens  to work together to ensure that the countrys laws, the media, and the Internet are devices utilized to protect the freedom of expression.\n \nThe United States is deeply committed to the protection of the basic freedoms enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.  As President Obama notes, Protecting human rights around the globe extends the promise of democracy and bolsters the values that serve as a basis for peace in our world.  As U.S. Ambassador to the Royal Kingdom of Cambodia, I am proud to support the Cambodian people as the country continues to develop a strong and enduring democracy that fully promotes and protects human rights.  The U.S. Embassy remains committed to our partnerships with all sectors of Cambodian society to promote freedom and democracy  not only on #HumanRightsDay, but every day.\n\n#AmbHeidt\n#HumanRights",

    "2016-01-01T02:02:28+0000": {
        "eng": "Making the Worlds Knowledge Computable\n\nOn December 30, Ambassador Heidt and Minister of Education Hang Chuon Naron were on hand for a lecture at RUPP by world-famous scientist and entrepreneur Dr. Stephen Wolfram entitled The Future of Computation and Knowledge.  \n\nDr. Wolfram is the founder and CEO of software company Wolfram Research, based in the United States, and the creator of the Wolfram Language, which powers the free answer engine Wolfram Alpha.  The talk was organized by the Ministry of Education, Youth, and Sports; the U.S. Embassy; the Cambodia Science & Engineering Festival; and the Cambodian Mathematical Society.\n\nAs Dr. Wolfram explained, unlike traditional search engines Wolfram Alpha doesnt search the web for answers; it answers factual questions by computing answers.  During the presentation, Dr. Wolfram demonstrated this by entering a series of mathematical and other questions, including How many chickens in Cambodia?.  Below is Wolfram Alphas answer to that question, based on the best available data.  This graph didnt exist before Dr. Wolfram asked the question.  Rather, Wolfram Alpha created it, using the information in its database.\n\nIn his introduction, Ambassador Heidt talked about the role of science, technology, and innovation in the American economy and challenged Cambodian youth to harness technology to build an innovation society.  You can read his remarks here: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/123015_sp.html\n\nDr. Wolframs talk will be available on video soon in its entirety.  Check back for details.",

        "eng": " \"\"                    OneBeat  \n\n \"\"         !\n\nCheck out \"'Tis Minnesota\" - the latest music video by Cambodian composer, singer, and musician Young Yorn! Born in Kampong Thom, Yorn plays traditional Khmer music and has been involved with the arts in Cambodia for more than ten years, working with organizations like the Department of Fine Arts & Culture in Phnom Penh and the Apsara Arts Association. He is also an alumnus of the U.S. Department of State's OneBeat Program, which brings together musical leaders from around the world to develop a global network of civically engaged music initiatives.\n\nIn \"'Tis Minnesota,\" Yorn sings about his experience visiting the U.S. state of Minnesota. He has also composed music about his time in Florida and New York. Today, Yorn continues to share his music with the world, performing in many festivals in Cambodia, the United States, and beyond.         "kh": "សូមអញ្ជើញទស្សនាបទអនុស្សាវរីយ៍មីនីសូតាដែលជាចំរៀងវីដេអូចុងក្រោយបង្អស់របស់លោកយឹងយនដែលជាកវីនិពន្ធអ្នកចំរៀងនិងជាតន្ត្រីករកម្ពុជា។មានស្រុកកំណើតនៅក្នុងខេត្តកំពង់ធំលោកយនលេងតន្ត្រីបុរាណខ្មែរនិងបានធើ្វការក្នុងវិស័យសិល្បៈក្នុងប្រទេសកម្ពុជាអស់រយៈពេលជាងដប់ឆ្នាំមកហើយដោយធើ្វការជាមួយនាយកដ្ឋានវប្បធម៌និងវិចិត្រសិល្បៈក្នុងរាជធានីភ្នំពេញនិងសមាគមសិល្បៈអប្សរា។លោកក៏ជាអតីតនិស្សិតដែលទទួលបានអាហារូបករណ៍សិក្សានៅសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកក្នុងកម្មវិធីមួយដែលមានឈ្មោះថា។កម្មវិធីនេះឧបត្ថម្ភដោយក្រសួងការបរទេសអាមេរិក។កម្មវិធីនេះនាំមកនូវមេដឹកនាំតន្រ្តីមកពីជុំវិញពិភពលោកដើម្បីបង្កើតនូវបណ្តាញពិភពលោកមួយសំរាប់គំនិតផ្តួចផ្តើមតន្រ្តីនានាដែលមានការចូលរួមពីប្រជាពលរដ្ឋ។នៅក្នុងចំរៀងវីដេអូអនុស្សាវរីយ៍មីនីសូតានេះយនច្រៀងរាយរាប់អំពីបទពិសោធន៍របស់គាត់ដែលបានមកទស្សនារដ្ឋមីនីសូតា។គាត់ក៏បាននិពន្ធបទចម្រៀងអំពីពេលវេលារបស់គាត់នៅក្នុងរដ្ឋផ្លរីដានិងញូវយ៉កផងដែរ។សព្វថ្ងៃនេះយនបានបន្តចែកចាយចំរៀងរបស់គាត់ជាមួយពិភពលោកតាមរយៈការសម្តែងនៅក្នុងពិធីបុណ្យជាច្រើននៅក្នុងប្រទេសកម្ពុជាសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនិងប្រទេសផ្សេងៗទៀត។សូមអបអរសាទរយន"

    "2016-01-05T10:46:08+0000": {
        "eng": "Cambodian engineers are part of a special team from Golden West Humanitarian Foundation (GWHF) that created the Advanced Ordnance Training Materials (AOTM) Program, which has been named as an Innovation Awards Honoree at the prestigious International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas - better known as CES 2016. Selected in the \"Tech For A Better World\" category, AOTM products are manufactured in Phnom Penh in GWHF's Design Lab, Cambodias largest 3D-printing facility. \n\nWith startup funding from the U.S. Department of State, the AOTM program improves the quality of materials available to humanitarian mine clearance and unexploded ordnance disposal personnel in Cambodia and around the world. \"Winning this major international award is an honor we share with the people of Cambodia and recognizes the global impact Cambodian-created products can have,\" noted Allen Tan, Director of Applied Technology at GWHF.\n\n#Cambodia\n\n Golden West (GWHF)  (AOTM)   (Innovation Awards Honoree)   Las Vegas  CES 2016   AOTM   GWHF  3D \n\n   AOTM      Allen Tan  GWHF   \n\nPhoto Credit: Golden West Humanitarian Foundation Design Lab",

        "eng": "U.S. Embassy Statement on Victory Day\nJanuary 7, 2016\n\n   \n\nCambodias Victory Day on January 7 marks the liberation of Phnom Penh from the Khmer Rouge, one of the most unambiguously evil regimes in history.  Victory over the Khmer Rouge is a victory shared by all Cambodians.  Today, we wish to express our grief for the loss of nearly two million lives and the disruption of so many others.  As friends of the Cambodian people, our strong wish is that Cambodians of all creeds continue to work together to build a more democratic and prosperous future.\n\n                 \n\n#Cambodia",

    "2016-01-08T09:11:38+0000": {
        "eng": "Say hello and congrats to Dr. Nary Ly, who was nominated this week by the National Olympic Committee of Cambodia to represent the Kingdom at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil! Recognized as the most outstanding and active female Cambodian marathon runner, she finished the 2015 Valencia Marathon in Spain in an amazing 2 hours, 59 minutes and 12 seconds.  If Nary would have competed in the 2015 SEA Games in Singapore, she could have won the gold for Cambodia with that time!\n \nAlong with her athletic skill, Dr. Nary has an extensive background in science and research.  Formerly a research scientist with the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 Detachment in Phnom Penh, she completed her post-doctorate studies at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York.  Today, Dr. Nary is an instructor at the University of Health Sciences-Cambodia.\n \nIn order to make her Olympic dreams come true, Nary will need financial and moral support as she continues to train to become the first-ever Cambodian woman to compete in the marathon event.  Do you want to find out more about her story and how you can help?  Please visit Narys Facebook page at www.facebook.com/narylyrunning/.\n\nThe U.S. Embassy commends Dr. Nary for her hard work and dedication, as well as her focus on being a role model for others.  Nary hopes her journey will inspire the Cambodian young generation for excellence in academics and sport, and at the same time having a healthy lifestyle!  Stay tuned for more about Dr. Narys path to the Olympics in the coming months\n\n         Rio de Janeiro !         Valencia                !\n\n     Unit-2     Mount Sinai School of Medicine  New York   \n\n     ()  ?         "kh": "“”’“”’…សូមអបអរសាទរចំពោះបណ្ឌិតលីណារីដែលត្រូវបានតែងតាំងនៅសប្តាហ៍នេះដោយគណកម្មាធិការជាតិអូឡាំពិកកម្ពុជាអោយធ្វើជាតំណាងព្រះរាជាណាចក្រកម្ពុជានៅក្នុងការប្រកូតកីឡាអំឡាំពិកឆ្នាំ២០១៦នៅទីក្រុងនៅប្រទេសប្រេស៊ីលដោយត្រូវបានទទួលស្គាល់ថាជា”អ្នករត់ប្រណាំងម៉ារ៉ាតុងកម្ពុជាដែលមានភាពលេចធ្លោនិងសកម្មជាងគេ”លោកស្រីបានរត់ម៉ារ៉ាតុងដល់ទីនៅក្នុងការប្រកួតឆ្នាំ២០១៥នៅទីក្រុងនៃប្រទេសអេស្បាញក្នុងថេរវេលាដ៏គួរអោយសរសើរគឺ២ម៉ោង៥៩នាទីនិង១២វិនាទី។បើលោកស្រីណារីបានប្រកួតនៅក្នុងកីឡាស៊ីហ្កេមឆ្នាំ២០១៥នៅប្រទេសសឹង្ហបូរីលោកស្រីអាចទទួលបានរង្វាន់មេដាយមាសអោយប្រទេសកម្ពុជាក្នុងថេរវេលានេះក្រៅពីជំនាញផ្នែកកីឡាបណ្ឌិតណារីមានប្រវត្តិច្រើនក្នុងផ្នែកវិទ្យាសាស្រ្តនិងការស្រាវជ្រាវ។ដោយធ្លាប់ធ្វើជាអ្នកវិទ្យាសាស្រ្តស្រាវជ្រាវជាមួយអង្គភាពផ្នែកស្រាវជ្រាវវេជ្ជសាស្រ្តរបស់កងទ័ពជើងទឹកសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនៅភ្នំពេញលោកស្រីបានបញ្ចប់ការសិក្សាថ្នាក់ក្រោយបណ្ឌិតនៅសាលាពេទ្យនៅរដ្ឋ។សព្វថ្ងៃនេះលោកស្រីគឺជាគ្រូបង្រៀននៅសាកលវិទ្យាល័យវិទ្យាសាស្រ្តសុខាភិបាលកម្ពុជា។ដើម្បីធ្វើអោយក្តីសុបិនរបស់លោកស្រីក្នុងការបានចូលរួមក្នុងកីឡាអូឡាំពិកក្លាយជាការពិតលោកស្រីណារីត្រូវការការគាំទ្រផ្នែកថវិកានិងស្មារតីក្នុងពេលដែលលោកស្រីបន្តហ្វឹកហាត់ដើម្បីក្លាយជានារីកម្ពុជាដំបូងគេបង្អស់ដែលបានចូលរួមប្រកួតនៅក្នុងព្រឹត្តិការណ៍កីឡារត់ម៉ារ៉ាតុងរត់ចំងាយ។តើលោកអ្នកចង់ដឹងបន្ថែមទៀតអំពីលោកស្រីនិងវិធីដែលលោកអ្នកអាចជួយគាត់បានដែរឬទេសូមចូលមើលទំព័ររបស់គាត់តាម។ស្ថានទូតសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកសូមសរសើរបណ្ឌិតណារីដែលមានការខិតខំនិងយកចិត្តទុកដាក់ខ្ពស់ព្រមទាំងការផ្តោតរបស់លោកស្រីដែលចង់ធ្វើជាគំរូសំរាប់អ្នកដទៃទៀត។គាត់សង្ឃឹមថាដំណើររបស់គាត់នឹង“បំផុសទឹកចិត្តដល់មនុស្សជំនាន់ក្រោយនៅកម្ពុជាដោយភាពលេចធ្លោនៅក្នុងការសិក្សានិងកីឡាដោយទន្ទឹមនឹងនោះរស់នៅប្រកបដោយការចេះធ្វើអោយសុខភាពបានល្អ”សូមតាមដានបន្តដើម្បីដឹងព័ត៌មានបន្ថែមស្តីពីដំណើររបស់បណ្ឌិតណារីទៅកាន់ការប្រកួតកីឡាអូឡាំពិកនៅក្នុងពេលប៉ុន្មានខែខាងមុខនេះ…"

        "eng": "  Heidt               HARVEST  NOURISH         CARD   \n\nToday, Ambassador Heidt met with H.E. Dr. Yim Chhay Ly - Deputy Prime Minister and Chairman of the Council for Agricultural and Rural Development (CARD) - to congratulate the people of Cambodia for improvements in the areas of nutrition and health. During the meeting, the Deputy Prime Minister expressed his appreciation for the work of U.S. government projects such as USAID's HARVEST and NOURISH, while noting the importance of focusing on youth and education as a way to better Cambodia's future. The Ambassador also highlighted wildlife trade as a possible area for cooperation in the future and looks forward to hearing from CARD on how the United States and Cambodia can work together on this important issue.\n\n#AmbHeidt #Cambodia",

        "eng": "  Jakarta \n John Kirby \n Washington\n    \n              Jakarta     \n                 Kerry      \n               \n\nPress Statement on the Terrorist Attack in Jakarta, Indonesia\nJohn Kirby\nSpokesperson, Bureau of Public Affairs\nWashington, DC\nJanuary 14, 2016\n\nThe United States strongly condemns todays terrorist attack in Jakarta. We extend our condolences to the families of those killed, and we wish a quick and full recovery to those injured.\n\nWe stand firmly with the Indonesian people against terrorism and extremist ideologies that give rise to terrorist violence. As Secretary Kerry said this morning in London, we join international condemnation of this attack, and acts of terror are not going to intimidate nation-states. [W]e stand together, all of us, united in our efforts to eliminate those who choose terror.\n\nWe will continue working with our Indonesian partners and others around the world to combat these shared threats.",

        "eng": "Ambassador's Wife Visits Hometown \n\nOn January 13, Ambassador Heidt accompanied his wife Sotie on a trip to her hometown Krakor, in Pursat province.  This was her first visit to the area since the fall of the Khmer Rouge regime in 1979.  Soties sister and brother in law, Polly Ken and Soukchai Ly, also joined the trip.\n\nIt's a trip that I felt I had to make, Sotie said.  Standing at the site of my childhood home, I was overwhelmed by memories of when our family was still together.  The only thing remaining from the past was an old, dried-up well that has been sitting there silently witnessing history.  It was an emotional day, but meeting Krakor residents who knew us from back then made the trip and my connection to Krakor all that much more special.\"\n\nI was very moved by the warm welcome the people of Krakor gave us, Ambassador Heidt said.   It was the first time Ive seen where my wife and her sister grew up, and I learned a lot about Cambodias history as well as its exciting potential.\" \n\nTo see more pictures from their trip to Krakor, please visit https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/albums/72157663417021292.\n\n#AmbHeidt #Cambodia",

I also met with the acting head of the opposition, Kem Sokha. And just now, a few minutes ago, I was able to spend some time with members of Cambodian civil society, young people who are working so vigorously on land reform, on environment, on sustainable energy, on accountability, deforestation challenges. And in every meeting, in every meeting, I made clear that we are committed  we, the United States of America, are committed to the relationship between our country and Cambodia and we are committed to building on the progress that we have already made in education, health, cultural preservation.\" - U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry \n\nSee Secretary Kerry's press statement from today's historic visit to #Cambodia in full via the U.S. Department of State website: http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2016/01/251694.htm.",

        "eng": "  (Community Innovation Center)  Oxfam                Facebook           http://www.oxfamamerica.org/explore/stories/bridging-the-digital-divide-in-cambodia/\n\nCambodian farmers are gaining access the Internet thanks to the new Community Innovation Centers that Oxfam America/Oxfam in Cambodia and their local partner organizations have opened in Pursat and Takeo Provinces. The centers provide computer classes and help farmers exchange stories, photos and videos about agricultural products with others both domestically and globally. I especially want to use Facebook to promote my product - the rice seeds that I produce in Sareng village - so I wont necessarily have to go from village to village to advertise the product, said local farmer Oun Noun. The goal is to have at least one of the centers in every province in #Cambodia.     "2016-02-01T10:00:01+0000": {
        "eng": "On this first day of #BlackHistoryMonth, we honor astronaut, physician, educator & entrepreneur Dr. Mae Jemison. On September 12, 1992, Dr. Jemison became the first African American woman to travel in space when she went into orbit as a crew member on NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Space Shuttle Endeavour. Prior to this historic feat, she was also a Peace Corps Medical Officer and volunteered in a Cambodian refugee camp in Thailand. Today, Dr. Jemison is a worldwide respected leader and voice in the fields such as space exploration, sustainability, and #STEM - science, technology, engineering and mathematics education.\n\nEvery February, the United States celebrates the heritage of African Americans and their contributions to the world. The U.S. experience shows that diversity and social inclusion are valuable goals that all societies can pursue. To find out more about Black History Month, visit http://www.africanamericanhistorymonth.gov/.  \n\n(Photo Credit: NASA)\n\n (#BlackHistoryMonth)  Mae Jemison           Jemison        Endeavour  NASA    Peace Corps     Jemison        \n\n         http://www.africanamericanhistorymonth.gov/ ",

        "kh": "នៅពេលលោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតដើរមើលកន្លែងច្រកដបរបស់រោងចក្រនៃក្រុមហ៊ុនកូកាកូឡានៅភ្នំពេញលោកបានជួបនឹងនិយោជិតស្រីមួយចំនួន។ក្រុមហ៊ុនកូកាកូឡាដែលជាក្រុមហ៊ុនវិនិយោគនាំមុខគេមួយរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនៅកម្ពុជាបានបង្កើនចំនួនភាគរយនៃនារីដែលធ្វើការអោយក្រុមហ៊ុនេះពី១៨ដល់២៥ក្នុងរយៈពេល២ឆ្នាំមកនេះ។លោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតមានការចាប់អារម្មណ៍ជាខ្លាំងចំពោះការប្តេជ្ញាចិត្តខ្ពស់របស់ក្រុមហ៊ុនកូកាកូឡាចំពោះបទដ្ឋានថ្នាក់ពិភពលោកក្នុងការបណ្តុះបណ្តាលនិងជ្រើសរើសអ្នកធ្វើការនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។’’’"

    "2016-02-02T07:54:24+0000": {
        "eng": "It's #WorldWetlandsDay! Today marks the anniversary of the signing of the Convention on Wetlands, also called the Ramsar Convention, which is an intergovernmental treaty that provides a framework for national action and international cooperation for the conservation and protection of more than 529 million acres (over 214 million hectares) of the world's wetlands. There are 169 members of the Ramsar Convention, including the United States and #Cambodia, which joined on October 23, 1999.\n\nThere are  four designated \"Wetlands of International Importance\" in Cambodia: Koh Kapik, Prek Toal Ramsar, the Boeng Chhamar river system, and the Mekong River system north of Stung Treng. These areas play a vital role in maintaining the biological wealth of the Tonle Sap river basin and support Cambodias economy by supplying fish to millions of people who depend on its productivity. To learn more about these and other protected wetlands around the globe, visit http://www.ramsar.org/.\n\n(Photo Credit: rasmar.org; Kimyean Ky)", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153492052033224", 
        "kh": "’"
    },

    "2016-02-17T08:32:45+0000": {
        "eng": "Two new health care facilities in Kampong Cham - a regional blood center and a laboratory at the provincial hospital - are now up and running thanks to support from the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia and its partners at the U.S. Pacific Command (PACOM), the Defense Threat Reduction Agency, the Naval Medical Research Unit Two, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), and the U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). \n\nYesterday, Ambassador Heidt was joined by Minister of Health H.E. Mam Bunheng and more than 700 people from the local community for a ribbon cutting ceremony and tour of the facilities. The new blood center is a valuable asset to the collection, storage, and distribution of a clean and safe blood supply in #Cambodia, while the new laboratory will help doctors identify a variety of diseases and design appropriate treatment plans for patients, significantly improving the quality of health care for the citizens of Kampong Cham.",

More than 1,000  young people came to the InterContinental Phnom Penh yesterday to get valuable information about opportunities to study in the United States. Lao Chhiv Eav - Undersecretary of State for the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports - stopped by the fair to show their support and encourage more students from #Cambodia to apply to study at U.S. colleges and universities. And with the help of an outstanding group of volunteers, over 100 participants became members of the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative. Earlier in the day, EducationUSA also brought U.S. school representatives to the CIA FIRST International School for a fair that attracted an additional 100 students. These events not only prove just how enthusiastic Cambodian youth are about education and studying in the United States; they also demonstrate the wide number of people, programs, and partnerships dedicated to helping students achieve their dreams.\n\nDid you attend the EducationUSA Fair?     "2016-02-23T11:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "      ?     Heidt    Pactics   Cambodian Textiles Worldwide (CTW) \n\n Pactics                  \n\n CTW          CTW  \n\n  %   Heidt           \n\nDid you know that the United States purchased over $3 billion in Cambodian goods in 2015? The majority of these products come from textile manufacturers located across #Cambodia. Recently, Ambassador Heidt visited two garment factories: Pactics in Siem Reap and Cambodian Textiles Worldwide (CTW) in Phnom Penh. \n\nPactics employs 350 people and produces 50 million products annually, mostly microfiber cloths and pouches for designer brand sunglasses. In addition to investments made in sustainable building measures and energy saving technology, the company also offers its employees fair wages, reasonable working hours, safe and clean working conditions, and a full array of other benefits aimed to keep workers healthy.\n\nCTW produces aprons, table linen, bed sheets, hospital apparel, and other specialty textiles. The American-owned company works diligently to maintain a work environment that is both productive and worker friendly. CTW also employs Cambodians in positions of management and actively promotes its employees.  \n\nThese two factories are vital to the success of Cambodia's garment industry, which generates over 80% of national export income. But as the managers of the companies told #AmbHeidt, their success is due to the investments made in their employees. For sustained labor productivity and economic growth in Cambodia, the health and reliability of the garment industry workforce is essential.", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153531606883224", 
        "kh": "តើអ្នកដឹងទេថាសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកបានទិញទំនិញពីកម្ពុជានៅឆ្នាំ២០១៥ដែលមានតំលៃជាទឹកប្រាក់ចំនួនជាង៣ពាន់លាដុល្លាអាមេរិកទេភាគច្រើននៃផលិតផលទាំងនេះគឺជាទំនិញវាយនភណ្ឌពីបណ្តារោងចក្រនៅទូទាំងប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។ក្នុងពេលថ្មីៗនេះលោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតបានទៅទស្សនារោងចក្រកាត់ដេរចំនួន២គឺរោងចក្រងនៅសៀមរាបនិងរោងចក្រនៅភ្នំពេញ។រោងចក្រប្រើមនុស្សចំនួន៣៥០នាក់ហើយផលិតរបស់បានចំនួន៥០លានក្នុងមួយឆ្នាំៗដែលភាគច្រើនគឺជាថង់និងក្រណាត់សរសៃឆ្មារសំរាប់អ្នកច្នៃម៉ូដនិងកញ្ចក់វ៉ែនតា។ក្រៅពីការវិនិយោគទៅលើបច្ចេកទេសសន្សំថាមពលនិងវិធានការក្នុងការសាងសង់ដែលធានានិរន្តភាពក្រុមហ៊ុននេះថែមទាំងផ្តល់ដល់កម្មករនិយោជិតរបស់ខ្លួននូវប្រាក់ខែនិងម៉ោងការងារសមរម្យស្ថានភាពនៅកន្លែងធ្វើការមានសុវត្ថិភាពនិងស្អាតហើយនិងការឧបត្ថម្ភដទៃជាច្រើនទៀតដើម្បីធ្វើអោយកម្មករមានសុខភាពល្អ។រោងចក្រផលិតអៀមកំរាលតុកំរាលគ្រែសំលៀកបំពាក់សំរាប់មន្ទីរពេទ្យនិងវាយនភណ្ឌឯកទេសដទៃទៀត។ក្រុមហ៊ុនដែលមានជនជាតិអាមេរិកជាម្ចាស់នេះខិតខំធ្វើអោយមានបរិស្ថាននៅកន្លែងការងារល្អទាំងសំរាប់អ្នកធ្វើការទាំងសំរាប់អោយគេធ្វើការបានលទ្ធផលល្អ។រោងចក្រថែមទាំងផ្តល់តំណែងថ្នាក់គ្រប់គ្រងដល់ជនជាតិកម្ពុជាហើយជំរុញយ៉ាងសកម្មអោយនិយោជិតរបស់ខ្លួនបានឡើងតំណែងថែមទៀតផង។រោងចក្រទាំងពីរនេះមានសារៈសំខាន់ណាស់សំរាប់ជោគជ័យនៃឧស្សាហកម្មកាត់ដេររបស់ប្រទេសកម្ពុជាដែលផ្តល់ប្រាក់ចំណូលពីការនាំចេញចំនួន៨០សំរាប់ប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។តែដូចអ្នកគ្រប់គ្រងក្រុមហ៊ុនបានជំរាបប្រាប់លោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតអញ្ចឹងថាជោគជ័យរបស់គេគឺបានមកដោយសារការវិនិយោគទៅលើកម្មករនិយោជិតរបស់គេ។ដើម្បីអោយកម្មករនិយោជិតបន្តអាចធ្វើការបានល្អនិងដើម្បីអោយប្រទេសកម្ពុជាមានកំណើនសេដ្ឋកិច្ចជាបន្តទៀតសុខភាពនិងភាពជាទីទុកចិត្តរបស់កម្មករនិយោជិតក្នុងឧស្សាហកម្មកាត់ដេរគឺជាការចាំបាច់។"

        "eng": "Ambassador Heidt gave remarks today at the National Committee for Counter Trafficking's meeting for #Cambodia's National Plan of Action to Counter Human Trafficking. Presided over by Deputy Prime Minister & Minister of Interior Sar Kheng, the event helped launch the new Cambodia Counter Trafficking in Persons (CCTIP) program and the Victim Identification Guidelines for human trafficking. For #AmbHeidt's full remarks, please visit: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/022516_sp.html.  \n\nThe CCTIP program - which will be administered by USAID Cambodia partner Winrock International - seeks to address root causes of trafficking by providing vocational training and employment opportunities to at-risk populations, increasing the likelihood of prosecutions, and strengthening local governance. The Victim Identification Guidelines - one of the key recommendations in the most recent U.S. Department of State Trafficking in Persons Report -  represent an important step in Cambodia's commitment to strengthening services and support to victims of human trafficking.",

        "eng": "Rosie the Riveter is an iconic image that celebrates the contributions American women made to the workforce during World War II and continue to make today. The symbol of Rosie also reminds us that real social change starts at the local level. This spirit of social change is here in #Cambodia as well, as more women are taking on new roles and making a difference in their communities. In recognition of the achievements of Cambodian women, U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh is proud to present the \"#CamWomenCan\" Club. From tomorrow until International Womens Day on March 8, we will feature a diverse group of inspirational women who - just like Rosie the Riveter - are showing what is possible when women have equal opportunity.         "kh": "“”គឺជារូបភាពដ៏ល្បីបំផុតមួយដែលអបអរចំពោះការរួមចំណែករបស់ស្រ្តីអាមេរិកជាកំលាំងពលកម្មនៅក្នុងអំឡុងពេលនៃសង្គ្រាមលោកលើកទី២ហើយការរួមចំណែកនេះបន្តមានរហូតមកដល់សព្វថ្ងៃនេះ។និមិត្តរូបនៃក៏រំលឹកអោយយើងដឹងផងដែរថាការផ្លាស់ប្តូរពិតប្រាកដនៅក្នុងសង្គមចាប់ផ្តើមពីថ្នាក់មូលដ្ឋានទៅ។ស្មារតីនៃការផ្លាស់ប្តូរក្នុងសង្គមនេះក៏មាននៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជាដែរដោយមានស្រ្តីជាច្រើនទទួលយកតួនាទីថ្មីហើយធ្វើអោយសហគមន៍របស់គេមានការប្រែប្រួលមុខមាត់។ជាការទទួលស្គាល់ការសំរេចបានរបស់ស្រ្តីកម្ពុជាស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកនៅរាជធានីភ្នំពេញមានមោទនភាពសូមបង្ហាញក្លិបនារីកម្ពូជាអាចធ្វើបាន។ចាប់ពីថ្ងៃស្អែករហូតដល់ទិវានារីអន្តរជាតិ៨មិនាយើងនឹងបង្ហាញក្រុមនារីផ្សេងៗដែលគួរអោយគេយកគំរូតាមហើយដែលដូចនិមិត្តរូបដែរកំពុងតែបង្ហាញអោយឃើញនូវអ្វីដែលគេអាចសំរេចបាននៅពេលនារីមានឱកាសស្មើបុរស។សូមចូលមើលទំព័ររបស់យើងរាល់ថ្ងៃដើម្បីជួបជាមួយសមាជិកនៃក្លិបនេះសូមអរគុណចំពោះបុគ្គលិកនៃស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកដែលបានស្ម័គ្រចិត្តចូលរួមក្នុងការថតរបស់យើង“”’"

    "2016-03-01T02:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "#CamWomenCan: Suos Srey Len, Coca-Cola Forklight Operator\n\nIn both #Cambodia and the United States, transportation and warehousing are male-dominated professions. But dont tell that to Ms. Suos Srey Len - one of 3 female forklift operators and 6 female truck drivers working at Coca-Cola in Phnom Penh! We think Len and her colleagues may be the first female forklift operators in Cambodia!\n\nSrey Len is 26 years old and has been driving a forklift at Coca-Cola for two years. When talking about why she loves her job, she said: I was hesitant to take the role as forklift driver when I was first asked because the job is generally for men. With encouragement from my family and friends, I decided to take the job. At first, I was nervous; but after a period of time, I got used to it.\n\nThe Coca-Cola Company  one of Americas largest and best known companies  is a leading U.S. investor in Cambodia. It is known for its global commitment to empowering women, both through its hiring practices and its programs that help women entrepreneurs throughout the Coca-Cola value chain.\n\n                 !    !\n                   \n          ",

    "2016-03-02T02:00:01+0000": {
        "eng": "Kim Sokngim  today's #CamWomenCan Club member  on why she decided to study engineering: \nIn #Cambodia, the field of engineering offers very few women higher positions. Many engineering companies will hire only men for higher positions because they think that women are weaker and less powerful than men... I went against this discrimination by choosing to study civil engineering. I want to empower equal opportunity of gender in every workplace in Cambodia. I believe that women can do anything that the men can do, because women are smart and creative.\n\nSokngim  who is from Kandal Province and is a graduate of The Harpswell Foundation  is completing her studies at the University of Georgia. After graduating, she hopes to return to Cambodia to start her own civil engineering firm that will build roads and bridges throughout the country. My roads and bridges would propel the economy and Cambodia would have the strongest economy in Southeast Asia. My roads would also mean that children in the provinces could ride the bus to school and so they would receive education and help Cambodia in the future.\n\n   (#CamWomenCan Club)                 \n\n   The Harpswell Foundation  Georgia             ",

    "2016-03-03T11:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "#CamWomenCan: Women in Technology\n\"My goal is to be a leader in an IT company. I have a strong desire to improve technology and to encourage women in #Cambodia to work in this field.\" - Heng Somphas, Computer Science Engineering major at the Institute of Technology of Cambodia (ITC)\n\nPictured below are three outstanding women who are studying for careers in technology: Heng Somphas, Chea Sovannara (Information Technology, Thammasat University, Bangkok), and Chhin Chileap (Information and Communication Engineering, ITC). They're among a growing number of female university students with tech-related majors.  All three are currently serving as interns as they prepare to graduate and move on to exciting high-tech careers.\n\nSomphas, Sovannara, and Chileap are following in the footsteps of other women pioneers. In his recent visit to the Pactics factory in Siem Reap, #AmbHeidt met Huonh Chun and Pour Choun, who both studied for two years at the National Polytechnic Institute of Cambodia in Phnom Penh.  Chun and Choun are currently finishing their probationary period at Pactics and will soon be working as Industrial Engineers for the company! Their message to other women interested in technology is simple: \"Knowledge has nothing to do with gender. Believing in yourself is key!\"\n\n#IWD2016",

    "2016-03-04T02:00:00+0000": {
        "eng": "#CamWomenCan Keep People Safe\n\"I remember being in an embassy security vehicle once and hearing a Cambodian police officer say: Wow! The officer driving that car so well isnt a man...its a woman! - Khim Sina, U.S. Embassy Mobile Patrol Guard Supervisor.\n\nOriginally from Kandal Province, Khim Sina attended the National Institute of Management and worked as an administrative clerk before applying for a job at the U.S. Embassy in 2000 with the hope of receiving a good salary, healthcare benefits, and equal opportunity. Sina is now one of 34 female guards currently working at the Embassy and the first woman to serve on the elite Mobile Patrol unit. She was promoted to the rank of supervisor in September 2015. I encourage myself and other women with positive thoughts, Khim Sina says. This job is not something that only a man can do!\n\nThanks to Sina and her colleagues (below, with Secretary of State John Kerry) for their loyal service to the U.S. Embassy and for showing us that #CamWomenCan succeed in any career!\n\n CamWomenCan \n       ! !\n\n                         !\n\n  (  John Kerry)    \n\n#IWD2016",

        "eng": "#CamWomenCan Build Greatness\n\"I wanted to be an architect because architecture is rich with constructive ideas for serving people. An architect is a person who understands political, economic, historic, artistic, geographic, and philosophical concerns.\" - Cheam Phally\n\nMeet Cheam Phally, Senior Architect and Coordinator for the World Monuments Fund in #Cambodia and a trailblazer in the field of cultural heritage preservation. Phally manages a number of major architectural conservation projects at the Angkor Archaeological Park, including the ongoing restoration of the ancient Phnom Bakheng temple, which has been supported by the U.S. Embassy and the U.S. Department of State since 2003. The work that Phally and her team are carrying out will preserve Cambodia's extraordinary cultural heritage for future generations. Find out more about Phally's life and work by watching this video: https://www.wmf.org/video/architect.   \n\nLike us, Phally believes every woman is capable of building great things. Why? As Phally says, \"Women can do everything because they don't just have 2 arms...they have 8 like Vishnu!\"\n\n#IWD2016 #AFCP #PledgeforParity",

    "2016-03-06T05:00:01+0000": {
        "eng": "#CamWomenCan Become Doctors\nI do not think that women are appreciated enough in #Cambodia, even though we earn an income, have good education, and care for our children and husbands. Yes, it is hard to be a woman in this country...but we are very strong.\" - Dr. Neou Leakhena\n\nDr. Leakhena knew from a young age that she wanted to work in pediatric medicine. Studying in Phnom Penh in the 1990s, she was one of only 17 women in her class of more than 100. After years of hard work and dedication, today Dr. Leakhena directs neonatal care at the Angkor Hospital for Children in Siem Reap, which receives support from the U.S. government for its vital work in pediatric HIV/AIDS treatment. She is among a growing number of Cambodian women that are working in the health sector - not only in the traditional roles of nurses or assistants - but also as doctors and healthcare administrators.\n\nFor example, the Sihanouk Hospital Center of HOPE in Phnom Penh - which trains medical professionals and provides free high quality care to the poor - also has several amazing female doctors on its staff. Pictured below are Dr. Huy Sophea, Dr. Uch Muzen, Dr. Soth Sotheary, Dr.Chhun Sreymao,  Dr. Heing Kosalthyda, and Dr. Say Sothea. They all agree that education is the key to success for women. As Dr. Sreymao says, \"If you dont want someone to look down at you as a woman, you should try to build your capacity and knowledge. When you have an education, no one can look down at you.\n\n#IWD2016 #PledgeforParity",

    "2016-03-07T07:03:56+0000": {
        "eng": "#CamWomenCan Compete\n\"My biggest wish is to finish the #marathon at the #Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, be in good shape, and inspire the younger generation to follow my path.\"  Dr. Nary Ly\n\nLike the women in yesterdays post, Nary Ly is also a medical doctor. But more than that, she wants to show the world that #CamWomenCan participate in The Olympic Games! \n\nDr. Nary Ly is charting a new path for Cambodian women through her work in medicine and her passion for competitive running. Nary is a former research scientist with the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit Two and a lecturer at the University of Health Sciences. Earlier this year, she was nominated by the National Olympic Committee of Cambodia to represent her country at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Nary, who is currently training in Spain, is set to become the first Cambodian woman to compete in an Olympic marathon.\n\nNary's strength and determination to run in the Olympics has taken her on a journey around the world.         "eng": "Ambassador Heidt met yesterday with His Excellency Sik Bun Hok and other members of the National Election Committee (NEC) for a constructive dialogue about the Cambodian electoral process and the NEC's preparations for upcoming commune and national elections.\n\n\"I would like to thank His Excellency Sik Bun Hok and the other NEC members for an informative and productive discussion,\" said Ambassador Heidt.  \"The United States believes that organizing inclusive, transparent, and fair electors that reflect the will of the Cambodian people is critical for Cambodias continued development.   We appreciate the reforms implemented at the NEC and the hard work underway to prepare for the next elections.\n\nThe United States welcomes the opportunity to engage with the NEC and other partners in the electoral process to strengthen democratic institutions and multi-party democracy in Cambodia.   The next key challenge is the voter registration process.         "eng": "Building off of a successful visit in March 2015, U.S. Science Envoy Dr. Geraldine Richmond recently wrapped up her second trip to #Cambodia last week. Among her many activities included giving a talk entitled Why I Love Being a Scientist, one of the highlights of the 2nd Cambodia Science & Engineering Festival. Talking about her experience at #CSEF2016, Dr. Richmond said, \"I was blown away by it and all the incredible students that I met.  It makes me more optimistic than ever about Cambodias future with efforts like the Festival and all the energy and enthusiasm of the students.\"\n\nRecipient of the National Medal of Science - the highest award for scientific achievement in the United States - Dr. Richmond is the Presidential Chair of Chemistry at the University of Oregon, president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and the founder and chair of the Committee on the Advancement of Women Chemists (COACh for Women Scientists and Engineers). Her work in Cambodia and throughout the region is in support of President Obamas initiative to strengthen science and education in Southeast Asia.         "eng": "We're now accepting applications for the The Fulbright Program! What's it like to be a #Fulbright Scholar from #Cambodia? Meet Sovath, who is currently studying in the United States:\n\nI am currently doing my masters degree in Hydrology and Hydrodynamics, generally known as Water Resources Engineering, at the University of Washington. I choose this major field of study because I want to make a difference in Cambodia's future and improve the well-being of Cambodia and its people through sustainable development in water resources. Cambodia has several water-related issues ranging from water quality to sewage and water management system. I plan to use the knowledge and practical skills from my study in the United States to develop more human resources in water resources engineering, and together with other professionals, I strongly believe that we can sustainably solve these water-related problems by developing wastewater treatment plants, hydraulic structures and electric energy generation to response to the growing water demand, environmental threats and projected global climate change.\n\nActive in more than 160 countries, the Fulbright Program offers grants to study, teach and conduct research for non-U.S. citizens to come to the United States and for U.S. citizens to go abroad. For more details, please visit http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/fulbright_announcement.html. And for help on completing and submitting your application, go to http://go.usa.gov/c74Pz. Applications are due by June 1st. Good luck!",

        "eng": "#WorldTBDay\nFACT #1: The rate of tuberculosis (TB) prevalence in #Cambodia was cut in half between 2002-2011.\nFACT #2: Cambodia reached its Millennium Development Goal (MDG) target of 50% reduction of TB mortality prior to 2015.\nFACT #3: There is still much work to be done to #EndTB in Cambodia.\n\nThrough USAID Cambodia, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention(CDC) and the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the United States works with Cambodia's national TB program to increase case detection and ensure high quality TB diagnosis and care services.         "eng": "   Rama   Denver Art Museum      Denver Art Museum  \n\n  Christoph Heinrich  Denver Art Museum  Rama   \n\n Heinrich        \n\n       Heidt  Anne Lemaistre  UNESCO        https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/ \n\nThis morning, a ceremony was held at the Council of Ministers to celebrate the homecoming of a 10th century statue of the Torso of Rama from Prasat Chen, Koh Ker, which had been in the collection of the Denver Art Museum for 30 years.  The Torso of Rama was returned by the Denver Art Museum after experts confirmed that the object had in fact been looted from its original home.\n\nIn his remarks, Denver Art Museum director Dr. Christoph Heinrich called the Torso of Rama an Ambassador of Cambodias distinguished tradition and culture that brought delight and wonder to millions of our visitors of our museum.\n\nWe are happy today to see this honorable Ambassador returning back home to be united with other important pieces from the temple of Koh Ker, said Dr. Heinrich.  The Torso of Rama is the seventh object from Koh Ker to be returned from U.S. collections.\n\nThe homecoming event was led by H.E. Yim Nolson, Vice-Chairman of the Economic, Social and Cultural Council of Cambodia, and was attended by Ambassador Heidt, UNESCO Representative in Cambodia Anne Lemaistre, and many distinguished guests from the diplomatic and cultural community.  The activities included a blessing dance and a garland ceremony.  To see more photos from this event, go to https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/",

    "2016-03-29T05:38:54+0000": {
        "eng": "The 2016 White House Easter Egg Roll, hosted on Monday by President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama, welcomed more than 35,000 jubilant visitors to the White House lawn with the theme Lets Celebrate, in honor of President Obamas final year in office. This annual tradition is a fun way to celebrate the Easter holiday and is also a reminder of the beginning of the spring season. \n\nThe Easter Egg Roll at the White House is a 138-year-old tradition started by President Rutherford B. Hayes when he invited a group of young children to roll Easter eggs on the lawn. This year's event was a fun-filled day of activities including the egg-roll, musical performances, cooking demonstrations, celebrity appearances, fitness activities and more. \n\nThe President and Mrs. Obama also took time to read the classic story Where the Wild Things Are to a group of young children. Watch the video and see them act out the characters from the book!  Watch the full video from today's event and learn more about the history of the Easter Egg Roll here https://www.whitehouse.gov/eastereggroll",

    "2016-03-30T07:31:42+0000": {
        "eng": "()\n\nThe U.S. Embassy and the Royal Government of Cambodia signed two bilateral agreements this morning to provide $35 million in assistance from the U.S. Agency for International Development USAID Cambodia for programs in health, agriculture, environment, and education.  The agreements were signed at the Council for the Development of Cambodia by Deputy Prime Minister Keat Chhon and USAID Mission Director Rebecca Black, with U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia William Heidt serving as a witness.\n\nThese agreements are the first part of a three-year, $137 million program from #USAID to support the Cambodian Government's national development plan.  The programs, which will be implemented primarily by non-governmental organizations, will boost the quality of healthcare, improve nutrition for mothers and children, reduce the prevalence of infectious diseases, expand agriculture markets and production, strengthen protections for Cambodia's natural resources, and help young students strengthen their reading skills.\n\nIn his remarks, Ambassador Heidt emphasized the strong collaboration between USAID and the government, saying I am very grateful for the partnership between our two countries over the past two decades.  Together, we have worked to address many key development challenges.  Together, weve pushed back HIV/AIDS from its dangerous levels in the 1990s.   Together, weve helped farmers increase their yields and enabled them to feed, educate, and access healthcare for their families.  And together, weve worked with Cambodians to take advantage of innovations in science and technology to improve many aspects of life.  \n\nTo read the Ambassadors full remarks, go to http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/033016_sp.html\n\n     (USAID)          Rebecca Black  USAID \n                \n   Heidt  USAID                      http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/033016_sp.html", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153632199408224", 
        "kh": "អត្ថបទជាភាសាខ្មែរខាងក្រោមនេះ“’’’”’ស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកនិងរាជរដ្ឋាភិបាលកម្ពុជាបានចុះហត្ថលេខាលើកិច្ចព្រមព្រៀងទ្វេភាគីចំនួនពីរនៅព្រឹកនេះដែលនឹងផ្តល់ថវិកាចំនួន៣៥លានដុល្លារអាមេរិកជាជំនួយពីកម្មវិធីរបស់ទីភ្នាក់ងារសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកសំរាប់ការអភិវឌ្ឍន៍អន្តរជាតិក្នុងវិស័យសុខាភិបាលអប់រំកសិកម្មនិងបរិស្ថាន។កិច្ចព្រមព្រៀងនេះត្រូវបានចុះហត្ថលេខានៅក្រុមប្រឹក្សាអភិវឌ្ឍន៍កម្ពុជាដោយលោកឧបនាយករដ្ឋមន្រ្តីគាតឈុននិងលោកស្រីប្រធាននៃទីភ្នាក់ងារដោយមានលោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកប្រចាំនៅកម្ពុជាធ្វើជាសាក្សី។កិច្ចព្រមព្រៀងទាំងពីរនេះគឺជាប្រាក់ផ្តល់ដំបូងក្នុងកម្មវិធីកញ្ចប់ថវិកាចំនួនប្រមាណ១៣៧លានដុល្លាសំរាប់រយៈពេល៣ឆ្នាំសំរាប់ទ្រទ្រង់ផែនការអភិវឌ្ឍជាតិរបស់រាជរដ្ឋាភិបាលកម្ពុជា។កម្មវិធីទាំងនេះដែលភាគច្រើនដំណើរការដោយអង្គការមិនមែនរដ្ឋាភិបាលនឹងជំរុញគុណភាពនៃការថែទាំសុខភាពលើកកំពស់អាហារូបត្ថម្ភសំរាប់មាតានិងកុមារកាត់បន្ថយជំងឺឆ្លងពង្រីកទីផ្សានិងផលិតកម្មកសិកម្មពង្រឹងការការពារធនធានធម្មជាតិនៃប្រទេសកម្ពុជាហើយជួយសិស្សក្មេងៗនៅក្នុងការរៀនអាន។នៅក្នុងសុន្ទរកថារបស់លោកលោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតបានថ្លែងសង្កត់ពីកិច្ចសហការរឹងមាំរវាងទីភ្នាក់ងារនិងរដ្ឋាភិបាលដោយលោកមានប្រសាសន៍ថា“ខ្ញុំអរគុណណាស់ចំពោះភាពជាដៃគូរវាងប្រទេសយើងទាំងពីរនៅក្នុងរយៈពេល២ទសវត្សមកនេះ។យើងបានធ្វើការជាមួយគ្នាដើម្បីដោះស្រាយបញ្ហាប្រឈមជាគន្លឹះជាច្រើន។យើងបានធ្វើការជាមួយគ្នាដើម្បីរុញជំងឺអេដស៍ចេញពីកំរិតគ្រោះថ្នាក់របស់វានៅទសវត្សឆ្នាំ១៩៩០។ជាមួយគ្នាយើងបានជួយកសិករអោយបង្កើនទិន្នផលរបស់គេហើយធ្វើអោយគ្រួសាររបស់គេមានហូបចុកទទួលបានការសិក្សានិងមានលទ្ធភាពទទួលបានការថែទាំសុខភាពហើយយើងបានធ្វើការជាមួយប្រជាជនកម្ពុជាដើម្បីទាញយកប្រយោជន៍ពីបច្ចេកទេសនិងវិទ្យាសាស្រ្តថ្មីៗសំរាប់កែលំអទិដ្ឋភាពជាច្រើននៃជីវិតរស់នៅ”។បើចង់អានសុន្ទរកថាទាំងមូលរបស់លោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតសូមចូលមើលក្នុង"

    "2016-03-31T05:02:27+0000": {
        "eng": "\n\nTake a look at this!  Camera traps in the Preah Vihear Protected Forests  funded by the #USAID Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project  captured two rare photos of a golden Jackal and Gaur bison roaming the forest.  The recent assessment using these cameras identified eight mammal species in total, revealing that the protected area is showing signs of good health.  The USAID Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project, implemented by Winrock International, works on several projects throughout the country to help preserve Cambodias biodiversity.  \n \nAre you interested in learning more about conserving Cambodias natural heritage?  On April 3, from 5:00pm to 8:00 p.m. at Chaktomuk Theater, the USAID Cambodia Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project will host a music festival entitled The Beauty of Cambodian Forests to educate and inform audience members about the importance of forested landscapes in Cambodia.  The fun and educational event will include a traditional chapey performance and much more.  Tickets are available now at various universities including RUPP, RUFA, CamIU, IFL, NUM, UHS and ITC.  For more information see the Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Facebook page.\n\n!    (USAID)           USAID  Winrock International   \n\n?         "eng": "The U.S. capital, Washington, DC, is named in honor of our first president:  George Washington.  But did you know that there is also a state called Washington?  The state of Washington is located in the Pacific Northwest region of the United States.  The state capital is Olympia, but the largest city and economic hub is Seattle.  Washington is the birthplace of Starbucks coffee and home to many major tech companies such as Microsoft.  Washington state is also home to a large and dynamic Cambodian-American community.  \n\nThe U.S. Embassy has a personal connection to Washington state:  Ambassador and Mrs. Heidt were married at the Asian Art Museum in Seattle, followed by a traditional Khmer wedding at home.\n\nFind out more cool facts about Washington here: https://share.america.gov/washington-mountains-museums-innovation/",

In his speech, Jobs explained how failure can sometimes lead to unexpected success.  \n\nJobs understood the power of perseverance - the ability to keep doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.  As Jobs once said in an interview, \"I'm convinced that about half of what separates the successful entrepreneurs from the non-successful ones is pure perseverance.\"\n\nWatch Steve Jobs' speech in the video or read the text here: http://news.stanford.edu/news/2005/june15/jobs-061505.html.",

        "eng": "   USAID (  Winrock International)            Community of Living Chapey, Reek Sai Day, Cambodian Living Arts, Champey Academy of Arts, Khmer Magic Music Bus,        USAID  https://www.flickr.com/photos/usaid_cambodia/albums  \n\nYesterday, the #USAID Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project (implemented by Winrock International) organized a Chapey Festival at Chaktomuk Theater in Phnom Penh featuring the amazing music of Master Kong Nay and the chapey dong veng, a traditional musical instrument from #Cambodia. The event  with the theme of The Beauty of Cambodian Forests - was produced in collaboration with the Community of Living Chapei,  Reek Sai Day, Cambodian Living Arts (CLA), Champey Academy of ARTS, The Khmer Magic Music Bus, and international conservation organizations, with additional support from the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts. The Chapey Festival informed the audience about the importance of Cambodias forested landscapes while entertaining them with music and dance performances. It is a family where all the members from different countries come together with a shared goal of making their countries and their communities better places to live. YSEALI is also an eye-opener for me as a governance worker to see different options on how I should support my local government. It makes me a better employee.         "eng": "Hawaii is the 50th and most recent state of United States of America, receiving statehood on August 21, 1959. Known as the \"Aloha\" state  Aloha is Hawaiian for both hello and goodbye  Hawaii is made up of eight main islands, many of which have become a favorite destination for honeymooners, surfers, golfers, and hikers. The population is very diverse, with large native Hawaiian, Asian, and Hispanic communities. Hawaii is a state with a rich history and stunning natural beauty.  It is known for its volcanoes, including Kilauea, which has been erupting for decades, and Mauna Loa, which is the largest volcano on earth. \n\nMany well-known people come from Hawaii, but perhaps the most famous is U.S. President Barack Obama, who was born in Honolulu on August 4, 1961.\n\nHawaii is also home to the East-West Center  an important education and research center established in 1960 by the U.S. Congress. In 2015, Architect Pen Sereypagna of the Vann Molyvann Project had an internship at the East-West Center through the International Council on Monuments and Sites (US/ICOMOS), which was sponsored in part by the U.S. Embassy. Many Cambodians have studied at the University of Hawaii at Manoa, which is one of the few U.S. universities to offer a Khmer Language Program!\n\nLearn more about the great state of Hawaii here https://share.america.gov/hawaii-volcanoes-big-waves-and-chapels/?utm_source=productiondesk&utm_medium=shareamericanews&utm_campaign=dosnyhawaii&utm_content=hawaii:pearlharbor,perfectwaves,vol",

    "2016-04-07T10:30:00+0000": {
        "eng": "Happy #WorldHealthDay!  Every year on April 7 we pause to celebrate World Health Day, sponsored by the World Health Organization (WHO).  The goal of World Health Day is to raise awareness of important global health concerns like food safety, mental health, and traffic accidents.\n\nThis years World Health Day is focused on diabetes, which affects nearly 350 million people worldwide.  Diabetes  a serious condition that affects the way your body uses blood sugar  is increasingly seen in low and middle-income countries like Cambodia.  Fortunately, many cases of diabetes can be prevented through simple steps like a healthy diet and regular exercise.\n\nIn Cambodia, the U.S. government is helping to reduce the impact of diabetes and other diseases by improving nutrition and increasing access to quality health care services.  This important and life-saving work is supported by a number of agencies including the USAID - US Agency for International Development, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ( CDC), and The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR).\n\nU.S. Embassy Phnom Penh staff teamed up with U.S. Missions around the world to mark #WorldHealthDay by wearing the color green.  For more on World Health Day, go to http://www.who.int/campaigns/world-health-day/2016/en/",

    "2016-04-18T10:52:45+0000": {
        "eng": "On Monday morning, Ambassador Heidt and Minister of Environment H.E. Dr. Say Samal flew over Prey Lang Forest to raise awareness about #deforestation in #Cambodia and to highlight U.S. and Cambodian government efforts to protect Cambodias precious natural resources. The Ambassador and Minister Samal were joined by representatives from the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries, the Ministry of Interior, and USAID Cambodia. The group met with the provincial governor of Steung Treng province and gave a press conference after returning to Phnom Penh.  \n\nThe U.S. government is providing $20 million to protect and conserve Cambodias rich natural assets and unique biodiversity through USAID's Supporting Forests and Biodiversity Project (SFB), implemented by Winrock International. In Prey Lang and other forested areas, USAID and its partners work closely with national and local authorities and communities to help mark protected areas, patrol community forests, and educate the public about the importance of conserving forest resources. For more information about the SFB project, please visit http://www.winrock.org/project/supporting-forestry-and-biodiversity.\n\n#AmbHeidt",

        "eng": "The U.S. Department of the Treasury has announced that the $20 bill - which currently has President Andrew Jackson on the front - will soon feature a portrait of Harriet Tubman, who dedicated her life to fighting for liberty. Born into slavery, she later became an abolitionist and helped others escape to freedom during the late 1800s. She is the first woman on U.S. paper currency since the late 19th century.\n\nPresident Jackson and images of the White House will now appear on the back of the new $20 bill. There will also be changes to the $10 and $5 notes, as part of a plan to have the themes of democracy, diversity, and equality better represented on U.S. currency. What are these changes?
