        "eng": "After a solemn Buddhist ceremony to honor and respect the souls of the deceased, a forensic archaeology team from the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts began work today on a project to analyze and protect human remains at the Khmer Rouge-era Kraing Ta Chan Security Center, located in the Tram Kok District of Takeo Province. The remains from Kraing Ta Chan will be studied and cataloged before being returned to the memorial stupa, which will be improved to provide better protection from the elements.\n\nThe Kraing Ta Chan project- supported by the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts and organizations like Youth For Peace-CAMBODIA - received a grant from the American Academy of Forensic Sciences. U.S. #Fulbright student Julie Fleischman is serving as an advisor on the project. Julie, a Ph.D. candidate at Michigan State University, received a one-year U.S. government Fulbright scholarship to conduct forensic research and contribute to vital scientific and cultural studies in #Cambodia.",

        "eng": " John Kerry   Ban ki-Moon             New York            http://www.state.gov/e/oes/climate/index.htm \n\nU.S. Secretary of State John Kerry, with his granddaughter and United Nations Secretary-General Ban ki-Moon looking on, signed the #COP21 Climate Change Agreement on behalf of the United States during a historic ceremony on #EarthDay, April 22, 2016, at the U.N. General Assembly Hall in New York. More than 170 countries  including #Cambodia  signed the agreement to take significant action on both mitigating and adapting to climate change.         "eng": "Two events this past weekend - the Technovation Cambodia National Pitch  and #Fishackathon 2016 - showed people in #Cambodia and around the world how #technology can be used to make positive changes globally.\n\nHosted by USAID Cambodia's Development Innovations project, the Technovation Cambodia National Pitch featured 14 talented teams of young women aged 10-18 who identified community problems, built mobile apps to address their key issues, designed business plans and pitched their ideas to a panel of judges representing the U.S. Embassy, the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport, Digital Mobile Innovations, and Development Innovations Cambodia. More than 500 students, tech professionals, and supporters were in attendance. Congratulations to all of this year's teams!\n\nIn its third year, Fishackathon  sponsored by the U.S. Department of State  is now a worldwide event that connects science and computer programming with addressing threats to sustainable fishing. Coders, technologists, and designers from over 40 cities internationally spent the weekend developing usable solutions to problems that the world's fisheries are facing today.     "2016-04-26T05:48:46+0000": {
        "eng": "    ,    (USAID)   ?\n\n   USAID                          \n\n    USAID        http://capmalaria.org/ \n\nEach year, #WorldMalariaDay provides an opportunity to recognize global efforts to eliminate malaria. The United States provides $4.5 million annually to the Control and Prevention of Malaria Project (CAP Malaria) - funded by USAID  through the President's Malaria Initiative (PMI) - to fight #malaria in #Cambodia. How does this help?\n \nIn FY2015, USAID Cambodia procured and distributed more than 122,000 mosquito nets to at-risk populations. Village malaria workers made over 143,000 visits to households and over 22,000 visits to development farms to educate people about malaria prevention. And after training more than 900 health facility and community workers in case management, close to 26,000 patients were confirmed malaria positive and received proper treatment.\n\nTo eliminate malaria in Cambodia by 2025, USAID is working with the National Malaria Program Center to pilot a malaria elimination intervention package, with the hope that it will one day serve as the basis for a model that can be replicated throughout the country. To find out more, please visit http://capmalaria.org/.\n\nUSAID Global Health USAID Asia",

        "eng": " Kent State  Ohio               Kent State     Kent State       James Tyner     \n\n           John Pirozzi      http://www.kent.edu/kent/news/kent-states-may-4-visitors-center-host-discussions-cambodia-after-kent-state.\n\nKent State University in the U.S. state of Ohio shares a special historical link with #Cambodia. On May 4, 1970, four unarmed students were killed during a demonstration against the announcement of U.S. military action in Cambodia. In remembrance of this pivotal moment in U.S. history, Kent State is hosting an educational series this week entitled Cambodia After Kent State. Event organizers include Cambodian graduate student Savina Sirik and Professor Dr. James Tyner, who has been working with the Documentation Center of Cambodia (DC-Cam) for the past 20 years.\n\nThe event features discussions with S-21 survivor Chum Mey and author of First They Killed My Father Luong Ung, as well as a special screening of the award-winning Dont Think Ive Forgotten hosted by director John Pirozzi and Khmer Rouge survivor LinDa Siphan.         "eng": "April 30 is International Jazz Day! \n\nJazz  a music genre that originated in African-American communities in the southern United States during the late 19th and early 20th centuries  is celebrated for its diverse cultural traditions and musical styles.  International Jazz Day was designated by the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) to generate global appreciation for the art form and as a way to foster unity among different cultures.\n \nLast night, President Obama and the First Lady hosted an International Jazz Day concert on the South Lawn of the White House.  The full concert will air at 8 p.m. on April 30 (7 a.m. in Cambodia on Sunday, May 1), and will be available on the United Nations, UNESCO, U.S. State Department and White House websites.\n \nIn the meantime, to see some more great jazz watch and listen to these musicians, each with their own unique style. http://www.npr.org/sections/allsongs/2016/04/28/475892969/throwback-thursday-five-great-jazz-tiny-desk-concerts",

        "eng": "\nLABOR DAY IN #CAMBODIA\n\n          \n\n          \n\nToday is the official Labor Day holiday in #Cambodia.  To mark this occasion, the U.S. Embassy gives special recognition to one of this countrys greatest resources  its workers. The strong economic success that Cambodia has enjoyed over the last decade would not be possible without the contributions of hard-working men and women across the nation.\n\nThe U.S. Embassy is proud to work with the Cambodian government, private sector, civil society organizations, and others to improve working conditions, encourage corporate social responsibility, strengthen commercial ties, and create economic opportunities for hundreds of thousands of Cambodians.         "eng": "In recognition of World Press Freedom Day, today we highlight the work of the Cambodian Center for Independent Media (CCIM), led by Executive Director Pa Nguon Teang. Established in 2007, CCIM collaborates with a wide range of international and local NGOs, governmental agencies, and private companies to build a strong and independent media in #Cambodia. To learn more about CCIMs work, visit www.ccimcambodia.org. \n\nSpeaking of media, a few days ago President Obama attended his final White House Correspondents Dinner. The annual event is traditionally attended by the President & First Lady and is famous for being the one night a year when the President is free to tell as many jokes as he can (often at his own expense). President Obama also had a serious message, taking time to thank the press for their work:\n\nI know that there are times that weve had differences. But weve always shared the same goal  to root our public discourse in the truth; to open the doors of this democracy; to do whatever we can to make our country and our world more free and more just. And Ive always appreciated the role that you have all played as equal partners in reaching these goals.\n\nTo see President Obamas message to journalists  and to hear all of the jokes  visit https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hA5ezR0Kh80\n\n#FreeThePress #WPFD2016r",

        "eng": " \nCambodian Human Rights and Development Association (ADHOC)\n\n Rebecca Black  (USAID)                 USAID  ADHOC    http://www.adhoc-cambodia.org/\n\nUSAID Cambodia Mission Director Rebecca Black and other U.S. Embassy staff met yesterday with representatives from the Cambodian Human Rights and Development Association (ADHOC) - a renowned human rights organization that plays a vital role in promoting fundamental freedoms and equitable economic development in #Cambodia. ADHOC was founded by a group of former political prisoners in 1991, and over the years it has grown to become one of Cambodias leading civil society organizations with a variety of programs that help Cambodians understand and defend their basic rights. USAID is currently partnering with ADHOC to improve local governance and help vulnerable populations. Learn more about ADHOC's efforts by visiting http://www.adhoc-cambodia.org/.",

        "eng": "Mr. Jon Sheehan, an American pilot with Delta Airlines, spoke to a group of students today about his work and other #STEM-related careers in #aviation.  Over 300 students from local schools in Phnom Penh attended the talk, which was hosted by Passtra University of Cambodia and organized by EducationUSA Cambodia. After his presentation, the students had several questions for Jon and he had some cool #Delta giveaways for the students.\n\nJon - who is married to a Cambodian and here to visit his wife's family in Kandal province - kindly volunteered to speak to youth in #Cambodia about aviation and STEM. Aviation is all about STEM,\" Jon said. \"For science, we have meteorologists to help us with the weather. For technology, we have people who design the aircraft we fly. For engineering, we have mechanics and technicians who keep us flying. And for math, Im doing math all the time in the cockpit.         "eng": "Want to see more photos from Ambassador Heidt's recent trip to Battambang, Pailin, and Pursat provinces? Log on to www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/!\n\n Heidt    ?  www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/ !\n\n#AmbHeidt's trip was full of many exciting and informative activities. In addition to meetings with the Battambang and Pailin provincial governors, the Ambassador also met with Peace Corps Cambodia volunteers, an English Language Fellow, and Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative (#YSEALI) members at American Corner Battambang, Cambodia. There were visits to a number of program sites that are receiving support from the U.S. government, such as demining organizations MAG (Mines Advisory Group) and The HALO Trust, the USAID Cambodia-funded HARVEST program, and a CDC HIV lab facility. Before returning to Phnom Penh, Ambassador Heidt also visited the Battambang Museum and the Youth Development Service Center, an NGO located in his wife Sotie's hometown in Krakor District, Pursat Province. \n\nStayed tuned for more photos and stories about the Ambassador's trips in #Cambodia.     "2016-05-09T06:08:57+0000": {
        "eng": "The United States Air Force Band String Quartet held a special concert last night for His Majesty King Norodom Sihamoni, Her Majesty Queen Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk, and other invited guests to commemorate a performance that took place on May 9, 1956 in Phnom Penh at the invitation of the late King Norodom Suramarit and Queen Sisowath Monivong Kossomak Nearireath Serei Watana. Joined by two Cambodian artists, The United States Air Force Band String Quartet played a mix of American, European, and Cambodian music, including two pieces by King Sihanouk that premiered in 1956. The musicians concluded the 60th Anniversary Concert with a special birthday message for HM King Norodom Sihamoni and a heart-warming encore performance of \"Monika\" in honor of HM Queen Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk.\n\nFor more photos from this historic event, please visit the Embassy's Flickr: https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/albums/72157667471323780.\n\n                                                                                                                      Monika           \n\n  Flickr  https://www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/albums/72157667471323780 \n\n#Cambodia #AmbHeidt",

That is the value of U.S. currency in circulation...but do you know the difference between real and counterfeit U.S. dollars? \n\nBetween one-half and two-thirds of the value of all U.S. currency circulates outside of the United States. To ensure that consumers and businesses in #Cambodia and around the world know how to authenticate genuine U.S. dollars and report suspect counterfeits, the Federal Reserve Boards U.S. Currency Education Program conducts international outreach.   \n\nMichael Lambert  the Director of Banknotes for the U.S. Federal Reserve System  is in Cambodia this week to raise awareness about educational resources available in Khmer at uscurrency.gov/km.         "eng": "#Cambodia is working to establish a national School Feeding Programme (SFP) that will improve children's health by helping them learn how to grow and prepare nutritious food. In support of this effort, a delegation of Cambodian government officials and representatives from the United Nations, the World Food Programme (WFP), and USAID Cambodia recently visited eight schools in Siem Reap Province that currently implement the SFP.  During the two-day mission, the delegation met local government and school authorities, community members, and families with children benefiting from the program. \n\nThe SFP has reached up to 840,000 beneficiaries in Cambodia each year since 2011 and is working with the government to establish a national school feeding program by 2021. The U.S. government is working with Cambodia to achieve its nutrition goals through initiatives like Feed the Future and USAIDs HARVEST project. The U.S. Department of Agriculture is WFP Cambodias largest donor, contributing more than $44 million since 2003 through the McGovern-Dole International Food for Education and Child Nutrition Program.         "eng": "       %          \n\n       USAID      USAID   https://www.usaid.gov/cambodia/tuberculosis-and-malaria \n\nThe #tuberculosis (TB) mortality rate in #Cambodia has reduced by more than half since 1990. However, it is estimated that as many as 40% of TB cases in Cambodia still go undiagnosed. To achieve the goal to eliminate deaths from TB by the year 2035, the Ministry of Health - Cambodia and the National Center For Tuberculosis and Leprosy Control (CENAT) are working with a number of partners to identify and treat cases throughout the country.\n\nThe opening ceremony for the 21st Annual National TB Conference took place today, hosted by CENAT and featuring officials from the Ministry of Health, USAID Cambodia, the World Health Organization (WHO), and others joining the fight to #EndTB in Cambodia and around the world. To learn more about USAID's collaboration with Cambodia's National TB Program, please visit https://www.usaid.gov/cambodia/tuberculosis-and-malaria.\n\nPictured: Mr. Kea Vutha, Chief of Kor health center collecting possible TB samples in Tbong Khmum.         "eng": "Check out these photos from The U.S. Ambassador's Youth Council (AYC), who held their annual strategic planning and service event in Kampot province this past weekend. The 25 AYC members spent the weekend conducting team-building exercises and prepared for upcoming community-based projects that will focus on areas such as literacy, civic engagement, STEM education, and more. The group also visited Trapangsangke Community Based Ecotourism-Kampot to plant mangrove trees with members of the Trapeang Sangke community in Teuk Chhou district, Kampot province. \n\nThrough monthly meetings with #AmbHeidt, the AYC helps to create a more effective partnership between the United States and #Cambodia by cultivating young leaders around the country, engaging Cambodian youth on topics of interest, and generating feedback on U.S. policy and programs in Cambodia.     "2016-05-17T13:02:19+0000": {
        "eng": "\"All people deserve to live free from fear, violence, and discrimination, regardless of who they are or whom they love.\" - President Obama\n\nMay 17 is International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia (#IDAHOT), which stands as a reminder that #LGBTI rights are also human rights. In #Cambodia, the NGO Khana Cambodia plays a leading role in providing quality care and support to members of the LGBTI community throughout the country. KHANA's work includes giving technical assistance to implementing partners and community workers, providing health services, case documentation on human right abuses, advocacy campaigns, and much more. LGBT persons who benefited from these efforts have expressed a great sense of relief with being able to be themselves, thanks to the support and counseling received from KHANA. The United States is proud to support KHANA through USAID Cambodia and the Flagship HIV/AIDS Project, part of The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR). Learn more about KHANA and what they are doing to promote #PRIDE and #HumanRights in Cambodia at www.khana.org.kh.\n\n#may17IDAHOT",

    "2016-05-18T07:20:15+0000": {
        "eng": "UT Bunchhoeun is among the latest group of #YSEALI members from #Cambodia participating in the YSEALI Professional Fellows Program. Bunchhoeun - a Program Team Leader with the NGO \"My Village Organization\" in Mondulkiri province - is in the United States on an exchange program hosted by the Mansfield Center of the University of Montana. Like Mondulkiri, the U.S. state of Montana is known for its natural beauty. Bunchhoeun recently visited Yellowstone National Park, the oldest National Park in the United States and the first National Park in the world. He said that he was \"very lucky\" to be one of the millions of people who visit the park each year to see its wildlife, forests, and \"Old Faithful\" -  one of the world's most famous geothermal geysers. See what else Bunchhoeun had to say about his visit to Yellowstone by reading his blog (and the blogs of other YSEALI members) at https://mansfieldprofellows.wordpress.com/2016/05/16/nature-interactions-in-america. \n\nIn addition to The Maureen & Mike Mansfield Center at the University of Montana, ICMA - International City/County Management Association is also hosting YSEALI members from Cambodia.     "2016-05-18T11:15:54+0000": {
        "eng": "Here's what Ambassador Heidt had to say about his meeting today at the Ministry of Labor and Vocational Training:\n\"I really enjoyed meeting Minister of Labor and Vocational Training Ith Samheng today. We had worked together closely in the late 1990s when I was the Economic Officer at the Embassy and #Cambodias garment industry was just getting started. I told the Minister that the United States is committed to working with Cambodia on labor and vocational training issues, and that I was very impressed by the growth of the garment industry over the past 15 years. The large increase in employment, factories, and shipments to America (over $3 billion in 2015) have all been good for Cambodia. The Minister briefed me on the Ministrys very broad reform agenda and important issues like harmonizing industrial relations, implementing the new trade union law, guaranteeing freedom of association, improving the minimum wage setting process, and rolling out a social security labor law.  \n\nTo me, the key challenge facing the garment sector today is improving perceptions among Cambodias international partners about conditions in the industry. It will be important to implement the new trade union law fairly and transparently, further refine the minimum wage setting process, settle industrial disputes professionally and fairly, and improve working conditions across the industry. I think Cambodia could make progress on some of these issues quickly, like developing a safer transportation system for garment factory workers and understanding the mass fainting issue better. I look forward to working with the Minister and his team to do just that.\" - #AmbHeidt\n\n Heidt  \n                 ( )            \n\n                ", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153738453323224", 
        "kh": "’’’ខាងក្រោមនេះជាប្រសាសន៏របស់លោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតនៅក្នុងកិច្ចប្រជុំនាថ្ងៃនេះនៅក្រសួងការងារនិងបណ្តុះបណ្តាលវិជា្ចជីវះ។“ខ្ញុំសប្បាយចិត្តដោយបានជួបប្រជុំជាមួយជាមួយឯកឧត្តមអ៊ិតសំហេងរដ្ឋមន្រ្តីក្រសួងការងារនិងបណ្តុះបណ្តាលវិជ្ចាជីវះនៅថ្ងៃនេះ។យើងបានធ្វើការជាមួយគ្នាយ៉ាងជិតស្និទ្ធចាប់តាំងពីចុងទសវត្សឆ្នាំ១៩៩០មកនៅពេលដែលខ្ញុំបំរើការជាមន្រ្តីសេដ្ឋកិច្ចនៅក្នុងស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកប្រចាំនៅកម្ពុជាហើយដែលនៅពេលនោះឧស្សាហកម្មកាត់ដេរទើបតែចាប់ផ្តើមដំណើរការ។ខ្ញុំបានប្រាប់ទៅឯកឧត្តមរដ្ឋមន្រ្តីថាសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកមានការតាំងចិត្តដើម្បីធ្វើការជាមួយកម្ពុជាលើបញ្ហាបណ្តុះបណ្តាលវិជ្ជាជីវះនិងការងារហើយខ្ញុំមានការចាប់អារម្មណ៏យ៉ាងខ្លាំងពីការរីកចំរើនលើឧស្សាហកម្មកាត់ដេរក្នុងរយះពេលជាង១៥ឆ្នាំកន្លងមកនេះ។ការកើនឡើងនូវចំនួនការងារចំនួនរោងចក្រកាត់ដេរនិងការនាំចេញទៅកាន់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកជាង៣កោដដុល្លាក្នុងឆ្នាំ២០១៥ជាការមួយល្អសំរាប់ប្រទេសកម្ពុជា។ឯកឧត្តមរដ្ឋមន្ត្រីក៏បានប្រាប់ខ្ញុំផងដែរអំពីផែនការកំណែទំរង់ដ៏ទូលាយរបស់ក្រសួងការងារនិងបញ្ហាសំខាន់ៗមួយចំនួនដូចជាធ្វើអោយមានសុខដុមរមនីយកម្មទំនាក់ទំនងឧស្សាហកម្មការអនុវត្តច្បាប់សហជីពថ្មីធានាអោយមានសេរីភាពនៃការបង្កើតសមាគមន៏ការធ្វើអោយប្រសើឡើងនូវប្រាក់បំណាច់អប្បបរិមានិងការអនុវត្តច្បាប់សន្តិសុខការងារសង្គមជាដើម។សំរាប់ខ្ញុំការប្រឈមចំពោះវិស័យកាត់ដេរនាពេលបច្ចុប្បន្នគឺការធ្វើអោយប្រសើរឡើងនូវការយល់ឃើញនៅក្នុងចំណោមដៃគូរអន្តរជាតិរបស់កម្ពុជាស្តីពីលក្ខ័ណ្ខនៅក្នុងឧស្សាហកម្មនេះ។វាមានសារសំខាន់ក្នុងការអនុវត្តច្បាប់សហជីពថ្មីដោយភាពត្រឹមត្រូវនិងដោយតំល្លាភាពដាក់ចេញនូវដំណើរការនៃកំណត់ប្រាប់បៀវត្សអប្បបរិមាបន្ថែមដោះស្រាវវិវាទការងារដោយត្រឹមត្រូវនិងប្រកបដោយវិជ្ជាជីវះនិងធ្វើអោយប្រសើរឡើងនូវលក្ខ័ណ្ឌការងារនៅក្នុងឧស្សាហកម្មកាត់ដេរទាំងមូល។ខ្ញុំគិតថាប្រទេសកម្ពុជានឹងអាចធ្វើអោយមានការចំរើនទៅមុខនូវបញ្ហាមួយចំនួននេះដោយឆាប់រហ័សដូចជាការអភិវឌ្ឍន៏នូវប្រព័ន្ធដឹកជញ្ជូនមួយដែលមានសុវត្ថិភាពកាន់តែប្រសើរសំរាប់កម្មកររោងចក្រកាត់ដេរនិងស្វែងយល់បន្ថែមពីបញ្ហានៃការដួលសំឡប់នៃចំនួនកម្មករដ៏ច្រើននៅក្នុងរោងចក្រ។ខ្ញុំរង់ចាំដើម្បីធ្វើការងារជាមួយឯកឧត្តមរដ្ឋមន្រ្តីនិងក្រុមរបស់លោកនៅលើបញ្ហាទាំងអស់នោះ”៕"

        "eng": "  Matuto!          \n\n#Cambodia: get ready for amazing music with Matuto! The Embassy is proud to work with Amrita Performing Arts and the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts to host this five-member music group for FREE CONCERTS this week in the following locations:\n\n     :  \n     :  \n     :   \n     :   \n\nMay 19, 7:00 pm\nProvincial Department of Culture in Kratie \n\nMay 20, 7:00 pm\nProvincial Department of Culture in Stung Treng\n\nMay 21, 7:00 pm\nNear the Regional Teacher Training Center and the Provincial Department of Pedagogy in Kampong Cham\n\nMay 22, 7:00 pm\nRoyal University of Phnom Penh\n\nMatuto( )    New York         (Association of American Voices)       Facebook, Twitter (@MatutoMusic)  http://www.matutomusic.com  !\n\nMatuto - which is Brazilian slang for country boy - is emerging as one of New York Citys top music acts and draws inspiration from rural traditions found across the Americas. The band is here in #Cambodia as part of the American Music Abroad program, supported by the U.S. Department of State and implemented by the Association of American Voices. In addition to the free shows, they will be doing outreach activities with Cambodian youth and sharing their passion for music with others. To learn more about the band, follow them on Facebook, Twitter (@MatutoMusic) or visit http://www.matutomusic.com. We'll see you at the show!",

        "kh": "កម្ពុជាអ៊ើយសូមត្រៀមចូលរួមទស្សនាការប្រគំភ្លេងដ៏អស្ចារ្យមួយរបស់ក្រុមតន្រ្តីដែលមានឈ្មោះថាស្ថានទូតអាមេរិកមានមោទនភាពសូមសហការជាមួយអង្គការអម្រឹតាសិល្បៈនិងក្រសួងវប្បធម៌និងវិចិត្រសិល្បៈដើម្បីរៀបចំទទួលក្រុមតន្រ្តីដែលមានសមាជិក៥នាក់ហើយដែលនឹងមកប្រគំជូនដោយឥតគិតថ្លៃនៅសប្តាហ៍នេះតាមទីកន្លែងដូចខាងក្រោម៖•ថ្ងៃទី១៩ខែឧសភាម៉ោង៧០០យប់នៅមន្ទីរវប្បធម៌ខេត្តក្រចេះ•ថ្ងៃទី២០ខែឧសភាម៉ោង៧០០យប់នៅមន្ទីរវប្បធម៌ខេត្តស្ទឹងត្រែង•ថ្ងៃទី២១ខែឧសភាម៉ោង៧០០យប់នៅជិតមជ្ឈមណ្ឌលគរុកោសល្យភូមិភាគនិងមន្ទីរគរុកោសល្យខេត្តកំពង់ចាម•ថ្ងៃទី២២ខែឧសភាម៉ោង៧០០យប់នៅសាកលវិទ្យាល័យភូមិន្ទភ្នំពេញពាក្យក្នុងគ្រាមភាសារបស់ជនជាតិប្រេស៊ីលដែលមានន័យថា“កុមារាស្រុកស្រែ”គឺជាការប្រគំតន្រ្តីតាមបែបម្យ៉ាងមិនទៅតាមបែបរបស់មនុស្សនៅលោកខាងលិចហើយដែលមានការពេញនិយមខ្លាំងនៅទីក្រុងហើយយកលំនាំតាមប្រពៃណីនៅតាមជនបទនៅទូទាំងទ្វីបអាមេរិក។ក្រុមតន្រ្តីនេះនឹងធ្វើទស្សនកិច្ចនិងធ្វើការប្រគំនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជាជាផ្នែកមួយនៃកម្មវិធីតន្រ្តីអាមេរិកនៅបរទេសដែលឧបត្ថម្ភដោយក្រសួងការបរទេសសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកហើយរៀបចំដំណើរការដោយសមាគមសំលេងអាមេរិក។ក្រៅពីការប្រគំជូនដោយគ្មានការលក់សំបុត្រចូលទស្សនាសមាជិកនៃក្រុមតន្រ្តីនេះនឹងមានកមុ្មវិធីផងដែរជាមួយយុវជនកម្ពុជាហើយបង្ហាញពីការស្រឡាញ់របស់ពួកគេចំពោះតន្រ្តីដល់អ្នកឯទៀត។បើចង់ដឹងបន្ថែមទៀតស្តីពីក្រុមតន្រ្តីនេះសូមតាមដានតាមឬចូលមើលក្នុងគេហទំព័រ។ជួបគ្នានៅកន្លែងប្រគំតន្រ្តី“”’"

In her remarks, Julie reminded the students that Science, technology, engineering and math or #STEM, is at the core of every thriving society and encouraged them by saying that Software and equipment alone dont result in innovation. Its the ideas behind the tools that drive the way ahead.  It is all of you in Cambodia who will help fill the blank white page.         "eng": "Congratulations to Youth and Media Literacy in #Cambodia (YMLC) for being among this year's winners of the Alumni Engagement Innovation Fund (AIEF) competition! YMLC is a media training project developed by #YSEALI and U.S. exchange program alumni Cheng Mengchou, Borei Sylyvann, Ket Monny Vathna, and Lim Sreysros.     "2016-05-27T04:21:14+0000": {
        "eng": "    Heidt      (LICADHO / )             \n\n Heidt            \n\n         \n\nOn May 26, #AmbHeidt met with Dr. Pung Chhiv Kek, the president of the Cambodian League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights, or LICADHO, and members of her staff to discuss the NGO's work in #Cambodia. Dr. Kek - who founded LICADHO in 1992 after the signing of the Paris Peace Agreements - has worked tirelessly ever since to promote peace, non-violence, and respect for the rights of every Cambodian citizen.  \n\n#AmbHeidt said, I have known Madame Kek for nearly 20 years and remain deeply impressed by LICADHOs very principled work on a wide range of issues affecting all Cambodians, including the protection of civil, economic, and political rights. The United States is proud to support civil society organizations like LICADHO.\n\nLICADHO advocates for womens and childrens rights, provides humanitarian legal aid and social services to people in need, and works to expand awareness about political rights in Cambodia. Additionally, LICADHO helps communities learn how effectively advocate for and protect their own rights. It is one of a number of civil society organizations in Cambodia working to empower citizens, develop innovative solutions to challenges, and hold the government accountable to the people they represent. #humanrights",

    "2016-05-27T10:41:39+0000": {
        "eng": "Preah Vihear Temple was closed for security reasons during my first tour in #Cambodia and I have wanted to visit it ever since. Sotie and I were incredibly impressed by the mountaintop location and the excellent condition of many parts of the temple. It is a remarkable cultural asset that all Cambodians should be proud of. - #AmbHeidt \n\nThe Ambassador and his wife Sotie visited the spectacular temples of Preah Vihear and Koh Ker on May 24. These temples are being preserved and protected by the Cambodian government thanks to the contributions of people like Dr. Kim Sedara, an alumnus of The Fulbright Program and Chairman of the National Authority of Preah Vihear (NAPV). The Ambassador met NAPV representatives, Member of Parliament H.E. Yara Suos, and officials from the Ministries of Interior, Culture and Fine Arts, and Tourism to discuss projects being implemented through partnerships like ICC-Preah Vihear. While there has been significant progress in protecting the temples, much work is still needed to ensure the full protection of these historic landmarks and to increase the number of people that can visit them. \n\nThe temple sites of Preah Vihear and Koh Ker are two of the most remarkable examples of ancient Khmer architecture found in #Cambodia. Preah Vihear Temple is one of the two cultural sites in Cambodia listed on UNESCO's World Heritage List (the other is Angkor). The temple's history can be traced to the 9th century and due to its location atop a 525-meter cliff, the site has been very well preserved. Koh Ker is another remote temple location, about 2.5 hours from Siem Reap. More than 50 temples are currently open to visitors at the site, including the pyramid-shaped Prasat Thom and Prasat Chen. \n\nVisit www.flickr.com/photos/usembassyphnompenh/ for more photos of the Ambassador and Sotie's visit to Preah Vihear and Koh Ker. And to learn more about what the United States to help preserve Cambodia's cultural heritage, log on to: http://cambodia.usembassy.gov/cultural_assistance.html.",

    "2016-06-02T08:13:17+0000": {
        "eng": "\"The key innovation of Feed the Future is that it goes beyond simply feeding people and tackles the problem at its source...In #Cambodia, that means addressing the challenges faced by rural farmers and families, who form the backbone of Cambodias agricultural sector. It means educating farmers about agricultural techniques and management practices. It means teaching them better business strategies. It means connecting them with input suppliers and markets both here and abroad. It also means working hand-in-hand with our national and provincial partners and with the private sector, who will carry this work forward over the long term.\" - #AmbHeidt\n\nAmbassador Heidt joined Deputy Prime Minister H.E. Dr. Yim Chhay Ly at the Intercontinental Hotel this morning to commemorate five years of the U.S. government's Feed the Future programs in Cambodia. Farmers, policy makers, donors, government officials, private companies, and members of civil society will be in Phnom Penh from June 2-3 to review the significant achievements in #agriculture, #nutrition, and poverty reduction that have taken place through the Feed the Future initiative, implemented by USAID Cambodia in cooperation with the Royal Government of Cambodia. The United States is proud of this successful partnership and recognizes that strong leadership from the Cambodian government in the agriculture sector is critical to future progress.     "2016-06-04T10:02:54+0000": {
        "eng": "In the 1920s, a popular American band known as Waring's Pennsylvanians recorded a song called \"I Scream, You Scream, We All Scream for Ice Cream.\" Almost 100 years later, people still love ice cream, including here in #Cambodia. So we're very excited about the arrival of Cold Stone Creamery to the Kingdom!\n\nFounded in 1988 in the U.S. state of Arizona, Cold Stone Creamery is one of the latest American companies to bring quality customer service and job opportunities to Cambodia. #AmbHeidt was at the official opening of Cold Stone Creamery Cambodia, located in Phnom Penh on Kampuchea Krom Boulevard (Street 128) next to Asia Euro University (AEU). Cambodia is now among 29 countries in the world with a Cold Stone Creamery store. With a wide variety of flavors and toppings, customers can try one of Cold Stone Creamery's signature items or even make their own ice cream creation.         "eng": "?       Golden West     Villanova  Pennsylvania              \n\n!   Liger  Development Innovations Cambodia  (USAID)           \n\n?  \n\nWhat would you get a robot to do for you? The potential of robots was discussed last Friday at the inaugural Conference on Robotics in #Cambodia, a joint endeavor by the U.S.-based NGO GOLDEN WEST HUMANITARIAN FOUNDATION, MoEYS Cambodia, and Villanova University in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania. With funding from the U.S. Department of State, Cambodian engineers have collaborated with U.S. university students to develop robots that can be used for demining efforts. In addition to these projects, the conference introduced Cambodian students to opportunities in #STEM and served as a platform for how future technology could be used in Cambodia.\n\nYoung children in Cambodia are also excited about robots! Last month, the Liger Learning Center and Development Innovations Cambodia - supported by USAID Cambodia - hosted an event called \"Robotics Basics\" that introduced robotics to students in grades 4-6. The students were able to share their knowledge and enthusiasm while encouraging others to learn more about robotics.\n\nWhat do you think about the impact that robots can have in Cambodia?         "eng": "Archaeologists have utilized light detection and ranging technology  - or LIDAR - to detect evidence of large, medieval cities hidden beneath the forest floor in #Cambodia. The research, released on Monday in the Journal of Archaeological Science, provides details about multiple cities that are between 900-1,400 years old, some of which were larger than the size of Phnom Penh.\n\n\"The new LIDAR survey is so exciting,\" says U.S. archaeologist Dr. Alison Carter, a Visiting Assistant Professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. \"There are plenty of opportunities for young Cambodians to take part in researching their culture and heritage. I hope this will also encourage them to take the lead on preserving these sites.\" To read the full story about the LIDAR study, visit https://goo.gl/Ur14Em.\n\n(Photo: AP Photo/Heng Sinith)",

        "kh": "សូមអបអរសាទរនិស្សិតអាហារូបករណ៍ងួនភក្តីឬយកល្អគួរហៅគាត់ថាបណ្ឌិតងួនភក្តីចំពោះការដែលគាត់បានទទួលសញ្ញាបណ្ឌិតផ្នែកភូមិវិទ្យាពីសាកលវិទ្យាល័យក្នុងរដ្ឋ។ក្នុងពេលថ្មីៗនេះគាត់បានធ្វើដំណើរទៅសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកជាមួយគ្រួសារដើម្បីទទួលសញ្ញាប័ត្របណ្ឌិតនៅក្នុងពិធីទទួលសញ្ញាប័ត្រដ៏ពិសេសមួយ។បណ្ឌិតភក្តីពេលនេះកំពុងតែប្រើប្រាស់ចំណេះដឹងនិងបទពិសោធន៍របស់គាត់នៅក្នុងការងារអភិរក្សបរិស្ថានដើម្បីតាក់តែងគោលនយោបាយសំរាប់ការអភិវឌ្ឍន៍សេដ្ឋកិច្ចប្រកបដោយនិរន្តភាពនិងលុបបំបាត់ភាពក្រីក្រខ្លាំងនៅកម្ពុជា។គាត់មានសេចក្តីរីករាយជាខ្លាំងចំពោះការបានទទួលឱកាសពីកម្មវិធីអាហារូបករណ៍។លោកបណ្ឌិតបានមានប្រសាសន៍ថា“វាជាការសំខាន់ដែលគេអាចបង្ហាញអោយឃើញនូវភាពអាចអោយគេមានជំនឿមកលើខ្លួនក្នុងនាមជាអ្នកស្រាវជ្រាវម្នាក់នៅពេលចុះធ្វើការតាមមូលដ្ឋាន។អាហារូបករណ៍ពីកម្មវិធីមានមកយូរហើយដែលជាការធ្វើអោយគេស្គាល់ភ្លាមៗ។ខ្ញុំសូមសារភាពថាការបានធ្វើជាអ្នកទទួលបានអាហារូបករណ៍ពីកម្មវិធីនេះពិតជាបានជួយច្រើននៅពេលខ្ញុំចុះធ្វើការនៅប្រទេសកម្ពុជា”។បើចង់ដឹងបន្ថែមស្តីពីកម្មវិធីអប់រំដែលឧបត្ថម្ភដោយរដ្ឋាភិបាលសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកសូមចូលមើលគេហទំព័រ។"

    "2016-06-23T10:46:08+0000": {
        "eng": "\"I was pleased to see the U.S.-supported Mine Action Planning Unit and discuss #Cambodias international leadership in the humanitarian mine action sector with newly-appointed Cambodian Mine Action Authority (CMAA) Secretary General and Senior Minister Ly Thuch this morning. For more than 20 years, the United States has partnered with Cambodia, donor governments and international organizations to clear landmines and other explosive remnants of war, restoring lands and livelihoods to Cambodians across the country.\" -#AmbHeidt  \n\nThe annual casualty rate from landmines and other explosive remnants of war in Cambodia has decreased from over 4,000 per year two decades ago to under 200 today. Despite this significant progress, Cambodia remains in the top five countries in the world for mine and unexploded ordnance casualties, and contaminated land hurts the poor more than anyone. The United States is committed to its partnership with CMAA and others to help raise the profile of mine clearance activities and efficiently prioritize resources in Cambodia in order to make the country mine-free by 2025 in accordance with the Maputo Declaration. For the full text of this agreement, visit www.icbl.org/media/2146336/Maputo-plus-15-_Declaration.pdf.",

    "2016-07-01T02:43:04+0000": {
        "eng": "Ambassador Heidt and the U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh congratulate Deputy Chair of the National Committee to Combat Trafficking (NCCT) Chou Bun Eng on #Cambodias upgrade to Tier 2 in the 2016 U.S. Department of State's Trafficking in Persons Report. Cambodias improved ranking this year reflects the strong leadership shown by the NCCT and acknowledges the governments significant efforts to bring itself into compliance with the minimum standards set out in the Trafficking Victims Protection Act  a U.S. law originally passed in 2000. The Trafficking in Persons Report assesses a governments efforts to prevent Trafficking in Persons, to protect victims, and to prosecute criminals.  It also offers recommendations for how countries can improve in each of these areas.\n\nDuring remarks at a ceremony to launch the report, Secretary of State John Kerry singled out the story of a Cambodian named Lang Long, who was rescued after being forced into slavery on a fishing vessel. Lang Long represents the 20 million people around the world who continue to be victims of Trafficking in Persons.\n\nFor more about the Trafficking in Persons Report, visit http://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/. To read the 2016 Country Report for Cambodia (a Khmer translation will be posted soon to the U.S. Embassy website), go to http://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2016/258738.htm. To read the Secretarys remarks, see http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2016/06/259227.htm.",

    "2016-07-04T04:19:07+0000": {
        "eng": " William Heidt     \n()\n\n         \n\n               \n\n           \n\n                   \n\n           \n\n            \n\n          \n\n                  \n\n                 \n\nA SPECIAL JULY 4TH MESSAGE FROM AMBASSADOR HEIDT\n(as seen in The Phnom Penh Post)\n\nOn November 8, the American people will come together to select a new President of the United States, along with thousands of other federal, state, and local ofcials. This years election is shaping up to be one of the most hotly contested in our history, with strong views on both sides. \n\nDespite the rhetoric and passion of the election, no matter who wins, the fundamental principles of our democracy will remain intact. The winners will celebrate, the losers will concede, and the decision of the American people will be respected, as it has been for more than two centuries. The candidates and the political parties will put the election behind them. The winners will get on with the business of governing; the losers will start getting ready for the next election.  \n\nThere is more than one recipe for democracy. What works for the United States may not necessarily work for Cambodia. But in any democracy, political forces must share a basic acceptance that their opponents have a legitimate right to engage in politics.  Politicians from all sides may not agree on the issues, or even like each other, but they must accept that their opponents have the right to advocate for their interests, and treat them accordingly.  \n\nI have gotten to know many of the leaders of the government and opposition since I returned to Cambodia nine months ago. By and large, they are good and patriotic people trying to do their best for Cambodia. But neither side seems to accept the other as legitimate. Little more than a year after the Culture of Dialogue was announced, once again I see little respect or polite discourse in contemporary Cambodian politics. When it comes to accepting the right of your opponent to pursue his interests  the essence of reconciliation  I feel saddened to say that there has been little progress on either side since my previous assignment here in the late 1990s.\n\nIf Cambodian democracy is going to endure, as the Cambodian people clearly want, politicians from all sides need to separate the political from the personal. They need to understand that two sides can disagree about the direction of the nation while sharing a love for the country, its citizens, and its institutions. They need, above all, to recognize the good in each other.\n\nThere is a fundamental difference between disagreeing with your opponent and considering him or her to be an enemy. Politicians in the United States have radically different points of view on every issue imaginable. But our best politicians  our statesmen and stateswomen  respect their opponents right to pursue their interests and compete in elections. They know that calling each other traitors, or challenging each others patriotism, cheapen our politics.\n\nIn all honesty, it has not always been that way. In the early part of our history our politicians often engaged in stghts and worse, and it took many years of bitter politics for them to realize that this was counter-productive to their interests, and the interests of the nation.\n\nSince arriving in Cambodia as the U.S. Ambassador last September, I have been amazed with the progress that this country has made since the 1990s. The economy is booming, the infra-structure is more developed, the people are healthier and more educated, and civil society is stronger. Cambodias youth are optimistic, proud of their country, and eager to participate in shaping its future. Cambodia has overcome many obstacles over the years, but the inability of Cambodias political leaders to work with each other for the benet of the nation continues to prevent this great country from reaching its full potential. \n\nOn July 4, we will celebrate the 240th anniversary of the independence of the United States of America. We have been through many ups and downs over the years, but over time our democracy has not just survived but ourished. The work of democracy is never nished, but we are making progress. As a friend of Cambodia, it is my earnest hope that both the government and opposition can reach out to each other in a spirit of patriotism and reconciliation to do the same.\n\n#AmbHeidt #Cambodia #USA #July4th", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153840811273224", 
        "kh": "សារពិសេសរបស់លោកឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតអាមេរិកក្នុងឱកាសបុណ្យឯករាជ្យជាតិ៤កក្កដានៃសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកដូចមានចុះនៅក្នុងកាសែតភ្នំពេញប៉ុស្តនៅថ្ងៃទី៨ខែវិច្ឆិកាខាងមុខនេះពលរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនឹងនាំគ្នាទៅបោះឆ្នោតដើម្បីជ្រើសរើសប្រធានាធិបតីថ្មីរបស់ខ្លួនរួមទាំងរើសមន្ត្រីមូលដ្ឋានមន្ត្រីតាមរដ្ឋនិងមន្ត្រីសហព័ន្ធជាច្រើនពាន់នាក់ផ្សេងទៀត។ការបោះឆ្នោតនៅឆ្នាំនេះត្រូវបានគេចាត់ទុកថាជាព្រឹត្តិការណ៍ប្រកួតប្រជែងដ៏ក្តៅគគុកបំផុតមួយនៅក្នុងប្រវត្តិសាស្ត្រខណៈដែលបក្ខជននៃបក្សទាំងពីរមានទស្សនៈច្បាស់លាស់រៀងៗខ្លួន។បើទោះជាវោហារសាស្រ្តនិងទឹកចិត្តពុះកញ្ជ្រោលនក្នុងការបោះឆ្នោតមានលក្ខណៈបែបណាក្តីតែគោលការណ៍ស្នូលនៃលទ្ធិប្រជាធិបតេយ្យរបស់យើងនឹងនៅតែដដែល។អ្នកឈ្នះឈ្នះដោយរីករាយអ្នកចាញ់ចាញ់ដោយអស់ចិត្តហើយការសំរចចិត្តរបស់ពលរដ្ឋអាមេរិកនឹងត្រូវបានគោរពដូចដែលគេបានធ្វើជាង២០០ឆ្នាំមកហើយ។ក្រោយពេលបោះឆ្នោតរួចបេក្ខជននិងគណបក្សនយោបាយបំភ្លេចរឿងបោះឆ្នោត។អ្នកឈ្នះនឹងត្រូវឡើងដឹកនាំប្រទេសខណៈអ្នកចាញ់នឹងត្រៀមខ្លួនសម្រាប់ការបោះឆ្នោតលើកក្រោយ។លក្ខណៈប្រជាធិបតេយ្យមិនដូចគ្នាទាំងអស់នោះទេ។អ្វីដែលដំណើរការនៅសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកមិនប្រាកដថាអាចដំណើរការនៅកម្ពុជាបាននោះទេ។តែបើទោះជាប្រជាធិបតេយ្យនោះមានលក្ខណៈបែបណាក្តីក៏កម្លាំងនយោបាយទាំងអស់ត្រូវទទួលយកគោលការណ៍គ្រឹះដែលថាគូបដិបក្ខរបស់ពួកគេមានសិទ្ធិស្របច្បាប់ក្នុងការធ្វើសកម្មភាពនយោបាយ។អ្នកនយោបាយមកពីគ្រប់ភាគីទាំងអស់អាចមានមតិផ្ទុយគ្នាលើបញ្ហានានាឬអាចមិនចូលចិត្តគ្នាក៏ថាបានក៏ប៉ុន្តែពួកគេត្រូវទទួលយកការពិតថាគូបដិបក្ខរបស់ខ្លួនមានសិទ្ធិតស៊ូមតិដើម្បីការពារផលប្រយោជន៍របស់ពួកគេហើយដែលភាគីម្ខាងទៀតត្រូវគោរព។ខ្ញុំមានឱកាសបានស្គាល់មេដឹកនាំរដ្ឋាភិបាលនិងមន្ត្រីបក្សប្រឆាំងជាច្រើនតាំងពីខ្ញុំបានវិលត្រឡប់មកកម្ពុជាវិញកាលពី៩ខែមុន។ជារួមពួកគេជាមនុស្សល្អស្នេហាជាតិហើយកំពុងខិតខំធ្វើការងារសម្រាប់ភាពល្អប្រសើររបស់កម្ពុជា។ប៉ុន្តែគ្មានភាគីណាមួយហាក់ទទួលយកភាពស្របច្បាប់របស់ភាគីមួយផ្សេងទៀតនោះទេ។ជាងមួយឆ្នាំក្រោយការប្រកាសវប្បធម៌សន្ទនាខ្ញុំឃើញមានការសន្ទនាក្នុងលក្ខណៈគោរពគ្នាឬផ្អែមល្ហែមដាក់គ្នាបានកើតឡើងតិចតួចណាស់។នៅពេលនិយាយដល់ការទទួលស្គាល់សិទ្ធិរបស់គូបដិបក្ខក្នុងការធ្វើការដើម្បីផលប្រយោជន៍របស់គេដែលជាចំណុចសំខាន់នៃការផ្សះផ្សានោះខ្ញុំមើលឃើញថាវាមានការរីកចម្រើនតិចតួចណាស់របស់ភាគីទាំងពីរតាំងពីខ្ញុំមកបំពេញបេសកកម្មនៅកម្ពុជាលើកដំបូងក្នុងអំឡុងចុងទសវត្សរ៍១៩៩០។ប្រសិនបើចង់ឲ្យប្រជាធិបតេយ្យនៅកម្ពុជារឹងមាំដូចដែលពលរដ្ឋខ្មែរចង់បានមែននោះអ្នកនយោបាយមកពីគ្រប់ភាគីទាំងអស់ចាំបាច់ត្រូវបែងចែកឲ្យដាច់ស្រឡះរវាងការងារនយោបាយនិងបញ្ហាផ្ទាល់ខ្លួន។ពួកគេចាំបាច់ត្រូវយល់ថាភាគីទាំងពីរអាចមានទស្សនៈផ្ទុយគ្នាលើទិសដែលប្រទេសជាតិត្រូវដើរតាមតែគេត្រូវមានដូចគ្នានូវសេចក្តីស្រឡាញ់ចំពោះប្រទេសជាតិចំពោះពលរដ្ឋនិងស្ថាប័នរបស់ប្រទេស។ជារួមពួកគេត្រូវទទួលស្គាល់ចំណុចល្អរបស់គ្នាទៅវិញទៅមក។វាមានភាពខុសគ្នារវាងការមិនយល់ស្របគ្នាជាមួយគូបដិបក្ខនិងការចាត់ទុកគូបដិបក្ខថាជាសត្រូវ។អ្នកនយោបាយនៅសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកតែងមានទស្សនៈឬការយល់ឃើញផ្ទុយស្រឡះពីគ្នាសឹងគ្រប់រឿងទាំងអស់ប៉ុន្តែអ្នកនយោបាយបុរសរដ្ឋស្រ្តីរដ្ឋរបស់យើងគោរពសិទ្ធិគូបដិបក្ខរបស់ពួកគេក្នុងការធ្វើការដើម្បីអ្វីដែលគេចង់បាននិងសិទ្ធិក្នុងការប្រកួតប្រជែងនៅក្នុងការបោះឆ្នោត។ពួកគេដឹងថាការហៅគ្នាថាជាជនក្បត់ជាតិឬការចោទសួរពីទឹកចិត្តស្នេហាជាតិរបស់គ្នាទៅវិញទៅមកនឹងធ្វើឲ្យបាត់តម្លៃនយោបាយរបស់យើង។និយាយអោយត្រង់ទៅវាក៏មិនមែនមានន័យថាសុទ្ធតែអញ្ចឹងទាំងអស់នោះទេ។នៅគ្រាដំបូងនៃប្រវត្តិសាស្ត្ររបស់យើងអ្នកនយោបាយយើងជាញឹកញាប់វាយតប់គ្នាហើយបន្ទាប់ពីការធ្វើនយោបាយដ៏ជូចត់អស់ជាច្រើនឆ្នាំទើបគេដឹងថាការធ្វើដូច្នេះផ្ទុយទៅនឹងប្រយោជន៍របស់គេនិងប្រយោជន៍របស់ប្រទេសជាតិ។តាំងពីពេលខ្ញុំមកដល់កម្ពុជាក្នុងនាមជាឯកអគ្គរដ្ឋទូតសហរដ្ឋអាមេរិកប្រចាំកម្ពុជាកាលពីខែកញ្ញាមកខ្ញុំស្ញប់ស្ញែងនឹងការរីកចម្រើនរបស់កម្ពុជាតាំងពីទសវត្សរ៍១៩៩០។សេដ្ឋកិច្ចកំពុងរីកលូតលាស់ហេដ្ឋារចនាសម្ព័ន្ធកំពុងមានការអភិវឌ្ឍពលរដ្ឋមានសុខភាពប្រសើរជាងមុនមានការអប់រំជាងមុនហើយសង្គមស៊ីវិលមានភាពរឹងមាំជាងមុន។យុវជនកម្ពុជាមានសុទិដ្ឋិនិយមនិងមោទនភាពចំពោះប្រទេសរបស់ខ្លួននិងចង់ចូលរួមក្នុងការកំណត់អនាគតរបស់កម្ពុជា។កម្ពុជាបានជំនះឧបសគ្គជាច្រើនក្នុងរយៈពេលជាច្រើនឆ្នាំមកនេះប៉ុន្តែការដែលថ្នាក់ដឹកនាំនយោបាយរបស់កម្ពុជាមិនអាចធ្វើការជាមួយគ្នាបានដើម្បីនាំមកនូវផលប្រយោជន៍សម្រាប់ប្រទេសជាតិបន្តធ្វើឲ្យប្រទេសនេះមិនអាចឈានទៅសម្រេចបាននូវសក្ដានុពលពេញលេញរបស់ខ្លួន។នៅថ្ងៃទី៤កក្កដាយើងនឹងប្រារព្ធខួប២៤០ឆ្នាំនៃឯករាជ្យជាតិរបស់សហរដ្ឋអាមេរិក។ប្រទេសជាតិយើងបានឆ្លងកាត់ការឡើងចុះជាបន្តបន្ទាប់ក្នុងរយៈពេលជាច្រើនឆ្នាំមកតែក្រោយៗមកលទ្ធិប្រជាធិបតេយ្យរបស់យើងមិនត្រឹមតែរស់រានមានជីវិតប៉ុណ្ណោះទេតែថែមទាំងរីកដុះដាលថែមទៀតផង។ការងារលើលទ្ធិប្រជាធិបតេយ្យគ្មានថ្ងៃបញ្ចប់ឡើយតែយើងកំពុងតែធ្វើឲ្យវារីកចម្រើន។ក្នុងនាមជាមិត្តរបស់កម្ពុជាខ្ញុំសង្ឃឹមយ៉ាងមុតមាំថាទាំងរដ្ឋាភិបាលទាំងបក្សប្រឆាំងរបស់កម្ពុជាអាចឈោងរកគ្នាទៅវិញទៅមកក្នុងស្មារតីស្នេហាជាតិនិងការផ្សះផ្សាដើម្បីធ្វើការងារសម្រាប់ប្រទេសជាតិដូចគ្នា។ﬁ’“”––––’’ﬁﬁ’’ﬁﬂﬁ"

    "2016-07-05T09:13:03+0000": {
        "eng": "Approximately 200 representatives from government, trade unions, private sector, civil society, and universities in #Cambodia gathered at the Raffles Hotel in Phnom Penh today for the annual National Industrial Relations Conference (NIRC). Joined by Minister of Labor H.E. Ith Sam Heng, Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung spoke at the event, which focused on industrial relations in Cambodia within the context of the country's competitiveness within ASEAN economic integration. The NIRC was organized by The Arbitration Council, which is also implementing a three-year project supported by USAID Cambodia entitled Upholding Labor Rights for Women and Men in Cambodia. To see the full remarks by DCM Julie Chung, please visit http://go.usa.gov/x3vr4.\n\n         Rafles Hotel         Julie Chung             USAID       Julie Chung  http://go.usa.gov/x3vr4 ",

    "2016-07-06T11:13:57+0000": {
        "eng": "Today, the  Ministry of Commerce hosted a press conference on the expansion of the U.S. General System of Preferences (GSP). The GSP expansion - which went into effect July 1 - means that #Cambodia can now export travel goods such as luggage, handbags, and wallets, duty free to the United States.   Ambassador Heidt, Minister of Commerce H.E. Pan Sorasak, and Chairman of GMAC - Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia Mr. Van Sou Leng welcomed the expansion as an opportunity to increase exports and create up to 100,000 jobs in Cambodia.  \n\nThis announcement has the potential to open up an entirely new market for Cambodian exporters and to create thousands of jobs for Cambodians,\" says #AmbHeidt. \"We encourage Cambodian manufacturers to take advantage of this new opportunity, which would help to diversify Cambodias economic base, spur economic growth, and alleviate poverty. To learn more about GSP, visit https://ustr.gov/issue-areas/trade-development/preference-programs/generalized-system-preference-gsp.",

        "eng": "Congratulations to #YSEALI Generation: EARTH alumni - also known as Team #Greennovators - for receiving a grant to fund their youth environmental education program entitled, Eco-Inspire-Ers! I also receive encouragement from other Cambodian YSEALI Alumni.         "kh": "សូមអបអរសាទរដល់អតីតសមាជិកក្រុមនៃគំរោងដែលត្រូវបានស្គាល់ផងដែរថាជាក្រុមចំពោះការបានទទួលអំណោយថវិកាសំរាប់កម្មវិធីអប់រំបរិស្ថានរបស់យុវជនដែលមានឈ្មោះថា។កម្មវិធីនេះនឹងចាប់ផ្តើមដោយរៀបចំសិក្ខាសាលាពិភាក្សាស្តីពីបរិស្ថាននៅកម្ពុជាដូចជាការគ្រប់គ្រងកាកសំណល់ការគ្រប់គ្រងធនធានធម្មជាតិស្ថានភាពបរិស្ថាននិងការរស់នៅដែលធានានិរន្តភាព។សឿនវឌ្ឍនៈដែលជាសមាជិកម្នាក់បាននិយាយថា“ខ្ញុំរីករាយណាស់ដែលអាចធ្វើការងារនេះបាន។ខ្ញុំបានធ្វើការស្ម័គ្រចិត្តជាច្រើនឆ្នាំមកហើយតែនេះជាលើកដំបូងសំរាប់ខ្ញុំក្នុងការដឹកនាំគំរោងបែបនេះ។ខ្ញុំបានរៀនសូត្រច្រើនពីអ្នកណែនាំរបស់ខ្ញុំនិងពីអង្គការនានាដូចជាអង្គការ។ខ្ញុំបានទទួលផងដែរនូវការជួយពីអតីតសមាជិកដទៃទៀតនៅកម្ពុជា។យើងចង់អោយមានការផ្លាស់ប្តូរនៅកម្ពុជា។ដូច្នេះយើងបង្រៀនមនុស្សជំនាន់ក្រោយនូវទំលាប់ល្អទាក់ទងនឹងបរិស្ថានហើយសង្ឃឹមថានឹងបំផុសអោយអ្នកដទៃបង្កើតគំរោងរបស់គេផ្ទាល់។បើចង់ដឹងបន្ថែមពីកម្មវិធីនេះសូមចូលមើលហ្វេសបុករបស់គំរោង។តើលោកអ្នកជាសមាជិកឬទេសូមស្វែងយល់ពីការដែលលោកអ្នកអាចធ្វើទំនាក់ទំនងជាមួយមេដឹកនាំយុវជនដទៃទៀតតាម។"

    "2016-07-08T10:48:56+0000": {
        "eng": "BREAKING NEWS: U.S. Department of State Announces First-Ever \nNBA-WNBA Sports Envoy Program to #Cambodia!\n !\n\nThe U.S. Department of State, in collaboration with the National Basketball Association (#NBA) and Womens National Basketball Association (#WNBA), will send Wayne Ellington and Sue Wicks as Sports Envoys to Phnom Penh, Cambodia, July 1217. The Sports Envoys will develop skills and generate even more interest in Cambodia for one of the world's most popular sports.  Cambodian youth will not only learn and improve basketball skills; the Sports Envoys will also focus on teamwork, effective communication, building self-esteem, and other lessons learned through playing basketball.\n\nThe U.S. Embassy is working together with MoEYS Cambodia, the National Olympic Committee Of Cambodia, the Cambodia Basketball Federation, and the Fulbright and Undergraduate State Alumni Association of Cambodia (FUSAAC) to host the Sports Envoys and organize a wide range of activities throughout the week.  Among these are two signature events that are free and open to the public:\n\n July 14, 9:00 am  A basketball court renovation project at Wat Koh High School in Phnom Penh, open to volunteers from the local community.\n July 15, 5:00 pm  Special event at the National Olympic Stadium in Phnom Penh, with basketball games, musical performances, and more.\n\nSports Envoys are athletes and coaches who travel overseas to lead programs developed by U.S. embassies and consulates. The Sports Envoys hold clinics for young people and coaches, participate in community outreach activities, and engage youth in a dialogue on the importance of leadership and respect for diversity. SportsUnited - U.S. Department of State manages the Sports Envoy programs, working in cooperation with the U.S. Olympic Committee, U.S. sports federations, and professional leagues. Stay tuned for more information about the NBA-WNBA Sports Envoy Program in Cambodia!\n\n   Wayne Ellington  Sue Wicks                     \n\n       Fulbright          \n\n          \n          \n\n               SportsUnited    \n\nNBA Cares",

        "eng": "                             \n\n https://kh.usembassy.gov/km/statement-john-kirby-spokesperson-death-prominent-cambodian-political-commentator-dr-kem-ley-km/  John Kirby  \n\nU.S. Embassy Phnom Penh, Cambodia shares in the Cambodian people's outrage and grief over the brutal murder of Dr. Kem Ley. Dr. Ley was a brave critic of injustice wherever he saw it. We are honored that he generously shared his wisdom and expertise with us on issues ranging from health to worker rights to education and democracy. If there was a single theme that united his work, it was a belief in Cambodias future and its people. Though Dr. Leys voice was silenced, we are confident his spirit was not. The United States stands by the people of Cambodia in this time of sorrow.\n\nVisit http://go.usa.gov/xc7PG for an official U.S. Department of State statement from Assistant Secretary and Spokesperson John Kirby.\n\n#Cambodia #KemLey #RIP",

        "eng": "USAID Cambodia recently announced a new project that focuses on strengthening the organizational and technical capacity of civil society organizations (CSOs) and grassroots networks in #Cambodia. The Cambodian Civil Society Strengthening (CCSS) project - awarded to the East-West Management Institute - will help CSOs improve their management, planning, and analytical skills while enabling them to play a more active role in Cambodia's economic and political development.         "eng": "    Heidt  USS Ronald Reagan (CVN 76)     U.S. Navy c-2 Greyhound           !     \n\n     Yokosuka           http://www.navy.mil/navydata/ships/carriers/cv-list.asp  \n\nOn July 7, #AmbHeidt visited the USS Ronald Reagan (CVN 76), one of 10 U.S. Navy aircraft carriers that are in active service. He arrived via a U.S. Navy C-2 Greyhound airplane, undergoing an arrested landing and experiencing a catapult launch on the way back to #Cambodia. During his time aboard the ship, the Ambassador observed flight operations, talked with senior leadership, and also met the ship's \"Sailor of the Year\" and learned that she is married to a Cambodian! This visit was an amazing experience, showcasing U.S. military-to-military capability and underscoring our mutual interest in regional maritime security.  \n\nSince August 2015, the USS Ronald Reagans home port has been Yokosuka, Japan. The ship has an established history of operating in the Pacific. This includes providing assistance after the 2011 tsunami in Japan, which ably demonstrated the ships potential for contributing to regional security.         "eng": "Wildscan      USAID  Wildlife Alliance  Freeland    \n\nWildscan - a mobile app used to help in the fight against illegal wildlife trading - recently launched in #Cambodia with Khmer translation. USAID Cambodia, Wildlife Alliance and Freeland  organized a launch event at the Phnom Tamao Wildlife Rescue Centre, giving participants the chance to test the new app's features.  \n\n             Wildscan      \n\nI think that having WildScan in Khmer will benefit law enforcement in the country, said Khem Vuthyravong, Project Manager for Wildlife Alliances Wildlife Rapid Rescue Team, which has rescued over 62,000 live animals from the wildlife trade since 2001. It is easy to use, allowing for everyone to quickly identify a range of different animals.\n \nWildscan  Adroid  Iphone               http://freeland.org//wildlife-identification-app-launches/  \n\nWildScan  available on both Android and Apple mobile devices  has been downloaded more than 1,000 times and is available in six Southeast Asian languages, with more to be added in the future. With information and photos for more than 500 animals and products, the app can also be used as an effective education tool.         "eng": "SECURITY MESSAGE FOR U.S. CITIZENS: #KemLey Funeral Procession\nJuly 24, 2016\n\nThe U.S. Embassy in Phnom Penh notifies U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to #Cambodia of the planned funeral procession for Kem Ley in Phnom Penh on Sunday, July 24, 2016. The funeral procession is scheduled to depart from the Wat Chas pagoda near the Sokha Hotel at 7:00 A.M. The procession is reportedly planned to proceed across the Japanese Bridge to Monivong Boulevard and Russian Boulevard until it reaches the Chom Chao roundabout near the Phnom Penh International Airport. The procession will then continue on National Road 3 to Takeo Province. News reports indicate participants could number in the tens of thousands and the procession is likely to take several hours.\n\nFor more details, please visit go.usa.gov/xr3xA.",

An overflow crowd of 350 people joined a community forum at the La Lune Imperial Restaurant in Long Beach.     "2016-07-26T05:19:22+0000": {
        "eng": "   (ADA)      \n\n (ICRC)          \n\n        ICRC     \nhttps://www.icrc.org/en/document/cambodia-queen-mother-mines-womens-wheelchair-basketball \n\nToday marks the 26th anniversary of the American with Disabilities Act (#ADA26), a civil rights law that would inspire the world to promote equal opportunity and address discrimination faced by persons with disabilities. \nIn the spirit of the ADA, we would like to recognize the amazing members of  #Cambodia's Wheelchair Basketball Federation (CWBF).\n\nEstablished with support from the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), players on the Cambodian Women's Wheelchair Basketball team from Battambang and Kampong Speu provinces came to Phnom Penh for the July 15 NBA-WNBA Sports Envoy event at Olympic Stadium. For the thousands of people in the audience and viewing live via Facebook, watching the players' amazing talents and passion for the game was the highlight of the event.\n\nSome members of the CWBF were also granted an audience with Her Majesty Queen Mother Norodom Monineath Sihanouk, who offered to lend assistance to the construction of a new roof for the basketball court at the ICRC's physical rehabilitation center in Battambang.         "eng": " John Kerry                     \n\n Kerry   http://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2016/07/260446.htm  \n\nLast September, we launched a Womens Business Center in #Cambodia. This project has already helped to create more than 60 businesses, 250 new jobs, and were going to be starting a parallel center in Vietnam this year. The reason is very straightforward: No country in the world can get ahead if it leaves half its population behind. And in most countries, women are half the population or more.         "eng": "The US-ASEAN Business Council (USABC) recently organized an impressive delegation of U.S. companies to visit #Cambodia for their annual mission. Representatives from ConocoPhillips, GE, Coca-Cola, Visa, P&G, Ford Motor Company, RMA Cambodia, and Herbalife met a number of government officials - including Prime Minister Hun Sen and Minister of Commerce Pan Sorasak - to express their commitment to the U.S.-Cambodia business relationship and to supporting Cambodias development efforts.  The USABC missions goals were to encourage the Royal Government of Cambodia to implement better governance and transparency, to push for deeper stakeholder engagement in policy formation, and to highlight the U.S. business communitys support for capacity building, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and human resources in Cambodia. More about USABC's activities in Cambodia is at www.usasean.org/countries/cambodia/about.\n\nPHOTO CREDIT: Khem Sovannara, AKP Phnom Penh",

    "2016-07-28T08:20:48+0000": {
        "eng": " ?       ,     %    %     B  %       \n\n B         UNICEF, Gavi  (Vaccine Alliance)  (CDC)         http://www.who.int/campaigns/hepatitis-day/2016/en/ \n\nDid you know that today is #WorldHepatitisDay? Viral hepatitis is the 7th leading cause of death in the world, with about 1.4 million people falling victim to the disease each year. Although treatments and vaccines exist, less than 5% of people with chronic hepatitis know they have it and less than 1% have access to treatment. Here in #Cambodia, one of the goals of the National Immunization Program (NIP) is to reduce Hepatitis-B prevalence to less than 1% by 2017. The NIP has made a significant impact on the reduction of hepatitis and other vaccine preventable diseases, contributing to important health gains across the country. \n\nHepatitis-B immunization in Cambodia has increased dramatically since its introduction in 2001. The Ministry of Health is working with a number of local and international partners, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), UNICEF, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, CDC, and others to provide services and increase community awareness of - and demand for - immunization to combat hepatitis and other diseases. Learn more about hepatitis and what is being done around the world at http://www.who.int/campaigns/hepatitis-day/2016/en/.",

        "eng": "Erland Herfindahl         (GSP)   Herfindahl   (GMAC)  Pactics Factory   Suntex Factory   GSP  \n\n GSP   Julie Chung        go.usa.gov/xgbYT \n\nOffice of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) Deputy Assistant Erland Herfindahl had a successful visit to #Cambodia from July 25-28 to promote the expansion of the Generalized System of Preferences (GSP) program. Along with a representative from the U.S. Department of Labor, Mr. Herfindahl met with the Minister of Commerce, GMAC - Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia, and toured the Pactics Factory in Siem Reap as well as the Suntex Factory in Phnom Penh. The inclusion of Cambodian-made travel goods in the GSP will help diversify the economic base and alleviate poverty in Cambodia.\n\nThe benefits of GSP depend on a commitment to internationally-recognized workers' rights.         "eng": "#AmbHeidt & Mrs. Heidt Tour Khmer Art Collection at The Cleveland Museum of Art\n Heidt  Heidt  Cleveland\n\nThe Ambassador and Mrs. Heidt took time out of their summer vacation last week to see the Indian and Southeast Asian Art collection at the Cleveland Museum of Art (CMA), one of the leading art museums in the United States.  The CMA has one of the worlds highest quality collections of Angkorean and pre-Angkorean art, which includes an exquisite 7th century sculpture of Ganesha. They also toured several of the CMAs conservation laboratories. There they saw a nearly 200-kilogram fragment believed to be from a Krishna Lifting Mount Govardhan statue, originally found at Phnom Da in 1935 and returned by the  National Museum to the CMA in October 2015. The CMA plans to exhibit the restored Krishna statue in 2017.\n\nThe CMA has a very active cooperative agreement with the Ministry of Culture and Fine Art ( :) and the National Museum. In May 2015, it voluntarily returned to #Cambodia a 10th-century statue of Hanuman after uncovering evidence that it was likely looted during Cambodias civil war. At the same time, the CMA signed a Memorandum of Understanding on cultural cooperation with the National Museum, the first such agreement between the National Museum and a U.S. museum.\n\n Heidt  Heidt      Cleveland (CMA)    CMA    Ganesha     CMA         Govardhan     CMA  National Museum     CMA   \n\n CMA   :      CMA        CMA      ",

        "eng": "      Nirmita      (CLA)           Corrina Bonshek  Koji Nakano  Sean Heim         Vicky Ray  Grammy  \n\nInitiated by the award-winning Cambodian-American Dr. Chinary Ung, the Nirmita Composers Workshop is dedicated to training the next generation of musical composers from #Cambodia and the Mekong region. With support from the U.S. Embassy, Cambodian Living Arts (CLA) recently hosted a group of world-class composers and performers for a two-week workshop and concert in Siem Reap, where traditional Cambodian instruments were paired with western classical music styles. The workshop and concert featured works by Dr. Ung, Cambodia's Keo Sophy, Australia's Corrina Bonshek of Australia, Japan's Koji Nakano, Sean Heim of the United States, and others. After the concert in Siem Reap, a special piano recital was held in Phnom Penh at the Him Sophy School Of Music featuring #Grammy-nominated American pianist Vicki Ray, who discussed how her visit to Cambodia has inspired her and helped her to better understand the music created by Cambodian composers.",

        "eng": "During the 2016 U.S. presidential campaign, many students in the United States will participate in \"mock presidential debates\" as a way to develop their public speaking and analytical skills. In #Cambodia, The U.S. Ambassador's Youth Council is looking for participants to put their skills to the test in the \"Model Prime Ministerial Debate\" competition (MPM Debate).\n\nMPM Debate encourages young Cambodians to practice their presentation skills and have fun debating, all while gaining a better understanding of how the Presidential debates in the United States help Americans decide who to vote for as the next #POTUS. There will also be prizes for the winners of the project's final competition in October.  \n\nInterested in signing up?     "2016-08-05T05:40:56+0000": {
        "eng": "Meet United States Air Force Staff Sergeant (SSgt) Virak Dara, a first generation Cambodian-American serving at Cannon Air Force Base in the U.S. state of New Mexico. He is part of a Defense Institute for Medical Operations (DIMO) capacity-building mission in #Cambodia. The DIMO team - comprised of medical and public health experts from the Air Force and U.S. Public Health Service - spent this week teaching a course on disaster preparedness to emergency managers from each of Cambodia's provinces. Not only did SSgt Dara serve as support staff and translator for the team; since he grew up in Phnom Penh he was a cultural liaison during courses and exercises, helping to amplify the lessons taught by the instructors. The team's chief said, SSgt Dara is a real force multiplier, hugely contributing to this missions success.\"\n\nSSgt Dara moved to the United States when he was 16 years old with his father, mother and older brother. Growing up in Lowell, Massachusetts, he graduated high school in 2004, attended college, and decided to join the Air Force in 2007. He has excelled in his military service, earning the title of distinguished graduate for Civil Engineering, serving two tours in Afghanistan, achieving high language proficiency through the Language Enabled Airman Program, and his recent promotion to the rank of E-6. Please join the U.S. Embassy in thanking SSgt Dara for his service - both to the United States and to Cambodia.",

Cambodia is the tenth and newest member of ASEAN, joining the organization in 1999.\n---------------------------------------------------\nHere are some quick facts about ASEAN:\n\n#ASEAN has ten member states#Brunei, #Burma, #Cambodia, #Indonesia, #Laos, #Malaysia, #Philippines, #Singapore, #Thailand, & #Vietnam\n\nIf #ASEAN were a single country, it would be the seventh largest economy in the world.\n\nThe United States was the first non-ASEAN country to name an Ambassador to #ASEAN in 2008.  In June 2010, the United States became the first non-ASEAN country to establish a dedicated Mission to #ASEAN in Jakarta@USMission2ASEAN\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n\nLast week, U.S. Secretary John Kerry issued a statement celebrating this important milestone.     "2016-08-12T08:09:03+0000": {
        "eng": "   USAID         Heidt             \n\nThe Royal Government of #Cambodia and USAID Cambodia implementing partner Wildlife Conservation Society signed a carbon credit project agreement on August 11, 2016, witnessed by Ambassador Heidt and Minister of Environment H.E. Say Samal. This agreement will implement Cambodia's first large-scale private-sector sale of carbon credits, which will benefit an important climate change mitigation project in Keo Seima Wildlife Sanctuary, which covers 300,000 hectares in Mondulkiri province.\n\n    (REDD+)            '\n\nThe carbon credit transfer took place under the UN-backed Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation program (REDD+). This transfer will avoid 14 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent emissions over a 10-year period between 2010 and 2019.\n\n  Heidt    REDD+    \n\nIn his remarks, Ambassador Heidt said that this new agreement would \"lay the groundwork for additional REDD+ agreements in the future that will benefit both Cambodias forests and the communities that live in and around them\"\n\nTo see the Ambassador's full remarks go to https://kh.usembassy.gov/remarks-ambassador-william-heidt-signing-ceremony-project-agreement-keo-seima-wildlife-sanctuary-redd-project/.\n\nPhotos: USAID", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153932425073224",

        "eng": "  USAID      \n\nA recent workshop by the #Cambodia Ministry of Environment called for assistance in exploring the effects of climate change on available groundwater in Cambodia.  Through USAID Cambodia's liaison U.S. Pacific Command (PACOM), the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers responded to the Ministry's need to measure and monitor groundwater resources.  \n\n Evan Ting            Andrea Stone  USAID\n\nThe workshop opening ceremony included U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Program Manager Evan Ting, Ministry of Environment Officials Secretary General H.E. TIN Ponlok and H.E Madam Mey Bouthwithy and #USAID's Andrea Stone. \n\n            \n\nThe event continued with workshop participants from other Ministries and local NGOs conducting a site visit to the Batheay District of Kampong Cham, discussed methods for determining groundwater table at a former mine pit near Cheung Chhnok Village and weighed options for water distribution/treatment techniques at the water tower for the Tang Krang commune.  All involved came away with concepts and tools that can be used to further study the impact of climate change in Cambodia.    \n\n \nTo see more photos from this event, go to https://www.flickr.com/photos/usaid_cambodia/sets/72157669279097513/with/28850840371/",

    "2016-08-16T06:05:36+0000": {
        "eng": "#AmbHeidt and U.S. Foreign Agriculture Service Administrator Phil Karsting  visited students at Thlock and Wat Run Primary Schools in Siem Reap this past weekend to observe firsthand the outstanding work done by the World Food Programme (WFP) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).  These students are among thousands of children at 850 primary schools across #Cambodia receiving nutritious meals through USDA's McGovern-Dole Program, which encourages school attendance and provides lifelong lessons about nutrition and food safety. During the visit, Mr. Karsting signed an agreement to provide a $15.2 million grant which enables the WFP to continue a multi-year school feeding program that provides school and take home meals for approximately 160,000 children each year.  \n\nSince 2001, USDA has provided a total of $45.8 million to the WFP.  The United States actively supports the WFPs goal to improve food security and nutrition for the most vulnerable while promoting long-term development in Cambodia through programs designed to break the poverty cycle. To learn more about these efforts taking place around the globe, please visit http://www.fas.usda.gov/programs/mcgovern-dole-food-education-program.\n\nUSAID Cambodia",

        "eng": "        (USAID) \n\n     USAID       \n\n                      \n\n  worldhumanitarianday.org \n\n#WorldHumanitarianDay was celebrated last week  when aid-worker heroes  who help and advocate for millions of people affected by crises around the world are honored.  Two active humanitarian forces in Cambodia today are #USAID and the U.S. Navy #Seabees.\n\nIn 24 years of operation USAID Cambodia has provided over $1 billion in assistance to the Cambodian people, much of it in humanitarian and rehabilitation assistance to meet the basic needs of Cambodians.\n\nSince 2008, the Seabees have constructed water wells, clinics, and other modern facilities throughout Cambodia. They also provide basic life support (BLS) training on proper sanitation and hygiene, snake bites, and basic stitching methods. Over the next three years the Seabees will construct new facilities throughout six provinces, serving more than 77,000 people in over 90 villages.\n\nTo learn more about helping others go to worldhumanitarianday.org\n\n#ShareHumanity  #WHD2016",

        "eng": "   !  Woodrow Wilson               \n\n       \n\n      https://www.fws.gov/international/wildlife-trafficking\n\n  ?  ?\n\nToday the U.S. National Park Service celebrates its 100th anniversary! Signed into law on August 25, 1916 by President Woodrow Wilson, the National Park Service was created to preserve and protect federally-owned parks and other properties. The National Park Service manages more than 400 protected areas, including monuments, battlefields, seashores, and even the White House. \n\nThe National Park Service is part of the U.S. Department of the Interior, which is responsible for the management and conservation of federal land and natural resources.  Representatives from the U.S. Department of the Interior were in #Cambodia this week to discuss ways to prevent wildlife trafficking.\n\nMore information about the U.S. governments efforts to end wildlife trafficking worldwide can be found here: https://www.fws.gov/international/wildlife-trafficking.\n\nWe're including photos of a few of our favorite U.S. national parks below.         "eng": "Ambassador Heidt made an official trip to Svay Rieng and Prey Veng this week to see what has changed since he last visited as a U.S. Embassy Economic Officer more than 16 years ago.\n\nThe Ambassador visited the bustling border at Bavet and met with Svay Rieng Governor Men Vibol and leading NGOs including LICADHO /  (Cambodian League for the Promotion and Defense of Human Rights), The Cambodian Center for the Protection of Children's Rights (CCPCR), COMFREL (The Committee for Free and Fair Elections in Cambodia), and the Rural Aid Organization (RAO). Deputy Governor Lieng Sreymol. The name  Papahnaumokukea (pronounced Pa-pa-hah-now-mo-koo-ah-keh-ah) comes from an ancient Hawaiian tradition about the formation of the Hawaiian Islands, where President Obama was born.   \n\nThe  Papahnaumokukea Marine National Monument contains more than 7,000 species, including whales, birds, and sea turtles.         "eng": "Forty-five special, young leaders in Kompong Thom and Banteay Meanchey provinces had reason to celebrate this weekend when they graduated from the U.S. Embassys English Access Microscholarship Program. The students received their certificates in ceremonies attended by local officials and representatives from the U.S. Embassy Public Affairs Section.\n\n           \n\nThe Access Program provides two years of English-language instruction to academically talented students in underserved communities across Cambodia. These students spent countless hours before and after school and on weekends learning and practicing English, but the hard work paid off!\n\n           !\n\nThe U.S. Embassy has provided the English Access Microscholarship Program in Cambodia for more than 11 years. The U.S. Embassy Phnom Penh  in conjunction with American English for Educators and eLearning company Voxy  is now accepting applications for the 2016 E-Teacher Scholarship Program.     "2016-09-01T09:43:38+0000": {
        "eng": " Arizona !\n   (AUPP)  Arizona        \n\n Arizona  AUPP         Arizona   \n\n Heidt         \n\n  https://kh.usembassy.gov/remarks-ambassador-william-heidt-launch-american-university-phnom-penh-university-arizonas-dual-degree-program/\n\nThe University of Arizona is coming to #Cambodia!\n\nAt a ceremony today at the American University of Phnom Penh (AUPP), the University of Arizona announced that it will be opening a micro campus in Phnom Penh, becoming the first U.S. university to establish a physical presence in Cambodia.\n\nThe University of Arizona and AUPP signed a dual degree program agreement, under which students will be able to study full time in Cambodia and receive degrees from both schools. To begin, the program will offer undergraduate degrees in business and law. The University of Arizona plans to include degrees in engineering and architecture in the near future.\n\nAmbassador Heidt served as a witness to the signing of this historic agreement, saying that, As the U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, I take great pride when U.S. institutions make strategic investments here, especially when those investments stand to develop the human and intellectual resources of Cambodias dynamic youth sector, represented by the young people who are with us today.\n\nClick here to read the Ambassadors full remarks:  https://kh.usembassy.gov/remarks-ambassador-william-heidt-launch-american-university-phnom-penh-university-arizonas-dual-degree-program/",

    "2016-09-04T13:06:25+0000": {
        "eng": "Security Message for U.S. Citizens: Possible Demonstrations in Phnom Penh\nSeptember 5, 2016\n\nThe United States Embassy in Phnom Penh alerts U.S. citizens residing in or traveling to #Cambodia of the possibility of political demonstrations in Phnom Penh on Monday, September 5.  The Cambodia National Rescue Party (CNRP) has announced planned demonstrations at or around CNRP Headquarters, located at 576 National Road 2, as well as at or around the Phnom Penh Municipal Court, located on Samdech Monireth Blvd. Additional demonstrations may occur throughout Phnom Penh through the week of September 5, including in the areas surrounding CNRP headquarters and the Phnom Penh Municipal Court.\n\nU.S. citizens are reminded of the Embassys existing guidance that even demonstrations intended to be peaceful can turn confrontational and have the potential to escalate into violence without warning.  The U.S. Embassy recommends you avoid areas where demonstrations are taking place and exercise caution when in the vicinity of any large gatherings, protests or demonstrations and immediately leave any area where there are large gatherings.  You should  remain alert of local security developments by monitoring local news reports, exercising vigilance regarding your preparedness and personal security, remaining aware of your surroundings, and planning your activities accordingly.  Please follow the guidance below to receive the most updated security information from the U.S. Embassy.\n\nFor further information:\n\n         See the State Department's travel website (http://travel.state.gov/) for the Worldwide Caution (http://travel.state.gov/content/passports/english/alertswarnings/worldwide-caution.html), Travel Warnings, Travel Alerts, and Cambodia Specific Information.\n\n         Enroll in the Smart Traveler Enrollment Program (https://step.state.gov/step/) to receive security messages and make it easier to locate you in an emergency.\n\n         Contact the U.S. Embassy in Cambodia, located at No. 1, Street 96, Sangkat Wat Phnom, Khan Daun Penh, Phnom Penh, at +855 (0)23 728 402 or + 855 (0)23 728 051, 8:00 am to 5:00 pm, Monday through Friday. After-hours emergency number for U.S. citizens is + 855 (0)23 728 000.\n\n         Call 1-888-407-4747 toll-free in the United States and Canada or 1-202-501-4444 from other countries from 8:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time, Monday through Friday (except U.S. federal holidays).\n\n         Follow us on Twitter (http://twitter.com/travelgov) and Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/travelgov).",

Labor Day is a national holiday that celebrates the contributions workers have made to the strength, prosperity, and well-being of the United States.\n\nThe origins of Labor Day date to the late 1880s, when the formal workforce was overwhelmingly male. Times sure have changed!
