    "2016-09-06T10:13:26+0000": {
        "eng": " Alison  Kyra Carter   University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign         \n\nWhen you picture Angkor Wat, you might think of the imposing and elegant temple surrounded by a thick forest of trees. However, archaeologists now know that when Angkor Wat was built, it was surrounded by a series of mounds that are likely places where people lived. Dr. Alison Kyra Carter, Visiting Assistant Professor, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.\n\n    ?  Greater Angkor Project (GAP)   Sydney \n\nMuch of what is known about life at Angkor Wat comes from inscriptions on stone temple structures, which only tell the stories of the elites. But what about the lives of the ordinary citizens who made Angkor one of the largest population centers of its time? This question is a topic of interest for the scientists of the Greater Angkor Project (GAP)  a joint initiative between the Apsara Authority  and the University of Sydney.\n\n  GAP   Alison Kyra Carter            Carter   Khmer Times      Carter   https://kh.usembassy.gov//household-archaeology-angkor-wa/ \n(   )\n\nLast year, a GAP team led by U.S. archaeologist Dr. Alison Kyra Carter and her colleague Chhay Rachna carefully excavated a single mound that scientists believe used to be the site of a household. This painstaking and difficult work led to some amazing new discoveries, which Dr. Carter wrote about in a recent essay first published in the Khmer Times. The archaeologists found evidence of household activities, including what the people ate and how they cooked their food. \n\nTo read Dr. Carters essay in Khmer, click here: https://kh.usembassy.gov/km/household-archaeology-angkor-wat-kh/\n\nTo read the essay in English, click here: http://www.khmertimeskh.com/news/26973/household-archaeology-at-angkor-wat/.\n\n(Note: This article was translated by the U.S. Embassy with the permission of the author and the APSARA Authority.)",

    "2016-09-07T10:31:19+0000": {
        "eng": "UPDATE: The transcript of Sophanna's question and President Obama's answer is included below.\n\nCongratulations to Cambodian #YSEALI member Sophanna, who was picked by President Obama to ask a question during the Presidents YSEALI Town Hall this afternoon in Luang Prabang, Laos. Sophanna asked the President about which of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals is most important. You can see the Presidents answer (ending poverty)  and the entire Town Hall  by following this link: https://www.whitehouse.gov/live/president-obama-holds-yseali-town-hall-0.\n\nPRESIDENT OBAMA:  Okay.  So, Cambodia, we have somebody from Cambodia?  Right here, this young man.  By the way, everybody looks very good in their native clothes.  Those of you who are just wearing shirts, you look good too.  (Laughter.)  But I appreciate how nice everybody looks today.  Go ahead.\n \nQ    Thank you, Mr. President.  And actually my question was taken by one of the fellows, so I just start with the second question.  If the 17 goals of the SDG were implemented in the United States, which goals should be the top priority, and why is it?  And how you got to deal with it?  Thank you.  (Applause.)\n \nPRESIDENT OBAMA:  That's a good question.  So for those of you who didn't hear the question, SDG is the Sustainable Development Goals that were an update on the original set of goals.  Keep in mind how much progress we've made on those goals over the last 20 years.\n \nThe number of people who we've seen rise out of extreme poverty, the number of people who are now able to have enough to eat, the reduction in infant mortality has been remarkable.  So we've made real progress.  Worldwide, people are much better off now than they were just 20 years ago, and I think we can make similar progress going forward.\n \nI've actually asked our teams to look at where in these Sustainable Development Goals do we have work to do in the United States?  And although we're still evaluating that, I would say that the areas where we still fall short are -- there are still too many children in poverty in the United States.  Now, they're not suffering extreme poverty of the sort that you see in parts of India or China or Laos or Cambodia, but we have children who are very poor and who still aren't getting enough to eat.  That is also connected to education.  And we still have a lot of children in a country so wealthy that on a day-to-day basis are not getting the kinds of educational opportunities that they deserve.\n \nSo I would say that the way forward for us involves addressing those pockets of poverty, and starting with kids.  And we have enough wealth to do it.  The question is whether we have the political will to make the investments in these communities, many of which are in inner cities.  Oftentimes they are poor African American or Latino who are still held back historically by discrimination.  And sometimes it's harder to get the society as a whole to invest in these kids.\n \nBut if we're going to be successful, we're going to have to do it.  This goes to a question that was asked earlier -- the United States, by the year 2050 -- which is only 35 years from now -- will no longer be a majority-white country -- think about that -- because the birth rates for particularly people of Hispanic background, but also Asians, in American, is much faster, much higher. \n \nSo if those kids today who are poor aren't provided opportunity, our society as a whole is going to be poorer, because that's going to be the workforce of the future.  And that's where I think we have to make the most progress.", 
        "id": "79770243223_10153999019003224", 
        "kh": "’’––"
    }, 
    "2016-09-08T06:07:53+0000": {
        "eng": "  !    UNESCO      \nToday marks the 50th anniversary of International #LiteracyDay! In 1966, UNESCO proclaimed September 8 as a day to recognize the importance of literacy to individuals, communities, and societies around the world.\n\n   Julie Chung   Monument Books and Toys \nIn honor of Literacy Day, our #ThrowbackThursday photo is from April, when Deputy Chief of Mission Julie Chung read to young students at the Reading Center at Monument Books and Toys Cambodia.\n\n ()?\nWhat are you planning to read today (besides Facebook, of course)?\n\nFollow this link to learn more about International Literacy Day: http://www.unesco.org//ce/international-days/literacy-day/",

Today, she shared her story with Ambassador Heidt and the staff of the U.S. Embassy, including her former colleagues at the Embassys Naval Medical Research Unit (NAMRU-2), where she worked as a scientist from 2011 to 2014.\n\n      \n\nNary talked about her life as a runner, which started as a hobby during post-graduate studies before rising to Olympic levels.         "eng": "VisionFund Cambodia, a microfinance institution, opened its newest branch in Phnom Penh today in a ceremony attended by Ambassador Heidt and other distinguished guests. \n\nVisionFund Cambodia has been providing loans to Cambodians since 2003. Ensuring that economic growth is broad based and reduces poverty has become a fundamental development challenge.         "eng": " (CSPO)          \n\nThe Cambodian School of Prosthetics and Orthotics (CSPO) provides free physical rehabilitation services to Cambodians in need, including people with birth defects or who have lost limbs in accidents. Just as important, it is a training center for Cambodian and international students who want to help others, offering a degree program for prosthetists and orthotists.  (Prosthetists and orthotists make and fit artificial limbs and other devices to help people regain mobility.)\n\nCSPO   ( Cambodia Trust)   CSPO         CSPO   \n\nCSPO is part of UK-based NGO Exceed (formerly called Cambodia Trust), which receives funding from around the world, including the United States.  CSPO has been in operation for more than 20 years and has trained more than 70 Cambodians, along with dozens of international students.  In addition to physical rehabilitation, CSPO also offers services to help their clients gain access to education and jobs and to improve their overall quality of life.\n\n  Jay Raman   CSPO   \n\nEarlier this week, U.S. Embassy Public Affairs Officer Jay Raman was invited to tour the CSPO campus in Phnom Penh, where he met with staff and was impressed by the painstaking work that goes into making prosthetic devices.\n\n CSPO  http://cspo.org.kh/   CSPO       thearith@cspo.org.kh  023 881 493 \n\nLearn more about CSPO here: http://cspo.org.kh/.     "2016-09-14T07:40:27+0000": {
        "eng": "36 Countries Issue Joint Statement of Concern on Human Rights in #Cambodia\n\n    \n\nA joint statement expressing concern about the human rights situation in Cambodia was issued today at the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) in Geneva, Switzerland. The statement was read by U.S. Ambassador to the UNHRC Keith Harper on behalf of Albania, Australia, Canada, Japan, Macedonia, Norway, Switzerland, the 28 EU member states, and the United States.\n\n       Keith Harper            \n\nThe statement reads in part: We are deeply concerned about the current escalation of political tensions in Cambodia, which threatens legitimate activities by opposition parties and human rights NGOs.  There is particular concern about the appearance that legal action is being disproportionately pursued against critics of the government. We are equally concerned about the status of culture of dialogue between the two main political parties, which has ceased to function. We lament the recent murder of commentator and analyst Kem Ley and note the chilling effect this crime has had upon civil society and independent voices in Cambodia.\n\n                  \n\nThe statement also reiterates previous calls by UN Special Rapporteurs to to ensure a safe and enabling environment for human rights defenders and civil society, which play a critical role in holding the Government to account and bringing benefits of human rights to the whole of Cambodian society.  \n\n      \n\nThe full statement is available in English here: https://kh.usembassy.gov/human-rights-situation-cambodia-joint-statement/   \n\n  https://kh.usembassy.gov/km/human-rights-situation-cambodia-joint-statement-km/",

The ocean feeds billions of people, employs millions of workers, and generates trillions of dollars in the world economy.  Secretary John Kerry.\n\nThe third #OurOcean Conference will take place in Washington, DC on September 15-16, hosted by U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry.     "2016-09-19T09:12:34+0000": {
        "eng": "     John Kerry       Washington, D.C.     Barack Obama  Leonado DiCaprio    ,     \n\nOn September 15-16, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry convened heads of state, scientists, business leaders, NGOs, and others to Washington, D.C. for the third #OurOcean conference.  President Barack Obama and actor Leonardo DiCaprio delivered remarks at the conference, which generated more than $5.2 billion in commitments to help protect the ocean and inspired nearly 40 significant new or expanded marine protected areas.\n\n                  \n\nCambodian Minister of Environment Say Samal gave a presentation outlining steps the Cambodian government has taken to support environmental preservation, including the creation of Cambodias first marine protected area, which covers 405 square kilometers in the waters of the Koh Rong Archipelago. Minister Samal noted that Cambodia has worked to improve natural resource protection, biodiversity conservation, and sustainable development. He called on countries to show more commitments to improving the environment through dedicated funding and by transferring technology to developing countries to support enforcement of environmental regulations.\n\n  Catherine Novelli   \n\nDuring his visit, Minister Samal also met with Catherine Novelli, Under Secretary for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment for the U.S. State Department.\n\n   http://1000oceanactions.org/ \n\nClick here to see how countries around the world are working to save our oceans: http://1000oceanactions.org/.\n#Cambodia",

    "2016-09-20T05:07:55+0000": {
        "eng": "    \n\nA topic of increasing interest in the world of finance is ethical banking, where banks adopt environmentally and socially conscious practices.\n\n  USAID      \n\nNow, thanks to a new project supported by USAID Cambodia, for the first time ever Cambodian banks have agreed to consider environmental and social impacts when making decisions about what projects to support. This agreement sets a new model for the region for corporate social responsibility by major banking institutions. \n\n      (ABC)   ABC    USAID    \n\nThe new commitment was signed on Monday by Association of Banks in Cambodia (ABC) acting chairman Charles Vann. The ABC designed the language with technical support from USAID's Mekong Partnership for the Environment (MPE) regional program. Other partners include the Ministry of Environment, the National Bank of Cambodia, and the National Council for Sustainable Development.\n\n Julie Chung          \n\nU.S. Embassy Charge daffaires Julie Chung spoke at the signing event, noting that Integrating environmental and social principles into investment decisions is not only important to ensure long-term business growth, but it is also integral to protecting and sustaining the human and natural resources that Cambodia will need in the future.\n\n https://kh.usembassy.gov/remarks-charge-daffaires-association-banks-cambodia-sustainable-finance-initiative-launch-signing/ \n\nRead the full remarks here: https://kh.usembassy.gov/remarks-charge-daffaires-association-banks-cambodia-sustainable-finance-initiative-launch-signing/.\n#Cambodia",

    "2016-09-27T11:30:38+0000": {
        "eng": " Heidt    (AFCP)               \n\nAmbassador Heidt traveled to Takeo province on Monday to announce officially a 2016 Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation grant of $121,745 to the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts. The Ambassador and Minister of Culture and Fine Arts Phoeurng Sackona participated in a ceremony at the Phnom Da archaeological site in Angkor Borei district, followed by a tour of Phnom Da and the nearby Angkor Borei Museum.\n\n              \n\nThis latest grant will help the Ministry of Culture and Fine Arts to document 24 important monuments from the 6th and 7th centuries in the provinces of Kampong Cham, Kampong Chhnang, Kampong Speu, Kampot, Prey Veng, Tbong Khmum, and Takeo.\n\n AFCP        \n\nThe Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation is an initiative of the U.S. State Department that supports the preservation of cultural sites, cultural objects, and forms of traditional cultural expression in more than 100 developing countries around the world, including Cambodia.\n\n    ,       AFCP    https://kh.usembassy.gov/km/education-culture-km/u-s-government-assistance-cambodian-cultural-heritage-preservation-km/ \n\nSince 2001, the U.S. government has invested more than $3.8 million to support cultural heritage preservation programs in Cambodia, including 18 grants from the Ambassadors Fund for Cultural Preservation. To see the full list of projects, click here: https://kh.usembassy.gov/education-culture/u-s-government-assistance-cambodian-cultural-heritage-preservation/. \n\n#AFCP #Cambodia",

        "eng": "Congratulations to Sipar Cambodia, which is being honored by The Library of Congress for its inspiring efforts to promote literacy in #Cambodia! Sipar is an NGO that has worked in Cambodia since 1992 to establish libraries and make books more accessible to garment factory workers, prisoners, underprivileged children, and other vulnerable groups. #AmbHeidt and Mrs. Heidt recently met with Sipars director, Hok Sothik, to learn more about their important work. \n\nSipar will be recognized during the 2016 Library of Congress Literacy Awards celebration next month in Washington, DC. The Library of Congress - the worlds largest library - created the Literacy Awards program to honor organizations working to promote literacy and reading worldwide.         "eng": "Apply now for the Spring 2017 #YSEALI Academic Fellows Program!\n\nYSEALI members between the ages of 18 and 25 are eligible to apply for the YSEALI Academic Fellows Program, which offers a month-long study opportunity at prestigious U.S. colleges and universities. Academic Fellows will build their leadership skills while focusing on one of three themes: civic engagement, environmental and natural resource management, and entrepreneurship and economic development.\n\nFellows will visit the United States for five weeks, with four weeks of classroom activities and a one-week study tour, ending in Washington, DC. The programs are scheduled to begin in February and March 2017.\n\nSok Sopheak Panha is an Academic Fellow alumnus from 2016, when she studied civic engagement at Kennesaw State University in Georgia. \"The Academic Fellows program helped me to have a new way of thinking, Panha says.         "eng": "UPDATE - ZIKA VIRUS IN SOUTHEAST ASIA\nOn September 29, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) posted a notice regarding #Zika in Southeast Asia. Travelers have returned from certain areas of the region with Zika virus infection. Several countries have reported occasional cases or small outbreaks of Zika virus infections. Though no new cases of Zika have been reported in #Cambodia since 2010, travelers to Southeast Asia are advised to be aware of the latest guidelines. For more country-specific information, please visit https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/page/zika-virus-southeast-asia.\n\n-  Zika \n     (CDC)  Zika      Zika        https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/page/zika-virus-southeast-asia ",

        "eng": " Sarah Fox                  \n\n          Fox              \n\n Sarah Fox    http://go.usa.gov/xkqJd \n\nThe U.S. Department of States Special Representative for International Labor Affairs Sarah Fox recently completed her official visit to #Cambodia. From October 3-5, she met with members of the Royal Government of Cambodia, civil society, the private sector, and other stakeholders to discuss freedom of association, labor courts, minimum wage, and other issues.\n\nDuring talks with Minister of Labor and Vocational Training H.E. Ith Sam Heng and Minister of Commerce H.E. Pan Sorasak, Mrs. Fox learned more about what the Cambodian government is doing to foster inclusive growth with mature industrial relations. She also spoke with The Arbitration Council Foundation about their success in mediating labor and management disputes. She met with civil society leaders and labor unions to discuss workers' rights, and with international brands and factory representatives to discuss Cambodias competitiveness and future growth.\n\nTo learn more about Sarah Fox and the Department of State - Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, please visit http://go.usa.gov/xkqJd.",

    "2016-10-06T04:24:47+0000": {
        "eng": "          ()  CFK ()      USAID   YSEALI   YSEALI       CFK       CFK      \n\nPanhchapor Chhim, Seyha Doeurn, Sereyvuth Thai, and adviser Dr. Reasmey Tan from the Institute of Technology of Cambodia -  make up \"Team CFK\" (Cam Fermentation Kit), one of top three finalists of the USAID Asia & Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative World Food Innovation Challenge! #FoodChallenge2016 invited #YSEALI members from across the region to submit their technology solutions to challenges in agriculture, aquaculture, and fisheries. Team CFK developed a project to improve quality and sanitation in cucumber pickling, which can help farmers preserve their crops and contribute to food security in #Cambodia. \"We believe that we can reduce losses in vegetable harvests, and at the same time produce a better pickle for everyone,\" say the members of Team CFK.\n\n       Austin  Texas        CFK  !\n\nThe team will now present their innovation at the ASEAN Ministerial Meeting on Science and Technology later this month in Cambodia. They will compete against teams from Indonesia and Malaysia for the grand prize of a study trip to Austin, Texas - one of the main technology hubs in the United States - in March 2017. Join us in congratulating Team CFK and wishing them good luck!",

    "2016-10-06T07:28:39+0000": {
        "eng": "Ben Skinner - an award-winning journalist and author of \"A Crime So Monstrous: Face-to-Face with Modern Day Slavery\" - visited Phnom Penh earlier this week to participate in a U.S. Department of State speaker program on combating human trafficking. From October 3-4, he met with a number of key stakeholders working on anti-trafficking in persons (TIP) and migration issues in #Cambodia.\n\nMr. Skinner first spoke with youth developing short films about human trafficking as part of the Chaktomuk Short Film Festival. He then met with members of the National Committee for Counter-Trafficking, including Secretary of State for the Ministry of Interior and Vice-Chairwoman H.E. Chou Bun Eng, to learn what the Cambodian government is doing to combat TIP. He also participated in a round-table discussion featuring civil society representatives from NGOs such as the Chab Dai Coalition, ADHOC-Cambodia, Ratanak International, Legal Support for Children and Women - LSCW, Winrock International, Legal Aid of Cambodia, and Samaritan's Purse. \"Cambodia has made progress,\" said Mr. Skinner, while noting the ongoing efforts of government, civil society, and the private sector to further reduce human trafficking. To learn more, please visit http://go.usa.gov/xkruW.\n\nBen Skinner    (\"A Crime So Monstrous: Face-to-Face with Modern Day Slavery\")             \n\n Skinner                   Cha Dai Coalition, ADHOC-Cambodia, Ratanak International, Legal Support fro Children and Women, LSCW, Winrock International, Legal Aid of Cambodia  Samaritans Purse   Skinner           http://go.usa.gov/xkrJW ",

        "eng": "More U.S. companies are choosing to invest in #Cambodia. This store is more than just a place for coffee and conversation, CDA Chung said.
